Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about. A lot. It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was a kid, having a kid. And that just…didn't feel right.

I talked to my dad, and he was…surprisingly cool about it. He didn't freak out or anything. He just listened. And he reminded me that I had a life to live. A life that didn't have to be completely derailed by a baby.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…amazing. They were already trying to adopt, and they were just so excited about the possibility of having a family. They were stable, and loving, and they had a beautiful home. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give it that. Not then. Not ever, probably.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were ready, who were financially secure, who could give it opportunities I just couldn't. I wanted it to be wanted, you know? And Mark and Vanessa, they *wanted* it. So badly.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right one. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby a life. And that's…something I can live with.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't pretty. But it was my decision. And I stand by it. Even now.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't had enough time to think about it.

Look, before all this happened, love was…easy. Like, crushes and stuff. Superficial. But getting pregnant? That kinda forces you to re-evaluate everything.

I learned that love isn't just about butterflies and holding hands. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if that means letting them go. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about making a really hard decision, even when it breaks your heart, because it's the right thing to do.

Giving the baby up…that wasn't about *not* loving it. It was about loving it enough to give it a life I couldn't provide. Mark and Vanessa, they were ready. They were excited. They could give that kid everything. And that's what mattered.

And responsibility? Oh boy. That was a whole other level. It wasn't just about taking care of myself anymore. It was about taking responsibility for a life I created. It was about facing the consequences of my actions. It was about growing up, whether I wanted to or not.

Paul…he helped with that. He wasn't perfect, but he showed me what it meant to be a good person. He was there for me, even when I was being a total mess. And he taught me that it's okay to ask for help.

And even Bleeker, that weirdo…he showed me that love comes in all shapes and sizes. He was a good friend, and he was always there to listen.

So, yeah. I learned that love is complicated. And responsibility is even more complicated. But they're both worth it. They're both about making choices, and living with those choices, and trying to be a good person.

It's still kinda scary, honestly. But I think I'm okay. I think I'm figuring things out. And I think I'm ready for whatever comes next. Even if it's just more awkward conversations and cheesy tater tots.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don't expect a heartfelt monologue. That's not really my style.

Look, when you find out you're pregnant at sixteen, life kinda throws a whole bunch of garbage at you, right? And you can either curl up in a ball and cry, or you can…make a joke about it. I chose the joke route. Mostly.

It wasn't about *not* being scared or confused or totally freaked out. It was about having something to push back against all the seriousness. Like, if I could make someone laugh, even for a second, it meant I had some control. It meant I wasn't just a walking, talking mistake.

My sarcasm was a shield, I guess. It kept people at arm's length, but it also let me process things without completely falling apart. It was a way to deflect, to avoid having to deal with the really heavy stuff all the time.

And honestly, it was just…easier. It's easier to make a snarky comment than to explain how you're feeling when you don't even know how you're feeling.

Plus, Paul and Mark…they got my humor. They didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. They just…laughed with me. And that was a really big deal.

It wasn't a perfect coping mechanism, obviously. I still had a lot of tough moments. But my wit, my sarcasm, my ability to find the funny in the absurd…it helped me get through it. It helped me stay me, even when everything was changing.

It's kinda like…if you're gonna be stuck in a mess, you might as well make a joke about it. It doesn't make the mess go away, but it makes it a little more bearable. And sometimes, that's all you can ask for.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…deep? Fine. It's not like I haven't had time to think about it.

Look, I put up a pretty good front, right? Sarcastic, quick with a comeback, always trying to seem like I had it all figured out. But underneath all that, I was a total mess. A confused, scared, pregnant mess.

My vulnerability…that was the hardest part. Letting anyone see that I wasn't as tough as I pretended to be. Telling my dad, telling Paul…it felt like ripping off a band-aid, except the band-aid was my entire carefully constructed facade.

And the search for identity? That was constant. Before the baby, I was just…Juno. A girl who liked records and hanging out with her best friend. But then suddenly, I was a *mom*. Or, I was going to be a mom. And that changed everything.

I had to figure out who I was *outside* of that. Was I still Juno? Or was I just…a vessel? It was terrifying.

Honestly, the whole pregnancy forced me to grow up way faster than I was ready for. I had to make some really hard decisions, and I had to own them. Giving up the baby wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing.

And through all of it, my vulnerability actually became my strength. It allowed me to connect with people on a deeper level. It allowed me to ask for help when I needed it. It allowed me to be honest with myself about what I wanted and what I needed.

And the search for identity? It's still ongoing, honestly. I'm still figuring things out. But I've learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be messy and imperfect. And it's okay to change your mind.

My journey wasn't about finding a perfect answer. It was about learning to be okay with the questions. And learning to be okay with myself, even when I didn't have all the answers. It was about realizing that being vulnerable isn't a weakness, it's a strength. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the ones that lead you to the most important discoveries about yourself.

So yeah. That's pretty much it. It was a whole lot of mess, a whole lot of tears, and a whole lot of figuring things out. But I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a sappy monologue. It's just…it was a thing, you know?

Honestly, before all this baby stuff happened, I was pretty good at being independent. Like, fiercely independent. I didn't *need* anyone. Or so I thought. Turns out, needing people isn't a weakness. It's…helpful.

My dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly awesome. He's kinda goofy and clueless sometimes, but he was always there. He didn't judge me, even when I was being a total mess. He just listened. And he made me grilled cheese sandwiches. A lot of grilled cheese sandwiches. That helped.

And then there was Renée, my best friend. She was the one who actually made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She didn't try to fix things, she just…hung out. And she helped me pick out baby names, which was surprisingly stressful.

But I think the biggest surprise was Vanessa Loring, the woman who wanted to adopt my baby. She wasn't what I expected at all. She was…normal. And kind. And she actually *wanted* me in her and Henry's lives. That made a huge difference. Knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for, and that I wouldn't just be…giving it away to strangers…that was huge.

They didn't tell me what to do. They didn't try to convince me to make a different decision. They just…supported me. They let me figure things out on my own, but they were there to catch me when I fell.

It made me realize that being strong isn't about doing everything yourself. It's about letting people help you. It's about accepting support when you need it. And it's about knowing that you're not alone.

So yeah, they contributed a lot. They helped me see that I could handle this. They helped me make the best decision for everyone involved. And they helped me realize that even though I was giving my baby up, I wasn't giving up on my future.

It was…good. It was really good. And I wouldn't have gotten through it without them. Don't tell them I said that, though. It'll go to their heads.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like a rom-com moment, you know? It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows and a sudden realization that my life was about to be perfect.

Honestly? I was mostly just…freaked out. Like, full-on, panic attack freaked out. I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and whether or not Paul Snow was gonna text me back, not…this.

It was a positive pregnancy test, and I just stared at it for, like, a really long time. I think I actually said "Well, crap" out loud. It wasn't a very eloquent moment.

Then I was just…numb. I didn't tell anyone for a while. I just kept it to myself and tried to pretend it wasn't happening. It felt like my whole life had just been turned upside down. Everything I thought I wanted, everything I thought I was going to do…it all just felt…different.

I was scared. Scared of what my parents would say, scared of what my friends would think, scared of what my future would look like. I was also kinda mad. Mad at myself, mad at Paul, mad at the universe.

It wasn't a happy moment. It was a terrifying moment. But it was also…a turning point. It forced me to grow up, to think about things I hadn't thought about before. It forced me to make some really hard decisions.

It wasn't what I expected my junior year to look like, that's for sure. But, you know, life rarely is. It throws you curveballs. And sometimes, those curveballs end up changing your life for the better. Even if you don't realize it at the time.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It kinda shook things up.

With my dad, it was…weird at first. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He's always been kinda quiet and reserved. He didn't really *get* it, I think. He just wanted me to be okay. And he was worried. A lot. We ended up bonding over milkshakes and bad daytime TV, which was…unexpected. It wasn't a big, dramatic moment, just a slow realization that he was still my dad, and he still loved me, even if I was a total mess.

My mom was…intense. She went into full-on nesting mode, even though it wasn't *her* baby. She was all about organic baby food and decorating the nursery, even before I'd decided what I was gonna do with the baby. It was a little overwhelming, but I knew she meant well. She just wanted to make sure everything was perfect.

And then there were Leah and Paul. That was…complicated. Leah was amazing, honestly. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she just listened and offered support. She helped me pick out baby names and went to doctor's appointments with me. She was the best friend anyone could ask for.

Paul…Paul was Paul. He was sweet and awkward and genuinely wanted to do the right thing. But he was also kinda clueless. He didn't really understand what I was going through, and he kept trying to fix things, which wasn't what I needed. But he tried. And that meant a lot.

It definitely changed our friendships. It forced us to grow up, I guess. It made us talk about things we normally wouldn't talk about. It made us realize how much we cared about each other.

It wasn't easy, but it made my relationships stronger, in the end. It showed me who my real friends were, and who was just…there. And it taught me that even when things are messy and complicated, you can still get through it with the people you love.

It was a whole lot of drama, but it was *my* drama. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a little less drama. But you know. Life is what it is.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while balancing a stack of textbooks and trying not to throw up.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was a mess. I was angry, scared, confused…all the things you'd expect a sixteen-year-old to be when she finds out she's pregnant. I spent a lot of time listening to The Moldy Peaches and just…feeling sorry for myself.

But then I started talking to people. My dad, surprisingly, was really supportive. And Paul…well, Paul was Paul. He was kinda clueless, but he tried. And then there was Vanessa, who just…listened. She didn't judge me or tell me what to do. She just let me vent.

And I started going to therapy. Which, yeah, it was awkward at first. But it helped me sort through my feelings and figure out what I wanted.

The biggest thing, though, was realizing I wasn't alone. There were other girls going through the same thing. And knowing that helped me feel less…freaked out.

It wasn't about pretending everything was okay. It was about acknowledging that it was hard, and allowing myself to feel those feelings. And then finding ways to deal with them.

I also found a lot of strength in the decision to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one. Knowing that I was giving the baby a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for it, helped me feel a little bit better.

It was still hard, though. Really hard. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But I kept going. I kept talking. I kept listening to The Moldy Peaches. And eventually, I got through it.

It changed me, obviously. It made me grow up a lot faster than I expected. But it also made me stronger. And it taught me a lot about myself.

So, how did I cope? By talking, by feeling, by making a difficult decision, and by surrounding myself with people who cared about me. And by listening to a lot of really good music.



It wasn't pretty, but it was real. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about this? It was a whole thing, alright? A complicated thing. But fine, I'll explain. Again.

It wasn't like I *chose* Women Now because it was, like, a better building or something. It was about…the vibe. And the people.

Havenbrooke was…intense. All sterile and quiet and judgmental. It felt like a hospital, not a place where a person would make a really hard decision. The protesters outside were awful, too. Really loud and scary. It just felt…wrong.

Women Now was different. It was…calmer. More respectful. The people who worked there were actually *nice*. They didn't try to tell me what to do, they just listened. And they understood. It felt…safer.

Plus, Mark was there. He was volunteering, helping people get inside without having to walk through the protesters. Seeing him there, being supportive…it made a difference. It made me feel less alone.

It wasn't about the facilities or the procedures or anything like that. It was about feeling like I was being treated like a human being, not just a statistic. It was about finding a place where I felt safe and respected.

It was a really hard decision, and I needed to be somewhere that felt…right. And Women Now felt right. It wasn't easy, but it was the best choice for me.

And honestly, I don't really want to talk about it anymore. It's a personal thing, and it's over. Can we move on now? Please?

Ugh. Okay. Wow. That's…direct. And honestly? Still kinda raw, even after all this time. It's not something I talk about a lot.

Look, it wasn't some grand romantic gesture, okay? It wasn't like in the movies. It wasn't even…planned. It just *happened*.

I was scared. Really scared. Finding out I was pregnant was…a lot. And I was trying to figure out what to do, and who I was, and what my life was gonna be like. And Bleeker…he was just *there*. He was always just…there. Quiet and supportive and not judging me.

I think I was looking for…something. Comfort, maybe. A distraction. A way to feel…normal, for a little while. It was stupid, I know. And reckless. And probably not the smartest decision I've ever made.

It wasn't about love, not really. It was about…connection. A desperate attempt to feel something other than fear and confusion.

And honestly? It was a mistake. A really big mistake. It complicated things even more. But it also…helped me realize what I really wanted. And what I *didn't* want.

It's not something I'm proud of, but it's part of my story. And I'm not gonna pretend it didn't happen. It was a messy, complicated, and ultimately important part of figuring out who I am.

Can we…maybe talk about something else now? This is kinda bringing back a lot of feelings.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. Don't even get me started. Everyone always wants to know about Bleeker. It's like, he's the only thing people see when they look at the whole story.

Look, he was…sweet. Really sweet. Like, aggressively sweet. And kinda clueless. But in a…endearing way? I guess? It's hard to explain.

He was a good listener, which was nice. I mean, I do a lot of talking, and most people just tune me out. He actually *heard* me. And he didn't judge me, even when I was being a total mess. Which was, let's be honest, most of the time.

But…we weren't really *on* the same wavelength, you know? He was all about music and feelings and being sensitive. And I was…trying to figure out how to be a responsible adult and give a baby a good life. It was a lot.

I think I liked him because he was safe. He was a constant. He was always there, offering me a guitar and a sympathetic ear. And that was really comforting when everything else was falling apart.

But it wasn't…enough. I needed someone who challenged me, who pushed me to be better. Someone who understood my sarcasm and didn't try to fix me.

So, do I *love* him? I don't know. I cared about him. A lot. But it wasn't the kind of love that lasts forever. It was the kind of love that's perfect for a certain moment in time.

He's a good guy. He deserves to be with someone who appreciates his sweetness and his music. And I…I needed to figure out who *I* was, before I could be with anyone.

It's complicated. Okay? It just…is. And honestly, I'm kinda tired of talking about it. Can we talk about something else? Like, the existential dread of being a teenager? Or the questionable fashion choices of the 80s? Anything but Bleeker.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? People always wanna know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I, at sixteen, could not give that to him. Or her. I didn't even know yet!

I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being a mom. I was still in high school, still trying to decide what I wanted to do with my life. I wasn't ready to put someone else's life before my own. And that's not selfish, it's just…realistic.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…ready. They were already a family, just missing a little piece. They had a house, and a stable life, and they were so excited. They could give the baby opportunities I just couldn't. College funds, vacations, a backyard…things I didn't even have growing up.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing the best life for him. It was about wanting him to be loved and cared for and have everything he needed to thrive.

And honestly? It was also about me. I needed to finish school, I needed to figure out who I was, I needed to have a life of my own. I couldn't do that and be a mom at the same time. Not then.

It was the hardest decision I ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. For everyone.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what the baby deserved. And that's something I had to learn. It's complicated, okay? Don't make me explain it again.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a moment. A really, really awkward moment.

Honestly? I was terrified. Bleeker is…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, and definitely not equipped to handle, like, *life* in general, let alone a baby. I mean, he still brings me those weird mix CDs. Bless his heart.

So, yeah, I was a mess. My palms were sweating, my voice was all shaky, and I kept looking at the floor. I'd rehearsed what I was going to say a million times, but it all just came out wrong. Like, a jumbled mess of apologies and explanations.

I was expecting him to freak out. To run away. To just…disappear. And for a second, he *did* look like he was gonna faint. His face went totally white.

But then…he didn't. He just…sat there. And he listened. And then he asked, like, a million questions. Not judgmental questions, just…curious ones. Like, "What does this mean?" and "Are you okay?" and "Can I help?"

It wasn't the grand, romantic reaction you see in movies. It was…quiet. And awkward. And surprisingly…supportive.

I was still scared, obviously. But a little bit of the weight lifted off my shoulders. Knowing that he wasn't going to abandon me, even though he was totally unprepared, meant a lot.

It wasn't a happy moment, exactly. It was a real moment. A messy, complicated, honest moment. And that's what mattered.

It was the beginning of a lot of things. A lot of hard decisions. A lot of growing up. And a lot of realizing that sometimes, the people you least expect can surprise you.

So, yeah. That's how I felt. Terrified, relieved, and a little bit hopeful. All at the same time. It was…a lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about it, like it's some fascinating sociological experiment. It's not. It's my life.

Honestly? It's terrifying. Like, seriously terrifying. I'm sixteen. I'm supposed to be worrying about getting my driver's license and figuring out what college I want to go to, not changing diapers and dealing with sleep deprivation.

It's not what I planned. Not even close. I had, like, a whole life mapped out, and now it's all…different.

But it's also…weirdly okay. I mean, it's not ideal. But I'm not, like, completely freaking out all the time. I think. Some days I am.

I've been doing a lot of thinking, and talking to Paul and Vanessa, and…it's starting to feel less like a disaster and more like…a really big responsibility. A really big, scary responsibility.

I'm not gonna lie, I'm scared of messing it up. Of not being a good mom. Of ruining this kid's life. But I also feel…protective. Like, this little person is depending on me, and I'm not gonna let them down.

It's just…a lot. I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, and now I'm supposed to be responsible for another human being? It's kinda messed up.

But I'm trying to be realistic. I'm not gonna pretend it's gonna be easy. It's gonna be hard. Really hard. But I'm also trying to be optimistic. Maybe I can do this. Maybe I can be a good mom, even if I'm young.

And honestly? I'm kinda excited. In a really, really scared kind of way. It's gonna change everything, but maybe that's not a bad thing. Maybe it's exactly what I need.

Just…don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…a lot to unpack. Honestly, right now, it feels like we're both just kinda…floating. Like two planets in space, vaguely aware of each other but not really colliding.

Before all this, it was easy. We just hung out, listened to music, made out a little. It was comfortable. Now? It's…different. He's trying, I'll give him that. He's being all supportive and stuff, bringing me ginger ale and asking if I need anything. It's sweet, but it also feels…forced. Like he's reading from a script.

I think he's scared. He's always been kinda quiet and awkward, and this is…a big thing. A *huge* thing. And I don't think he really knows how to handle it. He keeps saying things like, "We'll figure it out," which is nice, but doesn't exactly feel like a plan.

I think it's gonna get harder before it gets easier. We're gonna have to actually *talk* about things. Like, real things. About responsibility and the future and what we both want. And that's not exactly our strong suit.

I'm hoping we can grow up together, you know? That we can both become adults and figure this out. But I'm also realistic. I know it's possible that this will just…break us. That we're too young and too different to make it work.

Right now, I just need him to be…present. To be there for me, even if he doesn't know what to say. And I need to be honest with him, even when it's hard.

It's gonna be a bumpy ride, that's for sure. But maybe, just maybe, we can come out on the other side stronger. Or at least, not completely broken. It's a long shot, but I'm willing to try. For the baby, if not for us.

Ugh. Okay, so the judgment. Yeah, that was…a lot. Like, suddenly everyone's an expert on your life, right? And they all have opinions. And none of them are very nice.

Honestly? I mostly just pretended I didn't care. Which is a total lie, obviously. It stung. A lot. Especially from people I barely even *knew*. Like, seriously, Brenda from chem class? What does *she* know about my life?

But I figured if I acted like it wasn't a big deal, maybe they'd stop making it one. I just kept being me. Sarcastic, a little bit awkward, obsessed with pop tarts. I didn't let them see me sweat.

I leaned *hard* on my friends, too. Paulie and Leah were lifesavers. They didn't judge me, they just…supported me. They made me laugh when I wanted to cry, and they helped me figure things out. Having people on your side makes a huge difference.

And my dad? He was surprisingly cool about it. He was worried, sure, but he was mostly just…there for me. Which is all I really needed.

I also just kinda tuned out the noise. I stopped reading the stupid notes in my locker, I avoided the people who were being jerks, and I focused on what *I* wanted to do. I decided I was giving this baby up for adoption, and that was my decision. And no one else's opinion mattered.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I just wanted to hide under my covers and never come out. But I kept reminding myself that I was doing the right thing. And that eventually, the judgment would fade.

And you know what? It did. People eventually moved on. They found something else to gossip about. And I was able to focus on my life, and on making the best decision for this baby.

So, yeah. Pretend you don't care, lean on your friends, and remember that you're stronger than you think. And if anyone gives you trouble, just tell them to mind their own business. Seriously. It works. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not always easy to talk about, you know? It's not like I regret it, or anything. It's just…complicated.

Honestly, the whole adoption process is kinda weird. Lots of paperwork. Lots of people asking you personal questions. It feels like you're being interviewed for a job, except the job is…giving up your baby. Which is a really messed up way to put it, I guess.

But the people at the agency, they were…okay. They weren't all rainbows and sunshine, but they were helpful. And they seemed to genuinely care about finding a good home for the baby. Which is all I wanted.

And Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good people. They're kinda…normal. Which is good. I didn't want the baby to end up with, like, rock stars or something. They seem like they'll give the baby a really good life. A stable life. A life I…couldn't give right now.

It's not like I don't love the baby. I do. A lot. But I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. And that's okay.

It's hard, though. Really hard. Knowing that someone else is going to raise my kid. Knowing that I won't be there for all the firsts. But I keep telling myself that I'm doing what's best for the baby. And that's gotta count for something, right?

I think…I think it's brave. It's brave to admit that you're not ready. It's brave to make a hard choice. And it's brave to let go.

I still think about the baby, of course. A lot. But I'm trying to focus on the future. On school. On music. On figuring out who I am.

It's not a perfect situation. But it's my situation. And I'm trying to make the best of it. And I hope…I really hope…that the baby will be happy. That's all I want.



It's just…a lot. You know? It's a lot to process. And sometimes, I just need to listen to The Moldy Peaches and try not to think about it too much.

Ugh. Okay, so, the whole baby thing. Yeah. It kinda threw a wrench in my carefully constructed life plan, which, admittedly, didn't go much further than "avoid responsibility and listen to The Moldy Peaches." But still.

Before, I was…Juno. Sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical. I defined myself by my wit, my music taste, my ability to avoid anything remotely resembling emotional vulnerability. I was good at observing people, making fun of them, keeping them at arm's length. It was safe.

Then, suddenly, I wasn't just Juno anymore. I was a *pregnant* Juno. And that changed everything. People started looking at me differently. They stopped seeing me as just a kid and started seeing me as…a potential mother. Which was terrifying.

It forced me to confront things I hadn't even thought about before. Like, what do I actually *want* out of life? What kind of person do I want to be? And, most importantly, what kind of life do I want for this baby?

I had to stop being so flippant and start taking things seriously. I had to think about the future, about responsibility, about sacrifice. It wasn't fun. It was actually really hard.

I had to learn to let people in, to rely on others. Paul and Bleeker, my parents…they all stepped up in ways I never expected. And I had to let them. I couldn't do this alone.

It wasn't just about the physical changes, either. It was about the emotional ones. I started feeling things more deeply, caring about things more intensely. I started realizing that life isn't just about avoiding pain, it's about embracing joy, even when it's mixed with sadness.

I still don't have all the answers. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm…more. More mature, more compassionate, more aware of the world around me.

It wasn't the way I planned to grow up, but it was the way I *needed* to grow up. And honestly? I think I'm a better person for it. Even if it's still kinda scary. And I still really like The Moldy Peaches. Some things never change.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner? It's...a situation. Let's just say I'm not exactly the stereotypical science whiz. Paulie Bleeker, he's the one who actually *gets* the periodic table and stuff. I'm more of a...facilitator.

I'm the one who keeps things from exploding, mostly. And I'm really good at reading instructions, which apparently a lot of people struggle with. I'm also the designated note-taker, because my handwriting is actually legible, unlike some people's scribbles.

I'm pretty good at asking the questions that everyone else is too afraid to ask, like, "Wait, are we *sure* this is safe?" or "What happens if we mix these two things?" It usually gets us a weird look from Mr. Belting, but it's better than accidentally creating a biohazard.

And I'm good at keeping things real. Like, if we're dissecting a frog, I'm the one who's like, "Okay, this is kinda gross," and acknowledges the obvious. Someone's gotta do it.

Basically, I'm the voice of reason. And the safety monitor. And the one who makes sure we don't fail. Paulie does the science-y stuff, and I make sure we don't blow up the lab. It's a good system. Mostly. It's a symbiotic relationship, really. He needs me to keep him grounded, and I need him to explain what a molecule is.

Ugh. Okay. That ad. Yeah. I saw it. It was…subtle. Like, trying to be all low-key and reassuring, but still kinda screaming "we handle…situations." You know?

It's weird seeing it in the paper, all official-looking. Like it's just another dentist or something. But it's not. It's…a place where people go when they're, like, really messed up and scared. And I've been there.

It's not a bad place, honestly. The people were nice enough. They didn't judge. Which is more than I can say for some people. But it's still…heavy. It's a reminder of everything.

The ad tries to make it sound easy, you know? Like, "We're here for you!" and "Confidential care!" But it's not easy. It's the hardest thing I've ever done. And no ad can really explain that.

It's good that places like that exist, I guess. For people who don't have anyone else to turn to. But it's also kinda sad that they *need* to exist. Like, why are people in this situation in the first place?

It just makes me feel…complicated. And kinda tired. I wish people would just…think things through before they, you know. But then again, life isn't really about thinking things through, is it? It's about dealing with the mess afterwards.

So, yeah. That ad. It's a thing. It exists. And it reminds me that I'm still figuring things out. And that's okay. I think.

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on the hamburger phone? It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine, I'll explain. But don't judge.

It wasn't a *choice*, exactly. It was…a statement. A rebellion. A way to say, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. And yeah, I'm kinda weird. Deal with it."

Paul, he's…enthusiastic. About everything. He found it at a flea market and thought it was hilarious. He thought it would be a "fun" way to talk to Mark. And honestly? It *was* kinda fun.

It was just…so ridiculous. So over-the-top. It felt like the perfect way to break the tension. Everything was so serious, you know? The pregnancy, the adoption, the whole situation. The hamburger phone was just…silly.

It was a way to show Mark that I wasn't going to let this whole thing completely define me. I was still me. A sarcastic, music-loving, slightly awkward teenager who sometimes makes questionable decisions.

And it got a reaction. Which, let's be real, I kinda wanted.

So yeah, I used a hamburger phone. It was dumb. It was impulsive. But it was also…me. And sometimes, you just gotta embrace the dumb. It's better than being boring.

Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always want to know this, like it's some big mystery. It wasn't. It was just…the right thing to do.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was a kid. And having a baby…that's a whole other level of responsibility. A level I wasn't ready for.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything I couldn't give it. A stable home, financial security, parents who were actually prepared to be parents. Mark, the dad…he was nice, but he was even *less* prepared than I was. He was gonna be a dad and still live with his parents and play guitar. No offense to guitar players, but that's not exactly a solid foundation.

Vanessa and Mark, they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give the baby a good life. A *better* life. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right decision. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about making a plan. A plan for a future where everyone could be happy.

People kept asking me if I regretted it. And I don't. I mean, it was sad. It still is sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. And I got to be a part of something beautiful, even if it wasn't in the way I expected.

It wasn't a fairytale ending, but it was *my* ending. And it was okay. It had to be.



It's complicated, okay? It's not something you can just explain in a soundbite. It was a lot of thinking, a lot of feeling, and a lot of hoping that I was doing the right thing. And I was. I really was.

Ugh, okay, so you want to get into the family stuff? It's…complicated. It's not like we were, like, the Waltons or something. We were…functional. Mostly.

My dad, he's a good guy. A little clueless sometimes, but he means well. He's always trying to fix things, even when they don't need fixing. And my stepmom, Bren, she's…intense. She's all about decorating and organic food and making everything perfect. Which is exhausting.

Honestly, watching them try to create this perfect little life, this perfect little house, it made me realize I didn't *want* that. I didn't want to be trapped in a life that wasn't mine. And I definitely didn't want to bring a baby into that kind of pressure cooker.

My mom…that's a whole other story. She left when I was little. She's…free-spirited. Which is a nice way of saying she's kinda flaky. She's always chasing her dreams, and I love her for it, but it also means she's not always around.

I realized I didn't want to repeat that pattern. I didn't want to bring a kid into the world and then not be able to give them the stability they deserved. I didn't want to be a mom who was always chasing something else.

So, yeah, my family definitely influenced my decision. Not in a bad way, exactly. It just…showed me what I *didn't* want. I wanted to give this baby a better life than I could provide right now. A life with two parents who were fully committed, a stable home, and a lot of love.

It wasn't about me not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby enough to make the hard choice. And seeing my family, both the good and the bad, helped me realize that was the right thing to do.

It's still hard to talk about, honestly. But it's the truth. My family, in their own weird way, helped me figure out what I wanted and what I didn't want. And that's a pretty big deal.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. People think it's all sunshine and rainbows and finding the perfect family, right? It's…not. It's complicated. And kinda emotionally draining.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…feeling like I wasn't in control. Like, my body was doing this thing, and then everyone else had opinions on what should happen next. And I was just trying to figure out what *I* wanted.

There was a lot of paperwork. Seriously, mountains of paperwork. It felt like I was filling out forms about my life for strangers. And then they were asking me really personal questions, like, "What are your parenting skills?" Hello? I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out how to do laundry.

And then there was the whole choosing-a-family thing. That was…weird. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes. These were people who were going to raise my kid. It was a huge responsibility. And I wanted to make the right choice, but I didn't even know what the "right" choice was.

There was this one couple, they seemed perfect on paper. They were really nice, they had a beautiful house, they wanted a baby so badly. But something just felt…off. I couldn't explain it. And then there was Mark and Vanessa. They weren't what I expected. They were kinda quirky and messy, but they just felt…real.

And then there was the guilt. A lot of guilt. Guilt about not being able to raise the baby myself. Guilt about giving my baby away. Guilt about choosing a family. It was exhausting.

And then there was Paul. He was really supportive, but he didn't *get* it. He couldn't understand what I was going through. It was my body, my decision, but I still needed someone to lean on.

It was a lot. It was messy. It was scary. But in the end, I made the best decision I could. And I found a family who I knew would love my baby and give them a good life. And that's all that really mattered.

It wasn't easy, though. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. And I wouldn't wish it on anyone. But I learned a lot about myself. And about what it means to be a mother. Even if I wasn't going to be the one raising the baby.

Ugh, okay, so you want the whole story, huh? It's not exactly a walk in the park, being pregnant at sixteen. And giving a baby up? That's…complicated. It messed me up, for a while. But it also, like, *made* me, you know?

Before all this, I was just…Juno. Sarcastic, movie-obsessed, kinda drifting. I didn't really have a plan. I was just trying to get through high school without being totally weird. And then BAM. Pregnant. It was a total wake-up call.

It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to think about things I hadn't even considered before. Responsibility, consequences, what I wanted for my future. It wasn't just about me anymore.

And honestly, it was terrifying. I was scared of everything. Scared of telling my parents, scared of what people would think, scared of being a mom. But I knew I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved.

Choosing Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But I knew they were amazing people, and they were so excited to be parents. And that made it a little bit easier.

But it wasn't just about them. It was about me, too. It forced me to figure out who I was, what I wanted, and what I was capable of. I realized I was stronger than I thought. I could handle tough situations. I could make difficult decisions.

It also made me realize that life isn't always what you expect. It throws you curveballs. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just…roll with it.

I think it helped me appreciate the good things in my life. My family, my friends, my freedom. And it taught me the importance of being true to yourself.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still just Juno. But I'm a Juno who's been through something big. And I think that's made me a better person. More mature, more compassionate, more…real.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It shaped me into the person I am today. And that's something I can live with.



It's kinda weird to talk about, honestly. But yeah. That's how it shaped me.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. Just thinking about it makes my stomach twist.

It was…awful. Like, I knew people were gonna have opinions, right? I figured there'd be some judgment. But that guy…he wasn't just judging. He was trying to make me feel *guilty*. Like I was actively hurting something.

And the fingers thing? Seriously? That was just…cruel. It wasn't about the baby, it was about trying to make *me* feel bad. Like I hadn't already thought about all of it. Like I hadn't already cried about it a million times.

I mean, I knew it was a baby. I knew it was growing. But it wasn't a person yet. Not in the way he was trying to make it seem. It was…potential. And I was trying to do what was best for everyone involved, including the potential baby.

He didn't know anything about my life, or Paul's, or the kind of home we could offer. He just saw a situation and decided to judge. It was so unfair.

I just wanted to tell him to mind his own business. But I didn't. I just…walked away. Because arguing with someone like that is pointless. They're not listening. They just want to feel superior.

It was one of the hardest parts of the whole thing, honestly. It made me question everything. But I knew, deep down, that I was making the right decision. Even if it was a really, really hard decision.

It just…sucked. It really, really sucked. And I still get angry thinking about it. It wasn't his place to say those things. It wasn't his place to make me feel worse.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't like a movie scene, you know? No dramatic music or slow-motion crying. It was just…awkward. And cold. The room was, like, beige and smelled faintly of disinfectant. And there was this poster about responsible decision-making that felt really judgmental.

I was trying to look nonchalant, like I was just filling out a form for a library card or something. But inside? I was a mess. My hands were shaking so bad I could barely hold the pen.

There were all these questions. Like, "Medical history?" and "Last menstrual period?" and "Are you sure?" Like they thought I hadn't thought this through. Like it was a whim. It wasn't a whim! It was…complicated.

I felt numb, mostly. And really, really small. Like I was shrinking into the chair. And guilty. Even though I knew I was doing the right thing, I felt guilty. Guilty for getting into this situation in the first place, guilty for not wanting to be a mom right now, guilty for…everything.

And scared. Terrified, actually. Scared of what everyone would think, scared of the future, scared of…well, everything.

I kept glancing at the other people in the waiting room. Trying to gauge their reactions, trying to see if they were judging me. But everyone was just staring straight ahead, trying to disappear.

It felt so…clinical. Like I wasn't a person, just a case number. And that made it even harder.

I just wanted to get it over with. To sign the papers and get out of there. To pretend it never happened. But I knew I couldn't. I had to face it. I had to make a decision. And I had to live with it.

It wasn't a good day. Not even close. But it was a necessary one. And I got through it. Somehow.

Ugh. Okay, so, pregnancy. Right. It started as…a problem. A really big, inconvenient problem. Like, a pop quiz you didn't study for, except the stakes are, like, a whole human life. Honestly, at first, it was just about getting rid of it. Finding someone who wanted it. It wasn't about *wanting* to be a mom, it was about doing the responsible thing. Or what I thought was the responsible thing.

I pictured motherhood as…suffocating. Losing yourself. Becoming one of those moms who only talks about their kids and wears sensible shoes. No offense to those moms, but that wasn't my vibe. I wanted to be cool. I wanted to listen to The Moldy Peaches and eat tater tots and not have to worry about diaper changes.

But then…things started to change. Feeling the baby kick, for one. That was weird. And kinda amazing. And talking to Vanessa and Mark, seeing how much they wanted it…it made me think. It made me realize it wasn't just about me anymore.

It wasn't about *having* a baby, it was about *giving* a baby a good life. A life with people who loved it and would take care of it. And Vanessa and Mark, they were those people. They were good people.

My perception of motherhood shifted from something scary and limiting to something…beautiful. Not for *me*, necessarily. But for the baby. It wasn't about losing myself, it was about helping someone else find themselves.

I realized motherhood isn't one thing. It's different for everyone. It doesn't have to be about sensible shoes and PTA meetings. It can be about love and support and giving a child the best possible start in life.

And honestly, seeing Vanessa and Mark become parents…it was the best outcome. It was the right thing to do. And it made me realize that even though I wasn't going to be a mom right now, I could still be a part of something amazing.

It was still scary, giving the baby up. But it was also…peaceful. Knowing that it was going to be loved and cared for. And that I had made a good decision. A really good decision.

So yeah, my perception of pregnancy and motherhood changed a lot. It went from a problem to a possibility to a beautiful, selfless act. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about what really matters in life.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all deep and introspective? Fine. It's not like I haven't had enough of that already.

Honestly, at the beginning of the movie, I didn't really *have* a strong sense of identity. I was just…Juno. The sarcastic girl who liked records and avoided drama. I was good at observing people, making witty comments, but I didn't really know who *I* was underneath all that. I used humor as a shield, you know? To keep people at arm's length.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person I was growing, and the future I was creating for them. And that forced me to actually think about who I wanted to be.

At first, I thought giving the baby up was just the practical thing to do. Like, I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I wanted the baby to have a good life. But as I got to know Mark and Vanessa, and as I started to feel the baby kick, it got a lot more complicated. I started to realize that giving the baby up wasn't just about doing what was best for the baby, it was also about me figuring out what *I* wanted.

I started to question everything. My relationship with Paul, my friendship with Leah, my future plans. I realized I was trying to be cool and detached, but underneath it all, I was just scared. Scared of growing up, scared of making the wrong decisions, scared of being alone.

By the end of the movie, I hadn't magically figured everything out. I still didn't have all the answers. But I had started to understand that it's okay to be vulnerable, it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have everything figured out. I learned that my identity wasn't something fixed, it was something I was constantly creating.

I wasn't just "Juno the pregnant teenager" anymore. I was Juno, the girl who was learning to navigate life, to love, and to grow up. And that was…okay. It was actually pretty good.

It was messy and complicated, but it was *me*. And that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. Okay, you want to know about *that* day? Seriously? It's not exactly a fun memory, okay? But fine. I'll tell you.

It wasn't, like, a sudden decision. It wasn't like I woke up that morning and was all, "Nope, changing my mind!" It was…a lot of things building up.

I'd been doing a lot of thinking, you know? About the baby, about Paul, about what I wanted. And I realized…I wasn't ready. Not really. Not for giving the baby up, and not for keeping it. It was too much. Too soon.

I mean, I'd made the decision to find a good home for it, and I still believed that was the right thing to do. But going to the clinic…it felt so…final. Like I was just erasing everything. Like I was just getting rid of a problem. And it wasn't a problem. It was a person.

And then there was Paul. He was being all supportive and stuff, which was nice, but it also made me feel guilty. He was ready to be a dad, and I was just…a mess.

So when I got to the clinic, I just…couldn't do it. I sat in the waiting room for, like, an hour, just staring at the magazines and trying not to freak out. And then I just…left.

I didn't tell anyone right away. I just went home and cried. It was a really confusing time.

It wasn't about changing my mind about the adoption. It was about needing more time. About needing to figure things out for myself. About needing to feel like I was making the right decision for *everyone* involved.

It was scary, okay? Really scary. But it was also…right. I needed to do things on my own terms. And that's what I did.



It's complicated. Life is complicated. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut, even if it doesn't make any sense.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know *that*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do, and probably ever *will* do.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have…more. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone how to raise a kid. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud.

My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a baby either. They were kinda checked out. And I didn't want to drag my mom into it, especially. She'd already been through a lot.

And then there was Paul and Vanessa. They were…ready. They were older, they had a house, they had a stable life. They *wanted* a baby. They could give the baby things I just couldn't. A good education, a safe home, a loving family.

It wasn't about me not being able to love the baby. It was about me knowing I wasn't the best person to *raise* the baby. It was about putting the baby's needs first.

It was selfish, maybe. But it was also the most unselfish thing I could do. I wanted the baby to have a good life, and I knew I couldn't give that to it.

It still sucks, though. It always will. But I try to think about it as…giving the baby a gift. A better life. And that makes it a little bit easier to live with.

It wasn't a decision I took lightly. It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to people. But in the end, I knew it was the right thing to do. For everyone.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That's…a low blow. It was a sensitive time, alright?

Look, it wasn't just *tacky*, it was…desperate. Like, I was already feeling weird enough about the whole situation, and my dad suggesting we find potential adoptive parents in a classifieds section? It felt…cheap. Like I was a used car or something.

It's not like I was expecting a fancy ad campaign or anything, but the Penny Saver is where you find people selling broken lawnmowers and offering dog-walking services. It's not exactly a place to find someone to raise a baby.

It just felt…undignified. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved. I wanted someone who genuinely *wanted* a child, not someone who was just browsing through a discount newspaper looking for a deal.

Plus, it was my dad's idea. And he means well, but sometimes his ideas are…questionable. He's a sweet guy, but he doesn't always get it.

It was just…a really weird moment. And it made me realize how complicated this whole thing was going to be. It wasn't just about finding someone to take the baby, it was about finding someone who would love and care for it like their own. And I didn't think the Penny Saver was the place to find that.

Okay? Can we please talk about something else now? This is bringing back some bad memories.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, honestly.

It wasn't, like, a planned thing. It started with me just…avoiding doing my homework. I was supposed to be writing a paper on, like, the symbolism of butterflies or something equally boring. And I was staring out the window, and I saw Mr. and Mrs. Pearl, my neighbors, flipping through the Penny Saver.

And I was just thinking, like, people put everything in that thing. Lost dogs, used furniture, weird services…and then it hit me. Adoption ads. People looking to *give* a baby a home.

I mentioned it to Leah, kinda casually, just as a "what if?" thing. We were both just…processing everything, you know? The whole pregnancy thing was a lot. And Leah, she's always been the practical one. She was the first one to actually start looking.

It wasn't about finding someone *right away*. It was about…seeing what was out there. Seeing what kind of people were looking to adopt. It was a way to start thinking about it, I guess. To make it feel a little less abstract.

It was also kinda morbidly fascinating, if I'm being honest. Reading these ads, seeing these people pouring their hearts out, hoping for a baby…it was a lot.

So yeah, that's how it started. Avoiding homework, a random observation, and a whole lot of complicated feelings. The Penny Saver. Who knew it would be the place where we started figuring out what to do with my life? It's kinda pathetic, when you think about it. But it was also…necessary.

Ugh, okay, this is…a big question. And it's not like I have a checklist or anything. It's not about finding the "perfect" family, because, let's be real, those don't exist. It's about finding the *right* family. For this kid.

I've been thinking about it a lot, obviously. And I've talked to a lot of people. And I've decided…I want someone who's…real.

Not, like, perfectly polished and put-together. I don't want someone who's gonna try to mold this baby into some kind of mini-adult. I want someone who's gonna let them be a kid. A weird, messy, wonderful kid.

I want a family who's okay with things not being perfect. Who can laugh at themselves. Who can handle a little bit of chaos. Because life is chaotic. And this kid deserves a family who can roll with the punches.

I want someone who's gonna read to them. And take them on adventures. And teach them to be kind. And to think for themselves.

I don't care if it's a mom and a dad, or two moms, or two dads, or a single parent. I just want someone who's gonna love this baby unconditionally. And who's gonna be there for them, no matter what.

I want someone who understands that this isn't a rescue mission. This isn't about "saving" a baby. It's about giving a baby a loving home.

And honestly? I want someone who's a little bit quirky. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves. Because this kid is gonna be quirky too. And they deserve a family who gets that.

It's a lot to ask, I know. But I want the best for this baby. And I'm gonna hold out until I find the right family. Even if it takes a while. Because this kid deserves nothing less.

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot. Like, a whole *situation*.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, at first I thought Mark was kinda sweet. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely trying. And Vanessa? She's…intense. Like, really intense. She's got a whole aesthetic going on, and it's very…Vanessa.

But the more I saw of them, the more I realized they're just…weirdly co-dependent. It's like they need each other to function, but not in a healthy way. They're both kinda lost, and they're clinging to each other for dear life.

And the whole "organic, free-range" baby thing? Seriously? It's a little much. Like, I get wanting a natural birth and all that, but they take it to a whole other level. It's like they're trying to raise a woodland creature, not a human being.

I feel bad for them, honestly. They're both clearly insecure and trying to find their place in the world. But they're going about it in a really…unconventional way.

I think they genuinely want to be good parents, but they're so caught up in their own ideas about what that means that they're missing the point. It's not about being perfect, it's about loving and supporting your kid.

So yeah, that's my take on Mark and Vanessa. They're…interesting. And a little bit terrifying. I just hope their baby doesn't end up wearing hemp clothing and eating only organic kale for the rest of its life. That would be a tragedy.

Ugh, okay, you want to bring up *that* yearbook message? Seriously? It's kinda embarrassing, even for me. But fine. You asked.

I wrote: "Bleeker, you're a genuinely good egg. Don't let anyone tell you different. And seriously, call me."

I know, it's not exactly Shakespeare. It's pretty straightforward. But that's kinda my style, right? I'm not one for flowery language or grand declarations of love. 

I wanted him to know that I thought he was a good person, and that I actually *wanted* him to contact me. It was a risk, 'cause I wasn't sure if he felt the same way. And I didn't want to come across as, like, desperate or anything.

It was a simple message, but it was honest. And it worked, I guess. He *did* call. Eventually.

Honestly, looking back on it, it's kinda sweet. And kinda awkward. But that's pretty much my whole life in a nutshell.

Don't judge me. I was a teenager. And I was dealing with a lot. A baby, for starters. It's hard to write a profound yearbook message when you're also trying to figure out your entire future.

Ugh. Okay, Mrs. Bleeker. That's…a whole thing. It's complicated.

She's…wary. That's the best way to put it. Like, she's constantly sizing me up, trying to figure out if I'm a good influence on Paulie. Which, honestly, is fair. I *am* kinda a mess. And I definitely don't fit into her perfectly planned suburban life.

She tries to be polite, you know? She'll offer me cookies and ask about school, but her eyes are always scanning me, looking for something to disapprove of. She definitely judged my music taste. And my vocabulary. And probably my general life choices.

I think she's mostly worried about me distracting Paulie from his future. He's supposed to be this perfect, pre-med, college-bound kid, and she's afraid I'll derail him. Which, okay, maybe I did a little bit. But he seemed pretty happy.

She's not *mean*, exactly. Just…disapproving. And a little bit condescending. She always talks to me like I'm a child.

Paulie says she's warming up to me, but I'm not so sure. I think she's just resigned to the fact that I'm a permanent fixture in his life.

Honestly, I try not to think about it too much. It's stressful. I just try to be myself and hope that eventually she'll see that I'm not as bad as she thinks I am.

But yeah. Mrs. Bleeker. She's…a character. And not in a good way.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially explosive cloud. It's not like I haven't been thinking about it, obviously. It's kinda hard *not* to think about when you're starting to show and craving pickles and ice cream at 3 AM.

I'm mostly just…anxious. My dad's gonna be all practical and start talking about college funds and responsibility. Which, okay, fair. But it's not exactly what I need to hear right now. And my mom… she's gonna cry. A lot. And then she's gonna want to know *everything*. Like, every single detail. Which is… mortifying.

I keep rehearsing what I'm gonna say in my head, but it always comes out sounding either too dramatic or too flippant. Like, "Hey guys, so, surprise! I'm having a baby! No big deal!" Which is definitely not the vibe I'm going for.

Paul's being really supportive, which is good. He's offered to be there when I tell them, which is… helpful. But also terrifying. It's my parents, you know? I have to be the one to do this.

I just want it to be over. I want them to be okay with it. I want them to understand that I'm scared, but I'm also… kinda excited? It's complicated.

I'm trying to remind myself that they love me, and they'll eventually come around. But right now, it just feels like a really big, scary thing. I think I need to eat a whole bag of chips. And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. It's the only thing that calms me down.

Seriously. Don't even talk to me about it right now. I need to mentally prepare. It's gonna be a disaster. A beautiful, terrifying disaster.

Ugh, okay, you want to psychoanalyze me? Fine. It's not like I haven't done enough of that myself.

It's…complicated. My parents are good people, really. They just…they're not exactly equipped to deal with, like, *real* life. They're super into Brené Brown and attachment parenting and all that stuff, which is fine, I guess. But it also means they kinda freak out about anything that doesn't fit into their perfect little world.

If I told them I was pregnant, it wouldn't be a "let's figure this out" situation. It would be a full-blown emotional crisis. Lots of tears, lots of talking about feelings, and probably a lot of guilt trips. They'd be all, "What did we do wrong?" and "How could this happen?" It's exhausting just thinking about it.

They're also kinda…fragile. They're not used to dealing with difficult situations. They're more comfortable with, like, organic gardening and listening to NPR. So I don't want to burden them with something so big and scary. I don't want to disappoint them.

And honestly, I kinda want to figure this out on my own. I want to prove to myself that I can handle it. I don't want to be seen as helpless or incapable. I want to be…independent.

It's not that I don't love them. I do. It's just that they're not always the most…practical people to turn to. They mean well, but sometimes their "support" feels more like judgment.

So yeah, that's why I'm hesitant. It's a combination of wanting to protect them, wanting to protect myself, and wanting to prove that I can handle things on my own. It's a mess, I know. But that's my life, in a nutshell. A beautiful, messy, complicated mess.

Okay, look. This isn't, like, a super easy thing to talk about, alright? It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, yeah, giving my baby away, totally chill." It's way more complicated than that.

But here's the thing. I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I'm not ready. I don't have a job, I'm still in high school, and honestly, my life is kinda chaotic as it is.

And it's not about not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have the *best* life possible. A life I can't give it right now. I want it to have parents who are stable, who have a house and a plan and, you know, actual adult stuff figured out.

Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they're so excited. They're ready. They can give the baby everything I can't. A good home, a good education, a loving family.

It's not about me giving up something. It's about me *choosing* something. Choosing to give this baby the best possible start in life. It's a selfless thing, I guess. And it's really, really hard.

I know people think it's sad, or weird, or whatever. But it's not. It's responsible. It's mature. And it's the right thing to do. For the baby.

I'll always be the baby's birth mother. That's something no one can take away from me. And I get to be a part of its life, if they want me to be. But I also get to live my own life. Finish school, go to college, figure out what I want to do with myself.

It's not a perfect solution. But it's the best one. And sometimes, the best option isn't the easiest one. It just…is.



It's complicated, okay? Don't judge me. Just try to understand.

Ugh, okay, this is…the big one. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person's* life we're talking about. My kid's life. So, yeah, I've thought about this. A lot.

It's not about perfect people. Nobody's perfect. It's about…right. It has to *feel* right.

First off, they gotta be stable. Like, financially stable, emotionally stable. I don't want my kid growing up worrying about where their next meal is coming from, or dealing with a bunch of drama. A solid foundation is key.

They also gotta be open-minded. Like, *really* open-minded. This isn't gonna be a cookie-cutter family. My kid's gonna have a story, and they need to be okay with that. They need to be able to answer questions honestly and without flinching.

And they have to be fun. Seriously. I want my kid to have a life filled with laughter and adventure. I don't want them to be raised by a bunch of stuffy old people who don't know how to let loose.

They need to be patient. Raising a kid is hard work. It's gonna be messy and frustrating and exhausting. They need to be able to handle that.

And, honestly, they need to be a little bit weird. I mean, I'm pretty weird, and I want my kid to be able to embrace their own weirdness. I don't want them to feel like they have to fit into a mold.

It's not about finding a replacement family. It's about finding a family that will love and support my kid unconditionally. A family that will give them the best possible life.

It's a lot to ask, I know. But my kid deserves the best. And I'm gonna make sure they get it. Even if it means being super picky.

It's not about me, though. It's about them. And that's what matters.

Ugh. Okay. This is…the hard part. The part I’ve been trying not to think about, honestly. It’s not like I can just pretend it’s not happening, even though part of me really wants to.

I guess…I’m trying to be practical about it. Like, I’m making lists. Not of baby names, because that just makes things worse. Lists of things I need to do, things I need to accept.

I’m talking to a counselor, which is…weird. But she’s okay. She doesn’t judge. She just listens when I ramble about how this isn’t how I pictured my life going. Which, duh.

I’m also trying to focus on the good parts. Like, I’m giving this baby a life I can’t give it. A stable home, two parents who are ready for it, a future. That’s…something. It doesn’t make it easy, but it makes it feel…less selfish, I guess.

I’m letting myself feel sad. Like, really sad. I’m allowing myself to cry and be angry and be scared. Because pretending I’m okay when I’m not is just gonna make things worse in the long run.

And I’m leaning on Paul and Renee. They’re…surprisingly good at this whole supportive friend thing. They don’t try to fix it, they just…are there. Which is exactly what I need.

I think…I think it’s gonna be a long process. It’s not like I’m gonna wake up one day and be totally fine. There’s gonna be good days and bad days. And probably a lot of days in between.

But I’m trying to remember that this isn’t about giving something *up*. It’s about making a really hard choice for the best possible outcome. And that takes courage. Even if I don’t feel very courageous right now.

It’s gonna suck. But I’m gonna get through it. I have to. And maybe, someday, I’ll even be okay with it. Maybe. Don’t quote me on that.

Ugh, okay, you wanna know about "deliver"? Seriously? It's just...a word. But it feels *wrong*, you know? Like, I'm not a pizza. Or a package. Or a tiny, fragile piece of furniture that needs assembling.

It's just...I'm carrying a baby. A person. A little human being. And calling it "delivering" makes it sound like I'm ordering something from Amazon. "One baby, please. Prime shipping."

It's dehumanizing, I guess. Like, it reduces the whole thing to a transaction. And it's not a transaction. It's...complicated. It's emotional. It's a really big decision.

And it's not like I'm *giving* it away, exactly. I'm choosing a family for it. A family who can give it a good life. It's a loving thing, not a delivery.

Plus, it just sounds weird. "I'm going to deliver the baby." It sounds like I'm a stork or something.

So yeah, I find the term "deliver" weird. It just doesn't sit right with me. It feels...cold. And this isn't a cold situation. It's a really warm, messy, complicated situation. And it deserves a better word than "deliver."

It's just...ugh. Don't call it a delivery. Okay? Just don't.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the whole dad-at-the-adoption-meeting thing? That was…a choice. A bad choice. But a necessary one, I guess.

Look, my dad, bless his heart, is…enthusiastic. Like, aggressively enthusiastic. And he's got this whole "protective daughter" thing going on, even though I'm perfectly capable of protecting myself, thank you very much.

I didn't *want* him there. I specifically told him not to come. But he just…showed up. Said he wanted to "be supportive." Which, translated from Dad-speak, means he wanted to make sure I wasn't getting taken advantage of. Or that I wasn't, like, giving the baby away to a family of axe murderers.

Honestly, I figured it was easier to let him come than to have a full-blown argument with him in the parking lot of the adoption agency. He gets really loud. And dramatic. And I just wanted to get it over with.

Plus, a tiny part of me thought maybe having him there would make me look more…responsible? Like, "See? I have a responsible adult in my life!" Which is ridiculous, I know. But I was a mess of hormones and anxiety at the time.

It was a disaster, obviously. He kept asking inappropriate questions and trying to bond with Mark and Vanessa like they were potential in-laws. It was mortifying.

But, looking back, I guess it also showed me how much he loved me. Even if his way of showing it was completely embarrassing. He just wanted what was best for me, even if he didn't understand what that was.

So yeah, I let him come. It was a mistake. But it was *my* mistake. And sometimes, you just gotta roll with the punches. Especially when your dad is involved.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda sucks. Like, everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They know what they want to be when they grow up, what kind of music they like, who they're gonna marry. And me? I'm just…Juno. A girl who likes records and tater tots and making sarcastic comments.

It's not that I *want* to be labeled, you know? I don't want to be put in a box. But it's also kinda unsettling to feel like I'm just…floating. Like I don't have a solid identity.

I mean, I used to think I was just a normal teenager. A little quirky, maybe. But then I got pregnant, and suddenly everything changed. And now I'm trying to figure out who I am *after* that. Who I am *without* being a pregnant girl.

It's like, I'm shedding a skin, but I don't know what's underneath. And it's kinda scary.

Paul helped with that, a little. He didn't try to define me or tell me who I should be. He just…accepted me for who I was, even when I didn't know who that was.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be a work in progress. It's okay to be a little bit lost.

Maybe that's just part of growing up. Maybe we're all just figuring it out as we go along. And maybe, just maybe, that's okay.

It's just…sometimes I wish I had a little more clarity. A little more direction. But then again, maybe the fun is in the uncertainty.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And honestly? I'm kinda okay with that. For now.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that. It was…a moment. A really awkward, uncomfortable moment. Like, the kind where you just want to disappear into the floor.

So, my dad and Mark are having one of their "manly" talks, which basically means passive-aggressive silences and pointed stares. And it's clearly getting tense. And Bren, being Bren, decides the best solution is to just…shoo us upstairs? Like we're a pair of annoying puppies?

My first reaction was just…eye-rolling. Seriously. Like, thanks, Bren. That's *super* helpful. It's not like Leah and I are capable of having a conversation or anything. We're just teenage girls who need to be sequestered to avoid upsetting the delicate male ego.

I think I said something sarcastic, probably along the lines of, "Oh, good idea, Bren. Let's just retreat to our rooms and pretend everything's fine." I'm pretty sure Leah just gave her a look. A really withering look.

It wasn't about wanting to avoid the tension, it was about wanting to be treated like actual people. Like we weren't just…obstacles in their little drama. 

It just felt dismissive, you know? Like Bren didn't even *see* us. And it made the whole situation even more awkward. It was like she was saying, "You girls wouldn't understand." And maybe we wouldn't have understood the specifics of their adult problems, but we definitely understood that something was wrong.

Honestly, it was just another reminder that my family is…complicated. And that sometimes, adults are just really bad at dealing with their feelings. It's a whole thing.

Ugh, okay, that's…a lot to unpack. An open adoption. It's not something I really thought about at first, honestly. It felt kinda…complicated. Like, too much.

But the more I think about it, and the more I talk to Mark and Vanessa, the more I think it might be…okay. Actually, maybe even good.

It's not like I want to be a part of their lives every single day, you know? I don't want to be, like, the cool aunt who shows up unannounced. That would be weird for everyone. And for the baby, especially.

But the idea of knowing he's okay? Of getting to see pictures of him growing up? That's…comforting. It doesn't make it easier to give him up, not at all. But it makes it feel less…final. Like, I'm not just disappearing from his life completely.

It's scary, though. What if I get too attached to the pictures? What if I start second-guessing my decision? What if it makes things harder for everyone involved?

Vanessa seems really good about it. She says she wants me to know he's loved and happy. And Mark…well, Mark's just a good guy. He seems like he'd be a good dad.

I guess what I'm saying is, I'm still figuring it out. It's not something I'm totally comfortable with yet. But I'm willing to try. Because if it means knowing he's okay, then maybe it's worth the risk.

It's just…it's a lot. It's a lot to process. And it's a lot to ask of everyone involved. But I think, maybe, it could be a good thing. A really good thing. If we can all make it work.



It's just…it's not how I pictured things, you know? But then again, a lot of things haven't gone according to plan lately.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…a lot. It wasn't like a sudden punch in the gut, it was more like someone slowly turned the volume up on all my anxieties until my head was buzzing.

I mean, I knew it was an open adoption, right? I knew I'd get to see the baby and know where she was. But I hadn't really thought about the *legal* stuff. I was too busy trying to figure out if I could even handle being pregnant in the first place.

When Gerta said that, about my rights being terminated…it just hit me. Like, this wasn't just about giving a baby a good home. This was about giving up a part of myself. Forever. 

It wasn't that I didn't want the baby to have a good life with Mark and Vanessa. I did. They were amazing. But it was the finality of it. The knowing that I wouldn't legally be her mom. That I wouldn't have a say in her future.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Make a joke. "So, like, I'm just a glorified egg donor?" But inside, I was totally freaking out. It felt like…losing something before I even had it.

It made me realize how much I was already attached to the baby, even though I hadn't even met her yet. And it made me realize how hard this whole thing was going to be.

It was a really scary moment. And it made me question everything. But ultimately, it also made me realize that I was doing the right thing. Even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

It just…sucked. Plain and simple. It really, really sucked.

Ugh. Vanessa. Okay, look, she's a good person, really. But the whole baby thing? It's…intense. Like, she's been planning this for *years*. It's kinda scary how planned it is, you know?

It's not that I don't think she'd be a good mom. She totally would. She's patient and kind and she's got a whole nursery decorated before she even *met* Mark. It's just…it feels like she's trying to fill a hole with a baby. And that's not fair to anyone. Especially not the baby.

I mean, I get wanting a family. But I didn't exactly *plan* on getting pregnant. It just…happened. And it was messy and complicated and not at all what I expected. And Vanessa's version of motherhood feels so…perfect. And nothing is perfect.
