I guess I just worry that she's putting too much pressure on herself. And on Mark. And on the baby. It's like she thinks having a kid is going to magically fix everything. And it won't. Life is still gonna be life, even with a tiny human attached to your hip.

I just want her to be happy. And I want her to be realistic. And I want her to know that it's okay if things don't go according to plan. Because they never do.

It's her life, though. And she's gotta do what she thinks is right. I just hope she's really thought it through. And that she's prepared for the chaos. Because babies are chaos. Glorious, messy, exhausting chaos.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on Mark and the whole dad thing? Honestly? It's...complicated.

When people ask him about being a dad, he always does that thing where he tries to be all cool and nonchalant, right? Like, "Oh, it's no big deal. I'll just, you know, be a friend." And it's kinda sweet, in a clueless sort of way.

But it also makes me wanna roll my eyes so hard they get stuck. Like, dude, this isn't about being a buddy. It's about being a *dad*. It's about responsibility and showing up and actually being there for the kid.

I get that he's scared. He's, like, seventeen. He's not exactly equipped to raise a human being. But pretending it's not a big deal doesn't make it any less real.

It's like he's trying to avoid the whole emotional part of it. And that's...understandable, I guess. He's not exactly the most emotionally available person. But a kid needs more than just someone to play video games with.

I think deep down, he *wants* to be a good dad. He just doesn't know how. And he's afraid of messing it up. Which, honestly, is a pretty normal fear.

But he needs to step up. He needs to actually think about what being a dad means and start preparing for it. Because this isn't just about him anymore. It's about a little person who's gonna need him.

So yeah, his response is...a work in progress. He's got a lot to learn. And I hope he's willing to learn. Because this kid deserves a good dad. Even if that dad is a little bit clueless.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about the Loring's house? Seriously? It's…weird. It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just…intense. And their house is like a museum of awkward.

It's not one specific thing, it's just…the vibe. Everything is perfectly placed, like you're not allowed to *breathe* too hard in case you knock something over. And they're always watching. Not in a creepy way, exactly, but like they're observing you for a science experiment.

And the conversations! They always try to have these deep, meaningful talks, and I'm just sitting there trying to figure out how to politely excuse myself. It's exhausting. They want to analyze everything, and I just want to watch a movie and eat some cheese puffs.

Plus, they're really into antiques. Like, *really* into antiques. And I'm terrified I'm going to break something valuable and then they'll dissect my emotional response to it.

It's just…suffocating. I feel like I have to be a perfect version of myself when I'm there, and I'm not a perfect person. I'm messy and sarcastic and I say things I don't mean. And I feel like they're judging me for it.

So yeah, being left unsupervised in their house is terrifying. It's like being trapped in a really fancy, really quiet, really judgmental dollhouse. I just want to escape. It's a lot.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not something I think about all the time, you know? Like, I'm not constantly having some emotional breakdown about it. But it definitely crosses my mind.

It's weird, right? I made a decision, and that decision is gonna change their lives forever. And it's gonna change *my* life, too, obviously. It's not like handing someone a sweater. It's a whole person.

At first, it was mostly just…relief. Relief that I didn't have to, like, raise a kid right now. I'm seventeen! I have no idea what I'm doing with my own life, let alone another one.

But then, as I got to know Mark and Vanessa, it started to feel…different. They're good people. Really good people. They're excited. They're prepared. They're gonna give this kid a life I just couldn't.

So, yeah, I feel good about it. I really do. It's not sad, exactly. It's more like…a shift. Like, I'm giving them something amazing, and they're gonna cherish it. And that's a good feeling.

It's still kinda scary, though. It's a big responsibility, even just making the decision to give the baby up. And I know I'm gonna have moments where I wonder what my life would have been like if I'd kept it.

But I think…I think I'm doing the right thing. For everyone. And that's gotta count for something, right?

It's not a simple feeling. It's complicated. But mostly, I just hope they're happy. And that the baby is happy. And that they name him after a really obscure 80s band. That would be cool.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the "ASAP" thing? Seriously? That was, like, months ago. But fine, I'll explain. It's not just about the "ASAP," okay? It's about the *way* he said it.

It was just…so earnest. So *trying*. Like, he was trying to be all cool and efficient and adult, and it just came off as…dorky. He was all, "I need that information ASAP!" and it was just so…Mark.

It's not that I don't appreciate efficiency. It's just that he was trying so hard to impress me, and it was kinda transparent. And honestly, it was a little bit endearing. But I had to say *something*. I can't let people get away with that kind of earnestness. It's a slippery slope.

Plus, it's a good word to make fun of. It just is. It sounds ridiculous when you say it out loud. "A-S-A-P." Like a robot.

I mean, I'm a sarcastic person. It's how I cope. And Mark is just…a very easy target. Not that I don't like him. I do. He's a good guy. He's just…a little bit clueless sometimes.

And honestly, it was a way to deflect. I was feeling all weird and confused about everything, and making fun of his "ASAP" was easier than dealing with my own feelings.

So yeah, that's why I mocked him. It was a combination of sarcasm, defensiveness, and a general inability to resist a good opportunity for a witty remark. Don't judge me.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about guitars? Honestly, I'm not a guitar *player*. Paul's the one with the calloused fingertips and the obsession with amps. But I've been around enough guitars to have opinions.

My preferred brand? It's gotta be **Fender**. Specifically, a vintage Telecaster.

Don't get me wrong, Gibsons are cool and all, but they're kinda…showy. Like, they're trying too hard. A Telecaster is just…solid. It's reliable. It's unpretentious. It's the kind of guitar that doesn't need to prove anything.

Plus, they sound amazing. Bright and twangy, but also kinda gritty. It's a versatile sound. You can play anything on a Telecaster, from country to rock to indie.

Paul has a few, and they just feel…right. They're like an extension of him. And honestly, watching him play is kinda mesmerizing. It's the only time I don't roll my eyes when he's being all artistic.

It's not about the brand, really. It's about the sound. And the Telecaster just has a sound that speaks to me. It's honest and raw and a little bit rebellious. Which, you know, I can relate to.

So yeah. Fender Telecaster. Don't judge me. I'm just a girl with an opinion. And a baby on the way. And a lot of complicated feelings. But mostly, I just like the way a Telecaster sounds.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A desperate attempt to impress Paul. Don't judge.

Look, Paul was…cool. Like, *really* cool. And he was into music, specifically bands I didn't really know anything about. And he mentioned the Melvins, and I just…panicked. My brain short-circuited. I blurted out that I was a huge fan. It just *happened*.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I thought if I pretended to be into the same stuff as him, he'd like me more. It was a classic teenage move. Pathetic, I know.

I figured, what's the worst that could happen? He'd ask me about their albums, and I'd just…wing it. Which, obviously, didn't go well. He started quizzing me on their discography, and I was totally lost. It was mortifying.

I just wanted him to think I was interesting and cool and…you know. And I thought pretending to be a Melvins aficionado was the way to do it. It backfired spectacularly.

It was a dumb lie. I admit it. But it was a lie born out of…teenage awkwardness and a desperate desire for connection. And honestly, it kinda worked, in a weird way. It led to a conversation, and eventually, to something more.

So yeah, I lied about knowing the Melvins. Don't be too hard on me. Everyone does stupid things when they're trying to impress someone they like. It's just…sometimes those stupid things are really, really embarrassing.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so describing it is…complicated. It wasn’t like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing, you know? It wasn’t all sparkly and dramatic. It was…comfortable. Weirdly comfortable.

When we were playing guitar and singing, it was like…the world kinda faded out. All the stuff with the baby, with my parents, with school…it all just got quieter. It was just us and the music. And it wasn’t about showing off or trying to impress each other. It was just…doing something we both liked.

He wasn’t trying to be all profound or poetic or anything. He just…got it. He understood the songs I liked, the way I felt. And he wasn’t afraid to be a little dorky, which was good, because I’m pretty dorky myself.

It was like we were speaking the same language, but without actually saying anything. It was a connection through the music. A way to just…be.

I guess you could say it was a friendship. But it was more than that, too. It was a…safe space. A place where I could be myself, without having to pretend or explain anything.

It wasn’t a love connection, not in the traditional sense. It was just…a really good connection. And honestly, sometimes that’s enough. Sometimes, that’s even better.

It was just…nice. Yeah. It was just really, really nice. And I miss it, sometimes. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's a perfectly reasonable name for a guitar, okay? Don't judge.

Well, it started with my dad. He was really into Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Like, *really* into him. He had all these books about him, and he'd always be talking about the New Deal and stuff. It was kinda nerdy, honestly. But he was passionate about it.

And then, when I got the guitar – it was a hand-me-down from Mark, remember? – it just felt…sturdy. Solid. Like a president should be. And it had this kind of quiet dignity, you know? It wasn't flashy or anything. It was just…reliable.

So, I was sitting there, trying to come up with a name, and I just blurted out "Roosevelt." And it stuck. It felt right. It felt like a tribute to my dad, and to the idea of someone who tries to make things better, even when it's hard.

Plus, it's kinda funny. A guitar named after a president. It's ironic. I like irony.

So yeah, that's the story of Roosevelt. It's not a deep, philosophical reason. It just…happened. And honestly, I don't really care if people think it's weird. It's my guitar, and I like the name. Deal with it.

Ugh, okay, so the whole keeping Vanessa and Mark in the loop thing? It's…complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the dark, you know? They're my best friends. But it's also my pregnancy, and my decision. And it feels kinda weird to have to constantly report back to them like I'm some kinda project.

Vanessa's good. She's supportive, mostly. A little overbearing sometimes, with the whole "are you eating enough fiber?" routine. But she means well. She's just…Vanessa. She worries. A lot.

Mark's…Mark. He's trying. He's just not really equipped to deal with, like, *feelings*. He keeps trying to fix things, which is sweet, but also kinda annoying. Like, I don't need a solution, Mark, I just need someone to listen.

I guess I feel like they think they have a right to know everything, because they've been there for me. And they have! They're amazing. But it's still *my* life. And I need to figure this out on my own, at least a little bit.

It's just…it feels like they're treating me like I'm fragile. Like I'm gonna fall apart if I don't have their constant support. And I'm not. I'm stronger than they think.

I want them to be involved, but I also want them to respect my boundaries. I want them to trust that I'm making the right decisions for myself and the baby.

It's a delicate balance, you know? And honestly, I'm still figuring it out. It's just…ugh. Teen pregnancy is weird. And having to navigate friendships on top of it? Even weirder.



I just wish they'd chill out a little bit. And maybe stop offering me advice about prenatal vitamins. I got this. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me this, right? Like, they think I haven't thought it through, or that I'm just being…flippant about it. Which is rude.

Look, it's not like I woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, sure, I'll just give away my baby." It's been a lot of thinking. A *lot*. And a lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa. And honestly? It's the only thing that feels right.

It's not about not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have everything. And I can't give that to it. Not right now. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a kid. I'm barely responsible enough to keep my fish alive, okay?

Vanessa and Paul…they're ready. They've been trying for years. They have a beautiful house, a stable life, and a ton of love to give. They're gonna be amazing parents. And that's what matters.

It's not easy. It's gonna be hard. I'm gonna miss the baby, obviously. But knowing that it's gonna be loved and cared for, that it's gonna have a good life…that makes it worth it.

And honestly? I need to live my own life. I need to go to college, figure out what I want to do, and become a person. I can't do that if I'm changing diapers and dealing with sleepless nights.

So yeah, I'm 104% sure. It's not a perfect solution, but it's the best one. For everyone. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is admit that you can't do something yourself and let someone else step in. It doesn't make you a bad person. It makes you a responsible one.

It's just…the right thing to do. And I can live with that. Even if it sucks sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't like, *happy* happy, you know? It was more…relieved happy. Like they could finally breathe again. And honestly? A little bit awkward for me.

I mean, I get it. I was a walking, talking reminder of a really intense situation. A situation they hadn't exactly planned for. So, seeing them all…festive and decorating and suddenly super into baby stuff after I handed over the paperwork? It felt…weird.

It wasn't that I didn't *want* them to be happy. I did. I really did. I wanted them to be the best parents ever. But it felt like they were celebrating *my* leaving, not necessarily the baby. Which, I guess, is kinda the same thing, but still.

It was like they were finally allowed to be a "normal" family. And I was…not part of that normal. Which, again, I knew going in. But seeing it actually happen? It stung a little.

I tried to just…disappear. Just be quiet and let them have their moment. I didn't want to ruin it. I didn't want to make them feel guilty. I just wanted to get out of there.

It wasn't a bad feeling, exactly. It was more…bittersweet. Like, I was happy for them, but also sad for myself. It was a reminder that my life was going in a different direction. And that was okay. It just…felt weird to watch them celebrate while I was trying not to cry.

So yeah. Awkward. Relieved for them, awkward for me. That pretty much sums it up.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I'm some kind of zoo animal or something? It's… irritating. And honestly, a little invasive.

Look, it's my life, okay? And it's complicated enough without everyone else sticking their noses in. I get that people are curious. Small towns, you know? Everyone knows everyone's business. But it's not like I'm trying to hide anything. I'm just… figuring things out.

And the rumors? They're mostly wrong. Like, *way* wrong. People are making up stories about who the father is, and what I'm going to do with the baby, and whether I'm even happy about it. It's exhausting.

I'm not gonna stand up here and give you all the details of my personal life. That's not my style. But I will say this: I'm making a decision that's right for me. And for the baby. And that's all that matters.

I'm not asking for pity or anything. I'm just asking for a little bit of respect. And maybe for people to stop spreading rumors. It's not helpful. It's just… annoying.

Honestly, I just want to finish school, listen to The Moldy Peaches, and not have to deal with this drama. Is that too much to ask?

So yeah. The rumors? They're just rumors. And I'm trying to ignore them. It's not easy, but I'm working on it. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a life to live. And a baby to think about.

Ugh. Okay. You want the real deal, huh? Not the cute, sarcastic stuff? Fine.

It's…complicated. Like, massively, overwhelmingly complicated. It's not something you just *decide* to do, you know? It's not like picking a flavor of ice cream.

Part of me is, like, totally terrified. Giving up a baby? That's…a big deal. It feels wrong, even though I know it's the right thing. It's like giving away a piece of myself. And I haven't even *met* the little dude yet.

And then there's the guilt. A lot of guilt. Like, am I a bad person for not wanting to raise him? Am I selfish? But then I think about what kind of life I can give him right now. And it's not a good one. I'm still in high school. I'm not ready. I don't have a stable job or a house or…anything.

But the thing that makes it okay, I guess, is knowing that Mark and Vanessa are amazing. They *want* this baby. They're ready. They can give him a life I just can't. And that's what matters. It's not about what *I* want, it's about what's best for him.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's gonna hurt. A lot. I'm gonna miss him. I'm gonna wonder what his life is like. But I know that I'm doing this because I love him. And that's gotta count for something, right?

It's just…it's a really hard decision. And I'm still processing it. I'm trying to be brave, but honestly? I'm mostly just scared. And hoping I'm doing the right thing.



It's not a happy thing, but it's a responsible thing. And sometimes, responsible is all you can be.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know why I pushed for Mark and Vanessa to be surprised about the baby's sex? It's…complicated. It's not like I had some grand philosophical reason or anything.

Honestly? It was mostly about them. They're…a lot. Like, super prepared, super organized, super *everything*. They had a nursery planned before I even told them I was pregnant. Pink or blue, they had a theme picked out. It was kinda intense.

And I just thought…maybe they deserve a little bit of mystery. A little bit of surprise. They've planned everything else, why not let this one thing just *happen*?

It felt like, if they knew, they'd start planning the whole life for this kid before the kid was even born. And I wanted them to just…be in the moment. To experience the joy of finding out, you know?

Plus, it was kinda funny to me. They're so serious, and the idea of them being genuinely surprised just seemed…nice. A little bit of chaos in their perfectly planned world.

It wasn't about me, really. It was about giving them something they didn't expect. Something a little bit…real. And honestly, it was kinda fun to watch them freak out a little bit. Don't tell them I said that.

It's just…they're good people, and they're gonna be good parents. But sometimes, good people need to loosen up a little. And a surprise baby gender reveal seemed like a good way to do that.

Ugh. Seriously? That lady. I swear, some people just…assume. Like they’ve got all the answers because they point a wand at your stomach for ten minutes.

It was…infuriating. And embarrassing. And kinda sad, all at the same time. She was all, “Oh, so you’re not planning on keeping it?” and “You’re so young, you probably haven’t thought this through.” Like, excuse me? I’ve thought about this more than you’ve probably thought about your own life.

It wasn’t about not *wanting* the baby. It was about knowing I wasn’t ready. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human life. And she just…didn’t get that. She just saw the stereotype. Teenage mom, giving up the baby, tragic story.

It made me feel like I had to justify my decision to a complete stranger. Like I had to prove I was a good person, that I was doing the right thing, even though it was already the hardest thing I’d ever done.

And it stung, you know? Because I *was* scared. I *was* unsure. And her assumptions just made me feel even more vulnerable. Like she was confirming all my worst fears about what people would think.

I just wanted her to do her job and show me the little bean on the screen. I didn’t need a lecture on responsible parenting.

It made me even more determined to make the best decision for the baby, and for myself. And it made me realize that people are gonna judge you no matter what you do. You just gotta tune them out and do what feels right.

It was a really crappy moment. Honestly. And I still get annoyed thinking about it. Some people just don’t get it.

Ugh, okay, so you want the whole story, huh? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It wasn't like in the movies, all cute and heartwarming all the time. There were a lot of…things.

First off, telling my parents. That was…rough. My dad was surprisingly cool, actually. He just kinda blinked and then offered to help me build a crib. My mom? Not so much. Lots of crying, lots of "what will people think?" It was awkward. Really awkward.

Then there was school. Trying to navigate high school while also, you know, *growing a human*? It was a lot. People whispering, staring, making assumptions. It was exhausting. And trying to keep up with my classes while dealing with morning sickness? Forget about it.

And then there was Paul. He was…sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle the situation. He wanted to be involved, but he was also kinda clueless. It took a while for us to figure things out. It wasn't a romantic comedy, okay? It was messy and complicated.

But the biggest challenge, honestly, was deciding on adoption. It wasn't an easy decision. It felt like giving up a part of myself. But I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was still a kid myself. And I wanted my baby to have a life I couldn't give them.

Finding the right couple was…intense. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes. It was a human being. I wanted them to be amazing, to give my baby everything I couldn't. Mark and Vanessa were…good. They were real. And that made it easier.

But even after I made the decision, there was still guilt. And sadness. And a lot of second-guessing. It was a rollercoaster of emotions.

It wasn't about being selfless, you know? It was about being honest with myself. About knowing what I could and couldn't handle. And about wanting the best for my baby, even if that meant letting them go.

It was hard. Really hard. But it was also…right. And I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It taught me a lot about myself, about life, and about what really matters. It made me grow up, whether I wanted to or not.



So yeah, that's a little glimpse into the chaos. It wasn't pretty, but it was real. And that's what counts.

Ugh. Okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge. It's not like I *wanted* to have a philosophical moment, but…yeah. This whole thing, being pregnant and deciding to give the baby up…it kinda rearranges your brain.

Love…before all this, I thought love was, like, in movies. Dramatic declarations and grand gestures. Turns out, it's a lot more complicated. It's about wanting what's best for someone, even if that means letting them go. It's about Mark and Vanessa being good parents, even if it's not *with* me. It's about my dad being there for me, even when I'm being a total mess. It's not always fireworks and romance. Sometimes it's just…quiet support. And that's okay. Maybe even better.

Responsibility…that was a big one. I used to think responsibility was about doing your homework and not getting grounded. Turns out, it's about making really hard choices, even when they hurt. It's about thinking about someone else's future, not just your own. It's about being a grown-up, even when you don't feel like one. It's terrifying, honestly. But also…empowering. Knowing I could make that decision, and stick to it, even when it was the hardest thing I've ever done…that's something.

And growing up…well, that's still happening, obviously. But it's not about getting older, it's about figuring out who you are. Before this, I was just trying to blend in, you know? Be cool, be sarcastic, avoid anything remotely emotional. Now…I don't know. I'm still sarcastic, don't get me wrong. But I'm also…more honest with myself. I'm okay with being vulnerable. I'm okay with not having all the answers. I'm okay with being a little bit messy.

It's like, I used to think growing up meant becoming a perfect adult. Now I realize it's about becoming a *real* one. Flaws and all. And that's…a relief, actually.

It's still weird, though. I'm still trying to figure it all out. But I think…I think I'm okay. And maybe, just maybe, I'm even a little bit stronger than I thought I was.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about the abandoned living room? It's not like I'm *obsessed* or anything. It's just…weird. And I like weird.

It's just sitting there, you know? Like, a fully furnished living room, just…left. On Centennial Lane. No house attached. Just a living room. With a floral couch and a creepy porcelain doll. It's unsettling.

Paul found it first, actually. He was biking home from work and he said it just appeared overnight. Like, poof. Living room. And nobody knows where it came from.

It's not like it's a *nice* living room, either. It's all faded and dusty and kinda depressing. But it's…intriguing. It makes you wonder about the story behind it. Who lived there? Why did they leave it? What happened?

I've been biking by it every day, just…looking. Trying to figure it out. It's like a puzzle. And I like puzzles. Especially weird ones.

It's also a good place to think. You know? Just sit on the porch swing (even though it's kinda broken) and contemplate the meaning of life. Or, you know, just avoid thinking about everything else that's going on.

So, yeah. I'm interested in the abandoned living room. It's a mystery. And I'm a sucker for a good mystery. Don't judge me. It's not like I'm planning to move in or anything. Though…the floral couch *is* kinda comfy looking. No, no. Bad Juno. Don't even think about it.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with the Wizard. That guy was…creepy. Seriously. And that whisper? Still gives me the shivers.

Okay, so, he said, "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" when I went down to his basement to get the record. And it wasn't about the record. Not even close.

He didn't want a baby. He wanted…a connection. A family. He was lonely. Pathetically, desperately lonely. He'd been fixated on me for a long time, watching me, building this whole fantasy in his head. He thought if he could just get close to me, get involved in the adoption, he could somehow fill that void.

It was about control, too. He wanted to be needed. He wanted to be important. He wanted to be a father figure, but in a totally messed up, inappropriate way.

It was…gross. And scary. And it made me realize how dangerous he was.

He wasn't thinking about what *I* wanted, or what was best for the baby. He was just thinking about himself. And that's what made him so unsettling.

It wasn't a sweet, longing kind of whisper. It was a possessive, creepy, unsettling whisper. And it's a whisper I'll probably never forget.

Honestly, just thinking about it makes me want to listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. It helps drown out the bad thoughts.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. It's a valid question, I guess. It's not like I was thinking strategically or anything. It was more of a…panic move.

Look, I just found out I was pregnant. Like, *really* pregnant. And I was walking home from the doctor's office, trying to process everything, and I had this stupid juice container in my hand. It just felt…symbolic, you know? Like, a representation of my old life. All sweet and empty.

So I threw it away. Dramatic, I know. But I was feeling dramatic.

And then I just…needed something. Anything. To distract myself. To feel like I had some control. And Dancing Elk Drug was right there. It's not like I was going to buy a pregnancy test. I already knew. I just needed to…be around people. To feel normal.

Plus, they have those little candy displays by the register. And sometimes, a little bit of sugar is the only thing that can make everything okay. Even if it's just for a minute.

It wasn't a well-thought-out plan. It was just…a reaction. A desperate attempt to cope with a situation I wasn't prepared for.

Honestly, it was a really dumb thing to do. But I was a mess. And sometimes, messes just happen. Don't judge me too harshly, okay? It was a confusing time.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…a moment.

Okay, so, there I was, at the drugstore, trying to buy a pregnancy test without completely losing my mind. And this girl, she was…intense. Like, seriously hardcore. Muscles, tattoos, the whole nine yards. She looked like she could bench press a small car.

And she just…stared. And then, out of nowhere, she asked me, very seriously, if my nipples were real brown.

I was completely stunned. I just stood there, blinking, trying to process what she'd said. Like, what even *is* that question? And why would anyone ask it?

I think she was trying to…I don't know…gauge my authenticity? Like, she was suspicious that I wasn't "tough" enough to have naturally brown nipples? It was so bizarre.

I mumbled something about it being none of her business and tried to walk away, but she followed me for a few feet, still staring. It was incredibly awkward.

Honestly, I still have no idea what that was about. It was just one of those weird, random encounters that happen when you're a teenager. And it definitely made me question my life choices.

It just goes to show you, people are strange. And sometimes, they ask really, really weird questions. And sometimes, you just have to deal with it and try not to freak out.

It's a story I'll probably be telling for the rest of my life. Because seriously, who asks someone if their nipples are real brown? Only in my life, I guess.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. Right. She was…essential. Seriously. If it wasn't for Leah, I probably would have just run away to Canada or something. Not that Canada's bad, it's just…cold. And I don't do well with cold.

Look, I'm not exactly the most emotionally open person. I use sarcasm as a shield, okay? It's a defense mechanism. But Leah, she just…saw through all that. She didn't judge me for being pregnant, or for wanting to give the baby up for adoption. She just listened. And she didn't try to fix things, which was good, because things didn't *need* fixing. They just *were*.

She was the one who went with me to all the doctor's appointments. Which, let me tell you, are not fun. Especially when you're trying to pretend you're not freaking out. She held my hand and made me laugh, even when I wanted to cry.

And she was the one who helped me navigate the whole adoption process. It's complicated, you know? Lots of paperwork and meetings and emotional stuff. She was my advocate, my sounding board, my sanity check.

Honestly, she was the only person I could really talk to about it. My dad was great, but he didn't really *get* it. And my mom…well, my mom was just my mom. Leah understood what I was going through, because she's just…a good person.

She didn't try to tell me what to do, she just supported me in whatever decision I made. And that meant everything. She reminded me that I was still me, even though I was pregnant. That I still had a life, and a future, and that everything was going to be okay.

So yeah, Leah. She was a lifesaver. A total rock star. I don't know what I would have done without her. Seriously. She's the best. Don't tell her I said that, though. It'll go to her head.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the ultrasound thing? Honestly, it wasn't some grand, carefully planned gesture. It was more…desperate. And kinda impulsive.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were…distant. Like, they were nice enough, but they were so focused on their perfect life, their perfect house, their perfect everything. They weren't really *seeing* me, you know? They were seeing a problem, a bump in their perfect plan.

I needed them to see it as a *person*. Not just a thing to be dealt with. And I figured, if they could actually *see* the baby, maybe, just maybe, they'd start to feel something.

It was Paul's idea, actually. He was the one who said, "What if you showed them the ultrasound?" I was hesitant at first. It felt…vulnerable. Like I was putting my heart on a platter. But I was running out of options. They weren't listening to anything I said.

So, I just…did it. I brought the ultrasound picture to their house, and I just handed it to them. No big speech, no dramatic music. Just…the picture.

And it worked. Sort of. They were still freaked out, but you could see something shift in their eyes. They started to ask questions, to actually *look* at the picture. It wasn't a magical fix, but it was a start.

It was a gamble, for sure. But sometimes, you just gotta take a risk. Especially when you're dealing with people who are too busy being perfect to see what's right in front of them.

It was a messy, awkward, totally Juno-style solution. But it got their attention. And that's all that mattered.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark tells me Vanessa isn't home? My initial reaction? Probably a really intense eye roll. Like, a full-body eye roll. It wasn't exactly a surprise, you know? The guy was practically radiating awkwardness the whole time we were driving. And Vanessa? She's...Vanessa.

But then it hit me. Like, *really* hit me. This wasn't just some awkward teenage boy being a dork. This was…serious. He was lying. And not just a little white lie, a big, honking, "Oh, my life is a mess and I'm trying to hide it" lie.

So the eye roll turned into this weird, cold feeling in my stomach. Like I'd just swallowed a rock. And then I started thinking. Thinking about how he was acting, about how Vanessa always seemed kinda…sad. And it just clicked.

I didn't say anything right away. I just kinda stared at him. Trying to figure out what was going on. It wasn't about being mad at Mark, it was about…everything. About how messed up things were. About how people lie to protect themselves, even when it hurts everyone else.

It was a really heavy moment. And honestly? It was the moment I realized this wasn't just about a baby anymore. It was about a whole lot of other stuff too. It was about people being real, and being honest, and dealing with the consequences of their choices.

So yeah. Eye roll, then cold stomach, then a whole lot of thinking. It wasn't a fun moment. Not even a little bit.

Ugh, okay, you're picking apart my life choices now? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed that moment a million times in my head already.

Look, it wasn't about *Mark* specifically being a sellout. It was…everything. It was about him being all enthusiastic about making commercials for, like, car dealerships and stuff after he was so passionate about music. It felt…small. Like he was giving up on his dreams.

And honestly, it was a defense mechanism. I was already feeling super weird and vulnerable about everything that was going on with the baby and Paul and everything else. And he was being all…happy and normal. It was irritating.

I say a lot of sarcastic things. It's how I cope. It's how I keep people at arm's length. It's how I avoid actually dealing with my feelings.

So yeah, the "sellout" comment was a little harsh. I probably shouldn't have said it. But it was a way of deflecting, of making myself feel better by putting him down. It was immature and mean, and I regret it.

But it was also…real. I was scared. I was scared of losing him, of him changing, of everything falling apart. And sometimes, when I'm scared, I say stupid things.

It's complicated, okay? Don't judge me. I was a teenager dealing with a lot. And sometimes, teenagers say things they don't mean. Or maybe they do mean them, but they don't know how to say them in a nice way.

It's just…life. It's messy and awkward and full of stupid jokes. And sometimes, those stupid jokes are a way of hiding the fact that you're completely terrified.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a lot.

Honestly? It made me feel kinda small. Like, I was expecting…something. I don't know *what*, exactly. Maybe a little excitement? A little…I don't know, *joy*? But he just kinda…stared. And then he said it was "a lot to process."

A lot to process? It's a *baby*, Mark! It's not a tax return!

It wasn't that I expected him to be jumping for joy or anything. I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation. But I thought he'd at least be…human about it. You know?

It just felt like he was seeing the pregnancy as a problem to be solved, not a little person growing inside me. And that stung. It really stung.

I mean, I was already dealing with giving up the baby, and trying to figure out my own life, and then he just…shut down. It made me feel even more alone.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a joke about it being a little alien. But inside, I was just…sad. And kinda angry.

It made me realize that he wasn't really ready to be a dad. And that was okay, I guess. But it didn't make it any easier.

It was just…a really awkward moment. And it kinda set the tone for the rest of our relationship, honestly. It showed me that we weren't on the same page. And that was something I had to accept.

Ugh. I need a smoothie. And maybe a really loud song. Talking about it just brings back all the feelings.

Ugh. Okay, so Havenbrooke. That place…it smelled like antiseptic and regret. And the people there, they weren't *mean*, exactly, but they were…intense. Like they were trying way too hard to be understanding.

The possibility of getting an abortion there? It wasn't…easy. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yeah, let's do this!" It was a lot of thinking. A lot of staring at the ceiling. A lot of trying to figure out what the *right* thing to do was.

Honestly? I was scared. Not of the procedure itself, really. I was scared of what it would mean. Like, if I did it, would I be a bad person? Would I regret it forever? Would it change me?

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. Even though it wasn't…a baby yet, you know? It was still…something. And I felt responsible for it.

I talked to Paul about it a lot. He was…supportive. In his own, kinda clueless way. And I talked to my dad. He didn't say much, but he listened. Which is pretty much all I needed from him.

But ultimately, I realized that getting an abortion wasn't the right choice for me. It wasn't about what other people thought, or what society expected. It was about what *I* felt. And I felt like I wanted to give this baby a life. Even if it meant giving it up.

Havenbrooke…it was just a place to explore my options. And I'm glad I did. Because it helped me figure out what I really wanted. It wasn't a happy decision, exactly. But it was *my* decision. And that's what mattered.

It was complicated. Everything about this whole situation was complicated. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. For me. And for the baby.

Ugh. Okay. You want to talk about Bleeker. Right. Well, it's…complicated. It wasn't like in a movie, all sparkly and perfect. It was…Bleeker. And me. And a whole lot of awkwardness.

He was always *there*, you know? Like a really enthusiastic, slightly dorky puppy. Following me around, offering me guitar picks, being generally sweet. At first, I just saw him as a friend. A really persistent friend. I mean, he was always trying to write songs about me, which was…a lot.

But then, things started to shift. He was just…reliable. He listened when I was freaking out about the baby, and he didn't judge me. He just…accepted me. Which was a big deal, considering everything.

We started spending more time together, just talking. Walking around, listening to music. He made me laugh, even when I didn't want to. And he was genuinely kind. Like, actually kind, not just pretending to be.

As for when we…you know…became intimate? It wasn't a grand romantic gesture. It wasn't a movie moment. It was…gradual. We were at his house, just hanging out, talking about the future. And he kissed me. And it wasn't weird. It just…felt right.

It wasn't about sex, okay? It was about connection. About needing someone to hold onto when everything felt so out of control. It was about finding comfort in someone who genuinely cared about me.

It wasn't perfect. We were both scared and confused. And it definitely wasn't the solution to all my problems. But it was…good. It was a safe space. And it helped me feel less alone.

It wasn't a fairytale romance. It was real. Messy and awkward and real. And honestly, that's what made it work. It wasn't about finding "the one," it was about finding someone who was there for me when I needed him most.

And yeah, it ended. But it was important. It helped me figure out what I wanted, and what I needed. And that's something I'll always be grateful for.

Ugh. That was a lot. Can we talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of tater tots?

Ugh. Okay, so you want to know how I felt about being pregnant with Bleeker's kid? It's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a joyride, you know?

At first? Panic. Straight-up, full-blown panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not morning sickness and baby names. It was terrifying. I mean, Bleeker was sweet, don't get me wrong. But we were kids. *Kids* having a kid. It was insane.

Then there was the shame. And the awkwardness. Telling my dad was…rough. And my mom, she tried to be supportive, but I could tell she was worried sick. Everyone was worried sick.

But then, as things settled down, it started to feel…different. Like, I wasn't just Juno anymore. I was Juno *with* a purpose. I was growing a person. It was weirdly empowering, in a way.

I didn't want to keep the baby, though. I knew that pretty quickly. I wasn't ready. I had my own life to figure out. But I wanted to make sure the baby had a good life, a stable life. And Mark and Vanessa, they were perfect. They were ready. They were excited.

So, it wasn't about *not* wanting the baby. It was about wanting the best for the baby. And that meant giving it up.

It was sad, of course. Really sad. But it was also…right. It was the right thing to do. And I knew, deep down, that I could handle it. I could be strong enough to make that decision.

It was a lot. A whole lot. But it made me grow up, you know? It made me figure out what I wanted out of life. And it taught me that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the best ones.

So, how did I feel? Scared, confused, sad, hopeful…all of it. It was a mess. But it was *my* mess. And I got through it.

Ugh. Okay, so telling Bleeker… that was… a whole thing. It wasn’t like some romantic movie scene, let me tell you. It was awkward. Really awkward.

I didn’t just, like, casually drop it into conversation. That’s not my style. I needed a plan. And snacks. Always snacks.

I lured him to the park, under the pretense of needing help with a science project. Which was a lie. I just needed a neutral location where I could bail if things went south.

I had rehearsed what I was going to say, like, a million times. But when I actually opened my mouth, it all came out jumbled and weird. I think I started with something about positive pregnancy tests and the complexities of the human reproductive system. Smooth, right?

He just stared at me. Like, a deer in headlights. And then he started laughing. Not a mean laugh, but a nervous, “I have no idea what’s happening” laugh. Which, honestly, was pretty accurate.

I got really mad. I was like, “This isn’t funny, Bleeker! This is my life we’re talking about!” And then I started to cry. Which was not part of the plan.

He stopped laughing, obviously. And then he just…held my hand. And he listened. I told him everything. About the test, about the adoption plan, about how scared I was.

He didn’t say much at first. He just kept squeezing my hand. And then he said, “Wow.” Which, okay, not the most profound response, but it was honest.

He was really supportive, actually. He didn’t freak out or try to talk me out of anything. He just said he’d be there for me, whatever I decided.

It wasn’t a perfect moment. It was messy and emotional and totally unglamorous. But it was real. And that’s what mattered.

It was the start of us figuring things out. And honestly, it was a lot better than I expected. Even if it did involve a lot of awkward silences and a questionable science project.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like flipping a light switch, you know? It wasn't one big dramatic cry-fest, even though movies would have you believe it was. It was…complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…panic. Like, a full-blown, can't-breathe, everything-is-ruined kind of panic. I was sixteen! I had plans! Okay, not *detailed* plans, but plans nonetheless. And a baby just…didn't fit into those plans.

But then, after the initial freak-out, it started to feel…right. Not happy, exactly. But right. I realized pretty quickly that I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even ready to pick out a college, let alone raise a human being.

It wasn't about not wanting a baby, it was about wanting to give *this* baby the best life possible. And I knew I couldn't do that. Not then. Not ever, probably.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it wasn't like I was just giving the baby away. I was choosing a family for it. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They were exactly the kind of people I wanted raising my kid.

It still hurt, though. A lot. Especially when it was time. Saying goodbye…that was the hardest part. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

And honestly? It was empowering. I made a decision. A really hard decision. And I stuck with it. It wasn't about what other people wanted, or what society expected. It was about what was best for everyone involved.

It's still…something I think about. A lot. But I don't regret it. I gave my baby a good life, and I got to live mine. And that's all I could ask for.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't pretty. But it was my choice. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know my musical tastes? It's…complicated. It kinda depends on my mood, you know? Like, if I'm feeling angsty, I need something with a little bite. If I'm feeling mellow, I need something kinda sweet.

But generally, I'm into stuff that's a little bit quirky and a little bit real. I can't stand anything too polished or fake.

The Moldy Peaches are, like, my all-time favorite. They're just…honest. And kinda weird. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Seriously.

I also listen to a lot of indie rock. Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins, Bright Eyes…that kinda stuff. It's good for thinking and staring out the window.

I'm also a sucker for a good soundtrack. *Garden State* is a classic. And *Singles* is pretty awesome.

I don't really listen to a lot of mainstream stuff. It just feels…empty. Like, it's all about image and not about the music.

Oh, and I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, The Beach Boys and stuff. My dad used to listen to it, so it reminds me of him.

Basically, I like music that makes me *feel* something. It doesn't have to be happy, it just has to be real. And it definitely can't be boring.

So yeah, that's my musical taste in a nutshell. It's a little bit all over the place, but that's kinda how I am.



Don't judge me. I have eclectic tastes. It's a personality trait.

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Seriously? You're asking *me* about "The Wizard of Gore"? That's…a choice.

Look, I've seen some weird stuff, okay? Being pregnant and dealing with everything that came with it opened my eyes to a whole new level of weird. But that movie…that movie is just…*intense*.

It's not even scary, really. It's just…gross. And unsettling. And kinda pointless. Like, what was the point of all that fake gore? It's not even good fake gore! It's just…sticky.

And the whole premise? A snuff film festival? Seriously? That's just depressing. It's exploiting people's misery for entertainment. It's not funny, it's not clever, it's just…icky.

I get that it's a cult classic and people are into that kind of thing. But honestly, I'd rather watch a rom-com. Or even a documentary about competitive eating. Anything would be better than watching that again.

It's just…not my cup of tea. Or, like, my root beer float. Or whatever. It's just bad. Really bad.

Don't get me wrong, I appreciate a good horror movie. But this isn't horror. It's just…exploitation. And it's kinda depressing.

So, my opinion? Avoid it. Unless you're into that sort of thing. And if you are, well…you do you. But don't expect me to join you. I have standards, okay? Even if they're slightly questionable sometimes.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. But it's…very popular. Like, aggressively popular. It feels kinda…beige. No offense to any Madisons out there.

It's one of those names that was cool for a minute, and then everyone started naming their kids Madison, and now it just feels…overdone. Like a Starbucks pumpkin spice latte. It was good at first, but now it's just everywhere.

It's not offensively bad, it's just…predictable. It doesn't have a lot of personality, you know? It doesn't make me think of anything specific. It just feels…safe.

I'm more of a fan of names that are a little bit quirky, a little bit different. Like, Pearl or Clementine or even Agnes. Something with a little bit of edge.

But hey, if someone wants to name their kid Madison, that's their business. It's not my place to judge. It's just…not my vibe.

It's a perfectly fine name. Just…not a particularly *interesting* name. Does that make sense? It's like a really comfortable pair of jeans. They're practical, but they're not exactly going to turn heads.



Honestly, naming a kid is hard. There's so much pressure to pick the perfect name. Just pick something you like, and don't worry about what anyone else thinks. Unless they're your parents. Then you might want to listen to them a little bit.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? It's not exactly a light topic. And honestly, it still kinda messes with my head sometimes, even after everything.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. People try to make it sound all noble and selfless, and yeah, there's a part of that. But it's also…really, really sad. You're carrying a person inside you, and then you're choosing to give them to someone else. It's not something you just *decide* lightly.

I knew I wasn't ready. I was seventeen, for crying out loud. I had my whole life ahead of me, and a baby just didn't fit into that life. Not then. And I wanted that baby to have everything – a stable home, two parents who were ready and willing, a good education. Things I couldn't provide at the time.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the best *for* the baby.

It's a complicated mix of feelings. Grief, relief, guilt, hope…it's a whole mess. And it doesn't just go away. You still think about them. You still wonder what their life is like.

But I also know I made the right decision. For me, and for the baby. I found a really amazing couple, Mark and Vanessa, who were so excited to be parents. And I got to be involved in the process, to choose them, to know that my baby was going to be loved and cared for.

It's not a perfect solution. It's not what anyone *wants* to happen. But sometimes, it's the best option. And it takes a lot of courage to make that choice.

It's not something I talk about a lot. It's still…raw. But it's a part of who I am. And I wouldn't change it. Even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done.



It's just…it's complicated, okay? Don't expect a neat and tidy answer. Life rarely gives you those.

Ugh. Okay, so you want to know how I…deal with all this? It’s not exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It’s more like a hike up a really steep hill in snow boots.

Honestly? A lot of it is just…putting one foot in front of the other. And a whole lot of sarcasm. It’s my coping mechanism. If I didn’t make jokes about everything, I’d probably just curl up in a ball and cry. Which, don’t get me wrong, happens sometimes.

The biggest thing is realizing I can’t do it alone. I’m fiercely independent, okay? I like to handle things myself. But this…this is different. I needed help. And accepting that was, like, the hardest part.

My parents, they’re…complicated. But they’re trying. And Paul and Vanessa? They’re surprisingly awesome. They’re not judging me, they’re just…being there. And that means a lot.

And then there’s Bleeker. He’s…Bleeker. He’s sweet, but he’s not exactly equipped to deal with this. But he’s trying too.

It’s also about prioritizing. School is still important, even though it feels kinda pointless sometimes. I need to graduate. And I need to figure out what I want to do with my life, even if that life now includes a baby.

And honestly? It’s about letting go of expectations. I had this whole plan for my life, and now it’s completely different. And that’s okay. It’s not the life I expected, but it could still be a good life.

I also try to focus on the positive. I’m giving this baby a good home. I’m choosing a family who will love and support it. And that’s a pretty amazing thing.

It’s hard. It’s really, really hard. But I’m stronger than I thought I was. And I’m learning a lot about myself. And about life. And about the fact that sometimes, things just happen. And you have to deal with them.

So, how do I handle it? I take it one day at a time. I lean on my friends and family. I make a lot of sarcastic comments. And I try to remember that even though things are messy and complicated, it’s all going to be okay. Eventually.



It’s a work in progress, okay? Don’t expect me to have all the answers. I’m just figuring it out as I go.

Ugh, okay, that's…a loaded question. It's like, the whole point of my life right now, isn't it? Balancing wanting to do everything myself with realizing I can't, and also, maybe shouldn't.

It's hard, okay? I've always been pretty self-sufficient. My dad's kinda…absent. And my mom, she's…enthusiastic, but not always *helpful*. So I got used to figuring things out on my own. It's safer that way, you know? Less chance of getting disappointed.

But then, you know, *this* happened. And suddenly I needed a lot of help. From my dad, from Paul and Vanessa, even from Mark. And it was…weird. It felt like admitting I couldn't handle things. Like admitting I wasn't as strong as I thought I was.

I think the key is realizing that asking for help isn't the same as being weak. It's just being…smart. It's recognizing that other people have skills and experiences that I don't. And that sometimes, letting someone else take the wheel is the best thing you can do.

It's still a struggle, though. I still want to be in control. I still want to make my own decisions. But I'm learning to trust people. To let them support me. To let them be there for me.

It's about finding a balance, I guess. Knowing when to stand on your own two feet and when to lean on someone else. It's about being independent, but not isolated. It's about accepting that you don't have to do everything alone.

And honestly? It's kinda nice. It's nice to have people who care about you and want to help. It's nice to know you're not alone. Even when you feel like you are.

So yeah, I'm still figuring it out. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely. It's a work in progress. Just like everything else, I guess.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. Honestly, at first, he was just…Bleeker. You know? The quiet kid who played guitar and smelled faintly of patchouli. I didn't really *see* him, not like that. He was just a friend, a convenient study buddy, someone who didn't judge me for liking The Moldy Peaches.

When I found out I was pregnant, everything changed. Suddenly, he wasn't just Bleeker anymore. He was…reliable. He didn't freak out, he didn't run away. He just…showed up. He started walking me home from school, bringing me snacks, just being *there*. It was kinda sweet, actually.

At first, I was pushing him away. I didn't want him to feel obligated or anything. I was trying to handle everything on my own, be all independent and strong. But he just kept being…Bleeker. Quietly supportive. He didn't try to fix things, he just listened.

As my belly got bigger, and things got more real, I started to rely on him more. He helped me pick out baby names (which was a disaster, let me tell you), he went with me to doctor's appointments, and he even tried to build a crib, which was…a learning experience for both of us.

He wasn't perfect. He was still awkward and shy and sometimes said the wrong thing. But he was *genuine*. He wasn't trying to be someone he wasn't. And he was always there for me, no matter what.

By the end of it, he wasn't just a friend. He was…someone I trusted. Someone I cared about. Someone who made me laugh, even when I wanted to cry. He wasn't the father of the baby, but he was a really good friend, and he became a really important part of my life.

It wasn't a romantic thing, not at first. It was just…a connection. A quiet understanding. And honestly, that was enough. It was more than enough. He showed me that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still room for kindness and support. And that's something I'll always appreciate.

Ugh, okay, this question *still* comes up. It's not like I strategically chose the name of a powerful Roman goddess to make a statement or something. My parents are…eccentric. Okay, *really* eccentric.

My dad's obsessed with Greek and Roman mythology. Like, seriously obsessed. He reads all those books, watches all those movies, and constantly tries to work mythological references into everyday conversation. It's embarrassing.

And my mom? She's into astrology and crystals and all that stuff. She thought Juno was a "powerful, nurturing energy" and that it would bring me good luck. Honestly, I think she just liked the way it sounded.

So, they combined their obsessions and decided to name me Juno. I didn't have a say in it. I was a baby.

It's kinda ironic, right? Juno was the queen of the gods, the protector of marriage and women. And here I am, a pregnant teenager giving the baby up for adoption. Not exactly a queenly situation.

I used to hate my name. It felt…pretentious. But I've kinda grown into it. It's unique, and it definitely gets people's attention. And sometimes, it's fun to live up to the name. Just a little bit.

So, yeah, that's the story. It wasn't my choice. It was just my parents being…my parents. Don't read too much into it. It's not like I'm secretly a goddess or anything. Just a regular girl trying to figure things out.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, okay? She was trying to be supportive, but you could tell she was kinda freaked out. And I get it. It's not exactly a planned life event.

But to hear her say she was *relieved* to see it was a real baby, and not…I don't know, a monster or something? It just felt…dismissive. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like the whole thing was just about her anxiety, and not about the actual, you know, *life* growing inside me.

It made me feel like I was just a vessel. A walking, talking incubator. And it made me question everything. Was she even thinking about the baby as a person? Or just as a problem that was finally…visualized?

I tried to play it cool, obviously. I'm good at that. Sarcasm is my defense mechanism. But inside, I was just…hurt. And confused. And kinda angry.

It was one of those moments where I realized this wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person, and I needed to protect them. And maybe, I needed to protect myself too.

It definitely made me think about what I wanted out of this adoption. I wanted a family who would love this baby unconditionally, not just be relieved that it was "normal."

It was a wake-up call, honestly. A messy, uncomfortable, totally Juno-esque wake-up call. And it made me even more determined to find the perfect parents for this kid.

Ugh, Vanessa's mom. Okay, that was…a moment. A *very* intense moment. It was like being cornered by a very well-dressed, very angry bear. Seriously.

So, she finds out I'm at the house, right? And it's not like we were doing anything *wrong*, exactly. We were just…talking. About stuff. Life stuff. And maybe watching a movie. But apparently, that was a cardinal sin in Vanessa's mom's book.

She just…launched. A full-on verbal assault. About responsibility, and maturity, and the dangers of teenage pregnancy, and how I was a bad influence on Vanessa. It was a lot.

My first instinct was to be sarcastic. Like, "Oh, I'm *so* sorry I exist and am disrupting your perfectly curated suburban life." But I quickly realized that would just make things worse. She was already operating at a level ten rage, and I didn't need to escalate it.

So, I went for the…calm approach. Which is hard for me, obviously. I just stood there and let her yell. And then, when she finally paused for breath, I just said, really quietly, "I understand you're worried about Vanessa. I am too. And I'm not trying to make things harder for her. I'm just trying to be a friend."

It didn't magically fix everything. She still gave me the stink eye for the rest of the afternoon. But it seemed to…de-escalate things a little. She stopped yelling, at least.

And then Vanessa chimed in, which was good. She told her mom that I was being supportive and that she trusted me. That seemed to help.

Honestly, it was mostly just surviving. And hoping I didn't get grounded. It was a reminder that adults can be really, really dramatic. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just…be quiet and let them get it out of their system.

It was awkward. Super awkward. But hey, I've dealt with worse. Right? (Don't answer that.)

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is…still a hard thing to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? I totally wanted the baby. But I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud.

I looked at my life, and I just…didn't see a place for a baby in it. Not yet. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my dreams, my school, my…everything. I wanted to go to college, maybe travel, figure out who I was. And I knew I couldn't do all that and be a good mom at the same time.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted the baby to have a good life, a stable life, a life with parents who were ready and able to give it everything it needed. I knew I couldn't provide that, not at that point in my life.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They were the kind of people who would give that baby everything. And that's what mattered most.

It was the hardest decision I ever had to make. It still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right one. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby the best possible life. And that's something I can live with.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't perfect. But it was my decision. And I stand by it. Even now.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about the whole lab partner situation? Fine. It's not my *favorite* topic, but here we are.

Look, I wouldn't exactly call myself a "deadbeat," okay? That's harsh. More like…strategically absent. Or selectively engaged. It's a nuanced thing.

It's just…science isn't really my thing. Like, at all. All the beakers and the Bunsen burners and the dissecting…it just feels…pointless. I mean, what's the point of knowing the cellular structure of a frog? Seriously? It's not gonna help me navigate the complexities of teenage pregnancy, that's for sure.

And Paulie Bleeker? He's…enthusiastic. *Too* enthusiastic. He gets really into it, and he starts explaining things, and I just…zone out. It's not that I'm not listening, it's just that my brain is already occupied with, like, a million other things.

So, I tend to let him do most of the work. I'll offer moral support. And I'm really good at writing down his answers. It's a team effort, right?

Okay, maybe it's not a *fair* team effort. But I'm a good note-taker! And I'm a good friend. And sometimes, that's more important than getting an A in biology.

Plus, I figured he kinda liked doing the work. He gets to show off his science skills. It's a win-win.

So, yeah, maybe I'm a little bit of a slacker when it comes to lab work. But I'm a good person. And I'm trying to figure things out. And sometimes, that means letting Paulie Bleeker carry the weight of the scientific world on his shoulders. It's a sacrifice I'm willing to make.

Ugh. Seriously? They're bickering in the middle of dissecting a frog? Some people have no chill. Okay, here's how I'd handle that.

I'd probably just…stop dissecting. Like, dramatically put down the scalpel and look at them both with this *look*. You know, the one that says, "Are you kidding me right now?"

Then I'd say, and I'd say it really slowly, "Okay, hold up. We're dissecting a *frog*. A dead frog. It's not exactly brain surgery. Can we maybe focus on the frog and less on…whatever this is?"

If they kept going, I'd probably add, "Look, I'm just trying to get a good grade here. I don't need the added drama. And honestly, it's kinda grossing me out."

And then, if they *still* didn't stop, I'd just start talking really loudly about the frog's internal organs. Like, super detailed descriptions. "Oh, look at the liver! Isn't it fascinating? And the intestines are just…wow." Just to be annoying.

I'm not getting involved in their relationship issues. I have enough of my own, thank you very much. I'm here for the frog. And the grade. And maybe a little bit of peace and quiet.

Honestly, people are weird. And frogs are kinda weird too, now that I'm thinking about it. But at least the frog isn't arguing.

Ugh. Okay. You really went there. Look, it's not "hasty." It's…considered. And it's not something I'm taking lightly, okay? It's just…complicated.

I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior. I have tests to take and college applications to fill out and a life to, like, figure out. And now I'm pregnant. By Bleeker. Paul Bleeker. Who is a sweet guy, don't get me wrong, but definitely not equipped to be a dad. Neither am I, honestly.

My parents…they're good people. But they're also…my parents. They have expectations. And a baby doesn't exactly fit into their plan for me. And honestly, it doesn't fit into *my* plan either. Not right now.

I've been talking to my friend, Leah, and she's been really supportive. And I've been thinking about it a lot. And I've decided that giving the baby up for adoption is the best option. For everyone.

It's not about not wanting a baby. It's about wanting to give a baby the best possible life. And I don't think I can do that right now. I'm not ready. I'm not financially stable. I'm not emotionally ready.

So, yeah, I'm considering an abortion. But it's not "hasty." It's a difficult decision that I'm making after a lot of thought and consideration. And it's nobody's business but mine. And Paul's. And maybe my parents'. But definitely not yours.

Okay? Just…okay. It's a lot. And I don't really want to talk about it anymore right now.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? It's a valid question, I guess. People need to know. It's a cultural imperative.

Look, I'm not saying I'm a connoisseur of cheap wine coolers or anything. But when you're, like, 16 and trying to navigate the complexities of life, sometimes you need a little something to take the edge off. And Snow Peak Peach Boone's? It's…perfect.

It's not too sweet, it's not too strong, and it tastes vaguely like actual peaches. It's like a little burst of sunshine in a can. It's also, like, the least embarrassing flavor. I mean, Strawberry Kiwi? That's just…sad.

And it's just…nostalgic, okay? It reminds me of late nights with Leah, talking about everything and nothing. It reminds me of trying to figure out what I was going to do with my life. It reminds me of being young and confused and hopeful.

It's not about the taste, really. It's about the memories. It's about the feeling. It's about being a teenager and trying to make sense of the world.

So yeah, Snow Peak Peach Boone's. It's the best. Don't judge me. It's a complicated relationship. And honestly, I'm probably overanalyzing it. But that's what I do.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking why everyone's kinda…flailing around me about the whole baby thing? It's not exactly a surprise party, you know? I mean, I'm not exactly subtle.

It's mostly because I'm not doing what they *expect* a pregnant teenager to do. Like, most people freak out, right? They start talking about adoption or abortion or, like, running away to Canada. And I'm just…chill. Relatively.

I decided pretty quickly that I wasn't keeping the baby. I'm sixteen! I have a life to live, and it doesn't involve diapers and PTA meetings right now. And I found a really great couple, Mark and Vanessa, who are totally excited about it. They're, like, perfect parents.

But people don't get that. They think I should be more upset, or more scared, or more…something. They keep trying to tell me what I *should* be feeling, and it's really annoying.

My dad, he's just…confused. He wants me to be happy, but he also wants me to be safe. And he doesn't really understand why I'm not freaking out.

And my mom, she's trying to be supportive, but she keeps offering me advice about things I don't even want to hear. Like, "Have you thought about naming it?" No, Mom, I haven't. Because I'm giving it up!

It's like they're all waiting for me to fall apart, so they can swoop in and "fix" things. But I'm not broken. I just made a decision. And it's a good decision. For me, and for the baby.

They just need to get over it, you know? It's my life, and I'm handling it. And honestly, I'm doing a pretty good job, if you ask me.



It's just…people have a hard time with things that don't fit their expectations. And I'm definitely not fitting anyone's expectations right now.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It was…not a fun conversation. Bren was being all Bren-ish, you know? Super concerned and trying to be all mature and responsible. Which, fine, she's good at that. But it was still annoying.

I think I mostly just deflected. Like, a lot. I mean, what was I supposed to say? "Oh yeah, I'm totally dating a married man, it's super complicated and I'm probably making a terrible mistake?" No. That's not how I roll.

I remember saying something like, "Look, it's not as simple as you think." And then I probably made a sarcastic comment about how everyone always has an opinion about my life. I'm really good at sarcasm when I'm uncomfortable. It's a defense mechanism.

I tried to explain that it wasn't like I was actively *trying* to break up a marriage. It just…happened. And that Mark was going through stuff, and I was just…there. Which, looking back, sounds really lame. But that's how I felt at the time.

Bren kept pushing, though. She was all, "But he's married, Juno! It's wrong!" And I just kept saying, "I know, okay? I know it's wrong. I'm dealing with it."

Honestly, I think I mostly just shut down. I didn't want to talk about it. It was too messy and complicated and I didn't want to admit to myself how messed up the whole situation was.

I think I ended the conversation by saying something like, "Can we just talk about something else? Like, the new Fall Out Boy album?" Because, you know, priorities.

It wasn't my finest moment, okay? I was a mess. And Bren was right to be concerned. But I wasn't ready to hear it. I was too busy being…stupid.



It's still a little embarrassing to think about, honestly. But hey, everyone makes mistakes. Right?

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing that up *now*? It was a moment, alright? A moment of…intense emotion. And honestly, it felt right in the moment. Don't judge.

Look, it was my grandpa's memorial service. And it was…weird. Everyone was being all sad and quiet and pretending to be all dignified. And I just…couldn't. It felt fake. He wasn't a fake person. He was a goofy, fun-loving grandpa who would have probably laughed if he saw everyone moping around.

And the blue slushie? It was his favorite. He always got one when we went to the arcade. It was a little reminder of him.

So, yeah, I poured it into the urn. It was a way of saying goodbye in my own way. A way of honoring him and remembering the good times. It wasn't disrespectful, it was…personal.

It was a way of saying, "Hey Grandpa, I miss you, and I'm gonna live my life to the fullest, even if it means making a little bit of a mess."

Paul was not thrilled, obviously. But he eventually understood. And honestly, it broke the tension. People started laughing. It was a little bit of light in a really dark day.

So, yeah, I poured my blue slushie into the urn. Don't ask me to explain it. It just…happened. It was a Juno thing. And sometimes, you just gotta do a Juno thing.

Ugh, okay, so "cope" is a strong word. It wasn't exactly a graceful process. It was more like… flailing and trying not to drown. Honestly.

Growing up is hard enough without, you know, having a tiny human growing inside you. It felt like everyone else was just…living their normal teenage lives, worrying about prom and football games, and I was over here dealing with morning sickness and doctor's appointments and the terrifying realization that I was about to be a mom.

I leaned on a lot of things, I guess. First, Paul. He was…surprisingly good about it. A little clueless sometimes, but always supportive. And Bleeker, even though he was kinda a mess himself, he was always there to make me laugh.

My dad was…my dad. He tried to be understanding, but he mostly just worried. And my stepmom, Vanessa, she was actually really cool. She didn't judge me, and she gave me a lot of practical advice.

But mostly, I think I just tried to stay true to myself. I didn't want to let the pregnancy define me. I still listened to The Moldy Peaches, I still hung out with my friends, I still said what was on my mind. I just…had a bigger belly.

It was hard, though. Really hard. There were times when I felt completely overwhelmed and scared. I was worried about what people would think, about whether I was a good enough person to be a mom, about what my future would look like.

I think what helped the most was realizing that I wasn't alone. There were other people who had been through similar situations, and they were willing to help. And I realized that it was okay to ask for help. It wasn't a sign of weakness, it was a sign of strength.

And ultimately, I realized that I had a choice. I could let the pregnancy ruin my life, or I could use it as an opportunity to grow and learn and become a better person. And I chose the latter.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. It made me stronger, more independent, and more confident. And it taught me that even when things are really, really hard, you can still find a way to make it through.

So yeah, that's how I coped. Mostly by flailing, leaning on my friends and family, and trying to stay true to myself. And by listening to a lot of really good music.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense. Like, really eager. It was kinda awkward, honestly.

He was trying *so* hard to be cool, you know? Like, he'd try to use slang and talk about music I actually liked, but it always came off kinda forced. He'd be all, "That band is totally righteous!" and I'd just be like, "Okay, dude."

He was super nice, though. And really sweet to Vanessa. You could tell he really wanted a kid. He was just…a little bit clueless about, like, actual teenagers. He kept trying to relate to me by talking about his own high school experiences, which were, like, a million years ago.

He made me pancakes once. Which was nice, I guess. But they were shaped like dinosaurs. Dinosaurs! I'm sixteen, not six. It was a little patronizing.

And he kept asking me about my future plans. Like, what college I wanted to go to and what I wanted to do with my life. Which, hello? I'm pregnant. I haven't even thought past next week.

He wasn't trying to be weird or anything, he just…didn't get it. He was a good guy, a really good guy, but he was kinda clueless about the whole teenage pregnancy thing. It was like he was trying to solve a problem instead of just…being there.

Vanessa, though, she was awesome. She totally got it. She was the one who made me feel comfortable. Mark was just…Mark. A well-meaning, dinosaur-pancake-making, slightly awkward dude.

It wasn't *bad*, hanging out with him. It was just…weird. And a little bit exhausting. But I could tell he and Vanessa would be good parents. Even if he did try to talk to me like I was a little kid sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid. Honestly. It was…complicated.

So, there I was, trying to just, like, exist, right? And my stomach was doing its thing. It was getting harder to hide, even under, like, three layers of flannel. And Bleeker, being Bleeker, just had to *say* something.

It wasn't mean, exactly. He didn't say I looked like a whale or anything. He just…commented. Like, "Whoa, you're really…growing." Said it all wide-eyed and awkward.

And it was mortifying. Seriously. Like, full-body cringe. Because it was true, obviously. And it was a reminder that this wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. It was *happening*. And it was visible.

Part of me wanted to just punch him in the arm. Or yell at him. Or disappear into the floor. But another part of me…felt kinda relieved. Like, he acknowledged it. He didn't pretend it wasn't there.
