It was weird, because I was trying so hard to be cool and detached about everything. To pretend I had it all under control. But his comment just…broke through that. It reminded me that I was vulnerable. And scared.

And honestly? It made me realize I needed to stop pretending. I needed to let people in. Even Bleeker, as annoying as he could be.

So, I just kinda shrugged and said something sarcastic, like, "Yeah, well, I've been eating a lot of cheese fries." Which was true. But it was also a way of deflecting.

It was a small moment, but it stuck with me. It was one of those moments where everything felt…real. And kinda terrifying. And kinda beautiful, all at the same time.

Bleeker. He's a lot. But he's…okay. Sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Like, poking around in the messy parts of my brain. But fine, I'll answer it.

It wasn't the physical stuff, you know? Morning sickness was gross, sure, and my body felt like a total stranger for a while. But that was…manageable. It was a thing to deal with.

The hardest part? It was the feeling of…disconnect. Like, carrying this little person inside me, knowing I loved them already, but also knowing I couldn't keep them. It was like loving someone you knew you had to say goodbye to before you even met them.

And the guilt. Oh, the guilt. Even though I *knew* it was the right thing to do, even though I wanted the best for the baby, I still felt like I was failing somehow. Like I wasn't good enough. Like I was letting everyone down.

It was also weird, watching everyone else get all excited about the baby. Like, my parents were being supportive, but they were also…planning a nursery. And I was just sitting there, trying not to cry.

And then there was the waiting. Waiting for the right couple, waiting for the birth, waiting for the moment when I had to hand the baby over. It felt like my whole life was on hold.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best for the baby, even if that meant letting them go. And that was…the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

It still kinda stings, if I'm being honest. But I know I made the right decision. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand that too.

It's just…complicated. Okay? It's just really, really complicated.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was…intense. Like, aggressively holding a picture of a fetus. It was super awkward.

He kept yelling about how babies are "pre-born humans" and that abortion is "murder." He had a whole spiel about tiny fingers and toes and souls and stuff. It was a lot. And honestly, it wasn't helping anyone.

He kept trying to engage people in conversation, but mostly just got ignored. Which, honestly, was probably for the best. He was kinda scary.

I remember thinking, like, okay, dude, you're entitled to your opinion, but maybe yelling at people who are already having a really hard day isn't the most effective way to get your point across? Just a thought.

It was just…a really uncomfortable situation. And it made an already complicated day even more complicated. It's not like anyone there was *happy* about being there. It's not a fun decision, you know? And he just made it worse.

Honestly, I just wanted to get inside and get it over with. And avoid eye contact with the guy with the fetus picture. It was just…a lot.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It wasn't exactly a spa day, you know? It was…intense.

So, at the clinic, I mostly just tried to avoid eye contact with everyone. It's awkward enough knowing you're there, let alone having to explain it to strangers. But there were a couple of people I definitely noticed.

First, there was this woman, probably in her late twenties, early thirties. She was holding a little stuffed animal, and she was *crying*. Like, full-on sobbing. I tried to look away, but it was hard. She caught my eye and just…gave me this look. It wasn't judgmental, it was…sad. And understanding. She didn't say anything, just a little nod, like she knew exactly what I was going through. It was kinda creepy, honestly, but also…comforting?

Then there was this older guy, maybe in his fifties. He was sitting in the waiting room with his wife, and they were both looking really nervous. I overheard him saying something to her about "doing the right thing" and "it's for the best." It made me feel sick to my stomach, honestly. It reminded me of why I was there in the first place.

But the one that really stuck with me was this volunteer, a woman named Sandy. She was super nice, and she tried to make me feel comfortable. She handed me a magazine and said, "You're doing a brave thing, honey. A really brave thing."

And that just…broke me. I mean, I was trying to be all tough and sarcastic, but that comment just hit me right in the feels. I almost started crying right there in the waiting room.

She also said, "Whatever you decide, it's okay. You're okay." And that was…good to hear. Because at that point, I was feeling anything *but* okay.

It was just…a lot. A lot of emotions, a lot of awkwardness, and a lot of people going through their own stuff. It made me realize I wasn't alone, which was…something. But I still wanted to get out of there as quickly as possible.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on Su-Chin. That girl is…intense. And she has opinions. About everything.

So, yeah, I mentioned Adderall. It was at that diner, right? After we'd been talking about, like, how stressed everyone was about college and stuff. I just kinda blurted it out, about how some kids were using it to study. Just an observation, you know?

And her face. Oh. My. God. It was like I'd just confessed to robbing a bank. She went *completely* silent for a second, and then she just…stared at me. Like I'd grown a second head.

Then she launched into this whole thing about how it's a crutch and how people need to learn to cope with stress in healthy ways and how it's cheating and how it's ruining a generation. It was a lot. A *lot*.

She kept saying, "Juno, you're so smart, you don't *need* that stuff!" Which, okay, thanks, Su-Chin. But it wasn't about me needing it. It was just…an observation.

She was really judgmental about it. Like, she thought I was considering taking it or something. I tried to explain that I wasn't, but she just kept going. It was super awkward.

Honestly, it made me feel really uncomfortable. She has this way of making you feel like you're being interrogated. And it just felt…preachy. Like she had all the answers.

I think she was just really worried about everyone getting into good colleges. She puts a lot of pressure on herself, and she expects everyone else to do the same.

It was definitely a moment. And it kinda solidified my opinion of her, you know? She's smart, but she's also kinda…much.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot. It wasn't, like, a jump scare or anything. It was just…everything.

It was the magazines, mostly. All those pregnancy magazines. With the perfect moms and the perfect babies and the perfect nurseries. Like, who *lives* like that? It felt so…fake. And judgmental. Like I was already failing at being a mom and I hadn't even, you know, *had* the baby yet.

And then there were the people. All the couples, all beaming and excited. And me, sitting there, trying to look nonchalant while internally freaking out about giving a baby up for adoption. It felt like I was the only one who wasn't thrilled about the whole thing.

But the worst part was this one painting on the wall. It was a really cheesy painting of a baby with, like, huge, innocent eyes. And it just stared at me. Like it knew everything. Like it knew I was about to make a really big decision.

It wasn't the painting itself, it was what it *represented*. It was the weight of everything. The responsibility. The sadness. The uncertainty. It just hit me all at once, and I felt this wave of terror wash over me.

It wasn't a scary waiting room, exactly. It was just…a really *intense* waiting room. And I felt completely out of place. Like I was in a movie I hadn't auditioned for.

Ugh. I need a snack. And maybe a really loud song. Talking about it is making me feel all weird again.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been…a while. It's kinda embarrassing, honestly.

Look, Bleeker was…sweet. He was a good guy. And he was definitely the least intimidating person I knew, which was a plus at the time. He was just…there. A constant. Like a comfortable pair of shoes.

Do I still have *feelings* for him? That's a complicated question. It's not like I wake up every morning dreaming about him, okay? I've moved on. I have a life. I'm figuring things out.

But…there's a part of me that will always remember those late-night conversations, the music, the way he just…understood me. He didn't judge me for being weird or for being pregnant or for anything. He just accepted me for who I was.

And yeah, maybe there's a little bit of a "what if" lingering in the back of my mind. What if things had been different? What if I hadn't been so scared?

But honestly, I think we were both too young and too messed up to make it work. We needed to grow up and figure out who we were before we could be in a real relationship.

So, do I still have feelings for him? Maybe a little. But it's not the same kind of feelings I had before. It's more like…a fondness. A memory. A reminder of a simpler time.

And honestly, I'm okay with that. It's enough.



Can we talk about something else now? This is getting awkward.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa's decorating the nursery. Right. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not bad, exactly. It's just...not what I expected. At all.

She went full-on princess. Pink everywhere. Ruffles. A mobile with, like, a million little stuffed animals. It looks like a sugarplum fairy exploded in there. It's aggressively cheerful.

I mean, I appreciate the effort, I guess. She's really excited about being a mom, and she wants everything to be perfect. But it's a little overwhelming. It feels like it's for a doll, not a real human baby.

I tried to subtly suggest maybe toning it down a little. Like, "Maybe a little less pink?" or "Are you sure about the ruffles?" But she just gave me this look. You know the look. The "I'm-pregnant-and-emotional" look. So I backed off.

Honestly, it's not my room. It's hers and Mark's. And the baby's, eventually. I just hope the kid doesn't get completely overwhelmed by all the pink. Maybe I can sneak in a few black and white prints or something. Just to balance it out.

It's a little scary, thinking about bringing a baby into a room that looks like a birthday cake. But hey, maybe the baby will love it. And if not, we can always repaint. Eventually. After the hormones settle down.

It's just...a lot. Seriously. A lot.

Ugh. Nesting. Okay, so people keep talking about "nesting." Like I'm supposed to suddenly have this overwhelming urge to organize tiny socks and paint murals of woodland creatures. It's…weird.

Honestly? It feels kinda premature. Like, I'm still trying to figure out my own life, and now people expect me to create a miniature version of it? It's a lot.

And the baby room…it's cute, I guess. All the pastels and stuffed animals. But it also feels…distant. Like it's for someone else. It's hard to wrap my head around the fact that there's actually going to be a *baby* in there.

I mean, I'm not against preparing, exactly. I know it's responsible. And I appreciate people wanting to help. But I don't want it to feel like I'm pretending this is some perfect, idyllic situation. It's not. It's complicated.

I'm trying to focus on the practical stuff. Like, making sure we have a car seat and diapers and stuff. The fluffy stuff feels…less important.

Paul and Vanessa are really into it, which is good. They're doing a lot of the decorating. I'm mostly just trying to stay out of the way and not have a panic attack.

It's just…it's a lot to process. I'm giving a baby up for adoption. It's not exactly a Hallmark movie. So the whole "nesting" thing feels a little…off.

I guess I'll get there eventually. But right now, I'm just trying to take things one day at a time. And maybe avoid looking at baby clothes for a while. It's too much.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on those women at the mall. Seriously. It was…a whole *thing*. Like, a different planet.

It wasn't even the shopping, really. It was the *performance* of it. The way they carried themselves, like they were starring in their own personal movie. The perfectly coordinated outfits, the designer bags, the little yappy dogs in carriers…it was exhausting just watching them.

And the sales associates! They were practically bowing and scraping. It was like, "Yes, ma'am, this cashmere sweater is spun from the tears of unicorns and costs approximately a month's rent."

It just felt…disconnected. Like they weren't actually *enjoying* anything. It was all about status and appearances. Like, "Look at me, I can afford this ridiculously expensive thing."

I mean, I get wanting nice stuff. I'm not a total ascetic. But it felt so…empty. Like they were trying to fill a hole with handbags.

And the judgment! You could feel the judgment radiating off them. Like, if you weren't wearing the right shoes, you didn't belong. It was kinda intimidating, honestly.

It made me appreciate my thrift store finds even more. At least my stuff has a story. And it doesn't require me to take out a second mortgage.

It was a good reminder that money doesn't buy happiness. Or good taste, apparently. It just buys…more stuff. And a lot of stress, probably.

Honestly, it was a little depressing. I needed a grilled cheese and a copy of *The Catcher in the Rye* after that. It restored my faith in humanity, a little bit.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's…a lot. It's not what I expected, not even a little bit. I mean, I knew it was gonna be a big deal, obviously. But it's like, exponentially bigger than big.

Before, my biggest responsibility was, like, finishing my English assignment and avoiding Burnie. Now? It's keeping a tiny human alive. It's terrifying. And exhausting. And surprisingly…amazing.

The changes are insane. My body is completely different. My priorities are completely different. I used to spend my free time listening to The Moldy Peaches and eating tater tots. Now? I spend it changing diapers and trying to get five minutes of sleep. It's a trade-off.

And the responsibility? It's crushing sometimes. Knowing that this little person is completely dependent on me. It's a lot of pressure. I worry about everything. Am I doing enough? Am I messing her up? Is she gonna be okay?

But then she smiles. Or she grabs my finger. Or she just…exists. And it's like, all the worry and exhaustion melts away. And I realize that this is the most important thing I'll ever do.

It's not glamorous. It's not easy. It's messy and chaotic and overwhelming. But it's also the most rewarding thing I've ever experienced.

I'm still figuring it out, you know? I'm still trying to find my identity as a mom. I'm still trying to balance my own needs with the needs of my daughter. It's a work in progress.

But I'm learning. And I'm growing. And I'm realizing that motherhood isn't about losing yourself, it's about becoming someone new. Someone stronger. Someone more capable. Someone who can handle anything.

It's scary. But it's also…good. Really good. Even if I still have no idea what I'm doing.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about this, like it's some big, dramatic thing. It's not. Well, it is, but it's not like I'm picking a baby daddy or something. It's just...I want the kid to have a good life, you know? A *really* good life.

And I've been thinking about it a lot, and I realized I want the baby to go to someone who...gets it. Someone who isn't all about picket fences and perfect families. Someone who's a little bit different.

Mark and Vanessa, they're not, like, super traditional. Vanessa's a lawyer, she's career-focused, and Mark...well, Mark collects vintage Star Wars toys. They're not gonna try to mold the kid into something they're not. They seem cool with letting things just *be*.

I don't want the baby to grow up feeling like they have to fit into some pre-defined box. I want them to be free to be themselves, even if that means being a little weird. And I think Mark and Vanessa would get that.

Plus, they're financially stable and they seem genuinely excited about having a kid. Which is good. I want the baby to have everything they need.

It's not about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It's about finding parents who I think will be good for the baby. And right now, I think Mark and Vanessa are those parents.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. But I'm trying to do what's best for the kid. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay, so, hypothetically, if I decided to…keep the baby. Which, like, I haven't decided anything yet, okay? Just thinking out loud. But if I did…it would be a whole mess of stuff. A seriously huge mess.

First off, school. Like, hello? I'm a junior. I'm supposed to be thinking about colleges and stuff, not diaper changes and sleep deprivation. I'd probably have to drop out, or at least take a really long break. Which kinda messes up my whole plan.

Then there's the money thing. My dad's a good guy, but we're not exactly rolling in it. A baby is expensive. Like, ridiculously expensive. Diapers, formula, clothes, doctor's visits…it adds up fast. I'd probably have to get a job, which would mean even less time for school.

And then there's…everything else. My life. I like my life. I like hanging out with Leah, listening to The Moldy Peaches, and just being a normal teenager. A baby would change everything. It would be a constant responsibility, a constant worry.

My parents would be…disappointed. Not angry, probably, but definitely disappointed. They have plans for me. They want me to go to college and have a career. A baby doesn't exactly fit into that plan.

And then there's the whole…being a mom thing. I don't even know how to take care of a plant, let alone a human being. It's terrifying.

And, honestly, I'm not sure I'm ready for it. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. Adding a baby into the mix would just make everything even more complicated.

It's not that I don't think I could be a good mom. I think I could. But it's just…a really big decision. And it's a decision I have to make on my own.

It's a lot to think about. A *lot*. And it's kinda overwhelming.



So yeah, those are just some of the things. It's not a simple situation, okay? It's complicated. And scary. And I'm just trying to figure it all out.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She meant well, I guess. But she had this whole…vision. A very *Leah* vision.

When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she didn't just say "Okay, that's a good option." No. She launched into this whole thing about how we could, like, co-parent. 

She was all, "We could raise the baby together! We're young, we're creative, we can figure it out!" And she started talking about a yurt. A *yurt*, okay? Like we're gonna raise a baby in a portable felt tent.

She pictured us as this bohemian, free-spirited couple, raising a child in a totally unconventional way. It was…a lot. And honestly, terrifying. 

She kept saying it would be "an adventure." And I was like, "Leah, I'm sixteen. I'm barely equipped to handle high school, let alone a human being."

It wasn't a bad idea, exactly. Just…not realistic. And definitely not what I wanted. I needed to find a family who was ready and able to give the baby a stable, loving home. Not a yurt-dwelling, art-school dropout situation. No offense to art-school dropouts. But still.

Ugh, okay, let's talk about that. It was…not my finest moment, alright? And honestly, it's still kinda embarrassing to think about.

Look, I was a mess, okay? I was pregnant, I was scared, I was trying to act cool when I was totally freaking out inside. And those women…they were just so…*intense*. All matching outfits and perfectly coordinated snacks and talking about organic everything. It was like a Stepford Wives convention, but with more diaper bags.

I was projecting, I guess. I was jealous of their seeming…togetherness. I didn't have that. My life was a chaotic mess, and they looked like they had it all figured out. So I made a joke. A stupid, mean joke.

It wasn't cool. It wasn't funny. And I felt really bad about it afterwards. I realized I was just being a jerk because I was insecure.

Paul called me out on it, which was good. He's good at doing that. He made me see that I was being unfair and judgmental.

I'm not proud of it. I try to be a good person, but I mess up sometimes. I say things I don't mean. I act out. It's just…part of being a teenager, I guess. And part of being a human.

I learned a lesson from it, though. I learned that it's never okay to put other people down to make yourself feel better. And I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just be quiet and mind your own business.

So yeah, I made fun of those women. It was wrong. And I apologize for it. Even if they never hear me say it.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was…complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying, even now.

Look, Vanessa Loring is…intense. She's got a lot of feelings, okay? And she was going through a lot herself. She was really excited about the baby, and she wanted to connect with it, with *me*, I guess.

I wasn't exactly thinking straight at the time. I was overwhelmed, and honestly, a little lonely. Paul was being…Paul. And I was trying to be cool and accommodating, and I just…froze. I didn't know how to say no.

It wasn't like I *wanted* her to touch my belly. It just…happened. It was awkward and weird and I definitely regretted it immediately afterwards. 

It was a boundary thing, I guess. I hadn't really established clear boundaries with her, and she just kind of…overstepped. And I let her.

I was trying to be a good person, trying to be understanding, but I should have spoken up. I should have said, "Hey, that's not okay."

It was a learning experience, I guess. A really uncomfortable learning experience. It taught me that it's okay to say no, even to people you care about. And that sometimes, you have to protect yourself, even if it means hurting someone's feelings.

So yeah, that happened. And I'm not proud of it. But it's part of my story. And it made me stronger, I think. In a weird, roundabout way.

Can we talk about something else now? Please?

Ugh, seriously? You noticed that too? It's…a thing. It's like, people see the bump and suddenly develop a pathological need to be polite. It's weird.

It's not like I'm royalty or something. I'm just a girl with a baby in her stomach. But people will literally *move* out of the way. Hold doors open for me. Offer me their seat on the bus. It's like I've suddenly become fragile or something.

I think it's because they're trying to be nice. They see a pregnant person and their brains just short-circuit into "protect the precious cargo" mode. Which is…sweet, I guess. But also kinda patronizing.

It's like they assume I'm incapable of navigating the world on my own. Like I'm gonna trip and fall and the baby's gonna fly out. Which, obviously, isn't gonna happen.

And it's not just strangers. It's people I know too. Like, my dad suddenly started walking five feet behind me whenever we go anywhere. It's suffocating.

I appreciate the concern, I really do. But I'm still me. I can still walk. I can still open doors. I can still handle myself. I just happen to be carrying a tiny human.

It's a weird side effect of being pregnant, I guess. People treat you differently. It's like you're suddenly a delicate flower instead of a sarcastic, independent teenager. It's…confusing.



Honestly, sometimes I just want to yell, "I'm okay! I got this!" But then I remember I'm pregnant and yelling might not be the best idea. So I just smile and let them hold the door. It's easier that way.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa. The "wholesome" couple. Like they're some kind of perfect Stepford parents. And yeah, on paper, they *are* perfect. They have the house, the jobs, the golden retriever…the whole nine yards.

But that's kinda the problem, you know? It's too…perfect. It feels…sterile. Like a show home.

It's not that I don't think they'd be good parents. They absolutely would. They'd give the baby everything it needs. But I worry about what the baby would *lose*.

They're so…planned. Everything is organized and scheduled and thought out. And babies aren't like that. They're messy and unpredictable and they throw up a lot. I just don't know if they're ready for the chaos.

And honestly? I kinda want the baby to have a little bit of…edge. A little bit of weirdness. A little bit of real life. Mark and Vanessa seem like they want to mold the baby into something perfect, instead of letting it be itself.

Paul and Annie, they're…messy. They're flawed. They're real. They've got a record collection and a dog that sheds everywhere and they argue about stupid stuff. But they love each other, and they'd love the baby unconditionally, even if it's not perfect.

I want the baby to be loved, obviously. But I also want it to be *seen*. To be accepted for who it is, not for who someone wants it to be.

It's not about finding the "best" parents. It's about finding the right parents. And right now, I think that's Paul and Annie. Even if they're not as…wholesome.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. And everyone keeps telling me I'm overthinking it, but I can't help it. This is a baby's life we're talking about.

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot. Like, a whole *situation*.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, at first I thought Vanessa was kinda cool. She was all, like, earthy and granola and really into having a baby. And Mark seemed…okay. A little clueless, maybe, but harmless.

But then you start to realize they're both kinda using each other. Vanessa wants a baby, like, *yesterday*, and Mark just wants to be a dad to prove something to himself. It's not exactly a solid foundation for a relationship, you know?

And the way they talk about the adoption…it feels weird. Like it's about *them* and what *they* want, not about the baby. It's not like they're bad people, exactly. They're just…self-absorbed.

I feel bad for them, honestly. They're both trying so hard to be happy, but they're going about it in a really messed up way. They think having a baby is gonna fix everything, but it's not that simple.

I guess what I'm saying is, they're complicated. And I'm not sure they're ready to be parents. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a pregnant teenager. I'm not exactly an expert on relationships.

It's just…they make me nervous. Like, I hope they really think this through. Because a baby deserves parents who are actually ready for it, you know? Not just people who want to fill a void in their lives.

So yeah. That's how I feel about Mark and Vanessa. They're…a work in progress. A very messy work in progress.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about Vanessa? Bleeker's mom? Yeah, that was…a situation. Honestly, it wasn't a mystery, really. She just had a very specific idea of who Bleeker should be with, and I definitely didn't fit the bill.

It wasn't that she thought I was a *bad* person, exactly. It was more that I was…not polished enough. Not "country club" enough. She wanted him with someone who went to a fancy prep school and had a trust fund and knew how to properly arrange flowers or whatever. Someone who fit into her perfect little world.

I was…well, I was me. A little rough around the edges, a little sarcastic, a little bit of a mess. And pregnant. Which, let's be real, didn't exactly scream "ideal wife material" in her book.

She thought I was holding Bleeker back. That I was distracting him from his potential. She kept making these little comments about how he was "so talented" and how he needed to "focus on his music" and how I was just…a distraction.

It was annoying, to say the least. And honestly, it hurt Bleeker too. He was really torn between wanting to please his mom and wanting to be with me.

But he chose me. And that's what mattered. Vanessa eventually came around, a little bit. She saw that I genuinely cared about Bleeker and that I was trying to do what was best for him and the baby. But she never fully approved. And honestly? I didn't really care. I didn't need her approval. I had Bleeker, and that was enough.

It just goes to show, some people are just never going to understand. And you can't waste your time trying to convince them otherwise. You just gotta do your own thing and be happy. Even if it means dealing with a slightly judgmental mother-in-law.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the CD? It's…complicated. It wasn't like, instant love or anything. It sat on my dresser for a while, just…existing. A little plastic rectangle of awkwardness.

Honestly, I was avoiding it. It felt like…too much. Mark was sweet, don't get me wrong. But he was also kinda intense. And the whole thing felt really fast, you know? Like, he was trying to express all his feelings through a carefully curated playlist. It was a lot of pressure.

But then…I was just feeling really…blah. Everything with the baby and Paul and everything was just kinda weighing me down. I was sitting on my bed, staring at the ceiling, and I just needed something to distract me. Something to…feel.

So I put it on. And it wasn't what I expected. It wasn't all sappy love songs. There was The Moldy Peaches, which, okay, that was a good sign. And some other stuff I actually liked. It was…thoughtful.

It was like he was trying to show me who *he* was, not just what he wanted from me. And it was kinda…sweet. It made me realize he wasn't just some clueless guy who got me pregnant. He was a person. A weird, slightly awkward person, but a person nonetheless.

So yeah, that's what made me listen to it. I was bored, and I was curious. And it turned out to be…okay. More than okay, actually. It was a little window into his world. And it helped me see him in a different light.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get all smug.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Eight months. It's…a lot. It's like, I used to be able to just *exist* in my body, you know? Now it feels like there's a tiny, demanding roommate who's constantly kicking me and rearranging my internal organs.

It's weird. It's uncomfortable. It's exhausting. And it's kinda terrifying. Like, I'm about to be responsible for a whole human being. A tiny, screaming, poop-machine human being.

I get winded walking up the stairs. I can't reach my toes anymore. And my ankles are swollen like balloons. It's not exactly glamorous.

But…it's also kinda amazing. Like, I can feel him move. And sometimes, when he kicks, it feels…good. It's a weird, fluttery feeling. And it reminds me that there's a little person in there, waiting to meet the world.

I'm still figuring out all the feelings. It's not like in the movies, where everything is all warm and fuzzy. It's complicated. I'm excited, and scared, and overwhelmed, and…a little bit sad, because I'm giving him up.

But I'm also trying to focus on the good stuff. I'm trying to prepare myself. And I'm trying to accept that my life is about to change in a big way.

So, how does it feel? It feels…big. And heavy. And weird. And kinda wonderful. It's a lot to process, okay? Don't make me talk about it anymore. I need a nap. And maybe a pickle. Seriously, pickles are a lifesaver right now.

Ugh, seriously? You noticed too, huh? It's a thing. It *always* happens. I swear, people treat me like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo.

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in, okay? I have opinions. And I'm not afraid to share them. Loudly. And I dress how *I* want to dress, not how other people think I should. Which apparently is a crime against fashion.

And then there's the whole…situation. You know. The baby thing. People are always curious. They want to know the story. They want to judge. They want to whisper. It's annoying.

I think some people are just surprised that I'm, like, a normal person. They expect me to be all dramatic and emotional, but I'm just trying to get through the day without completely falling apart.

And honestly, some people are probably just staring because I'm kinda weird. I get it. I'm not exactly conventional.

But whatever the reason, it's rude. And it makes me want to glare back. But I usually just roll my eyes and keep walking. It's less effort.

It's like, can't people just mind their own business? It's not that hard. But noooo, they have to stare. It's exhausting.

So yeah, that's why people stare. It's a complicated answer to a simple question. And it's mostly just annoying.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek, okay? He deserves to have someone to go to prom with. He's a good kid. A little…intense, maybe. But good. And Katrina's…Katrina. She's got her thing going on. She's definitely…confident.

But those two together? It's like pairing a goldfish with a shark. They just operate on completely different levels. He's all quiet and sensitive and into fantasy stuff, and she's…well, she's Katrina. She's got a whole *vibe* going on that I'm not entirely sure Bleek understands.

I'm not saying it's a bad idea, exactly. Maybe opposites attract, or whatever. But I have a feeling Bleek is going to spend the entire night trying to figure out what she's thinking, and she's going to be bored out of her mind.

It's gonna be…interesting, to say the least. I'm just picturing a lot of awkward silences and Katrina rolling her eyes. 

Honestly, I'm mostly worried about Bleek getting his feelings hurt. He's a sweet guy, and he doesn't deserve that. But hey, maybe I'm wrong. Maybe they'll have a blast. Maybe Katrina will discover her hidden love for Dungeons & Dragons. 

Stranger things have happened. Especially when you're a teenager. It's all just…a mess. A beautiful, complicated mess. And I'm just here to observe the chaos.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Like, existential crisis deep. Honestly, before all this happened, I thought I had things pretty figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, and perfectly content being a little bit of a loner. I thought I was…tough.

But being pregnant? It kinda shattered all that. It forced me to actually *feel* things, you know? Not just observe them and make a witty comment. It was terrifying, and confusing, and…surprisingly emotional.

I learned that I'm way more capable than I thought I was. Like, I'm making a huge decision, giving a baby up for adoption, and it's the hardest thing I've ever done. But I'm doing it because it's the right thing. And that takes guts.

I also learned that I'm not as self-sufficient as I pretended to be. I needed help. From my dad, from Paul, from Vanessa. And it was okay to ask for it. It was actually…good.

And I learned that I'm not afraid to be vulnerable. I used to hide behind my sarcasm and my attitude, but this whole thing has forced me to open up and let people see who I really am. It's scary, but it's also…liberating.

I guess what I've learned is that I'm a lot more complex than I thought I was. I'm not just a sarcastic teenager. I'm a person with feelings and dreams and the capacity for great love. And I'm figuring things out as I go.

It's still kinda scary, not knowing what the future holds. But I'm okay with that. I'm learning to trust myself and to believe that everything will work out the way it's supposed to. Even if it's not the way I expected.

So yeah. That's what I've learned. I'm a work in progress. And that's okay.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about Bleeker and Katrina? It's…complicated. It's not like I *like* Bleeker, okay? He's kinda a dork. But even *I* can see he's messing with Katrina's head.

Look, Katrina's a good person. She's…intense, yeah, and maybe a little bit dramatic, but she's got a good heart. And she deserves someone who actually *likes* her, not someone who just likes the idea of having a girlfriend.

Bleeker's all, "Oh, I'm so sensitive and misunderstood," but he's just using that as an excuse to be a jerk. He's leading her on, making her think there's something there when there isn't. It's manipulative, and it's not cool.

I've been through enough emotional stuff lately to know when someone's getting played. And Katrina doesn't need that. She's already dealing with a lot. She doesn't need some clueless guy making things worse.

Plus, it's just…annoying. Like, can't he see he's hurting her? It's so obvious. It makes me want to yell at him. But I'm trying to be mature and not interfere. Mostly.

It's just…I want her to be happy. And Bleeker is not the way to happiness. He's a distraction. A bad one. And she deserves better than a distraction. She deserves someone who actually *gets* her.

So yeah, that's why I'm concerned. It's not about me liking Bleeker or not. It's about Katrina being treated with respect. And he's not doing that. It's just…ugh. Boys. They're all the same.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so you're finally old enough to go, and suddenly it's...lame? Yeah, I get it. It's a total bait-and-switch.

When you're little, prom is this magical thing. Like, in movies, it's always this perfect night with a perfect dress and a perfect date and everything just *works*. But then you actually get to high school, and you realize it's just a really expensive dance thrown in a gym decorated with streamers.

It's like, everyone's trying so hard to make it look like it's a big deal, but it's all so…forced. Everyone's stressing about dresses and dates and who's going with who, and it's just a lot of pressure for something that's ultimately kinda pointless.

And honestly, once you're old enough to actually *go* to prom, you've probably already figured out that life isn't like the movies. It's messy and complicated and things don't always work out the way you plan. So, the idea of trying to create this perfect, fairytale night just feels…fake.

Plus, by the time you're a senior, you're probably already thinking about what you're going to do after graduation. College, jobs, moving out…prom just feels like a distraction from the real stuff.

It's like, you've outgrown it. It's a thing for younger kids who still believe in magic. And you're too cool for magic now. Or at least, you're trying to be.

Don't get me wrong, if you want to go to prom, go to prom. But don't feel like you *have* to. It's not the be-all and end-all of high school. There's a whole world out there waiting for you, and it's a lot more interesting than a dance in a gym.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. Even though it happened a while ago. It's not like it's a story I *love* retelling, but I get why you'd ask. It was a big decision. The biggest, probably.

It wasn't, like, a snap decision. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot of thinking. A lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa. A lot of just…feeling really overwhelmed.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were trying, but they weren't exactly equipped to handle a baby either.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him. Or her. I didn't even know what it was at first.

Vanessa and Mark…they were perfect. They were older, stable, they had a house and a garden and they were just…ready. They were genuinely excited. And that made it easier. Knowing that the baby would be loved and cared for.

It was still hard. Really hard. Saying goodbye was…the worst. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For everyone.

People kept asking me if I regretted it. And I don't. Not really. It was a tough choice, but it was *my* choice. And I stand by it.

It taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About what it means to be a grown-up. And it taught me that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is let go.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. And that's all that really matters.

It's…complicated. And I don't really like talking about it too much. But you asked. And I figured I owed you the honest truth.

Ugh, my dad. He means well, okay? He really does. But sometimes he just…overthinks things. Like, a lot. And the whole "getting ripped off" thing? Seriously? It's not a car sale, Dad. It's a baby.

It's not like I'm just handing over a toaster oven. I'm choosing a family for my kid. And I've done a lot of thinking about it. A *lot*. And Mark and Vanessa? They seem…good. Really good. They're excited, they're prepared, and they actually seem to get what I'm going through.

But my dad, he's all, "What if they change their minds? What if they're secretly awful people? What if they don't give the baby a good life?" It's exhausting. Like, I get it, he's protective. But it feels like he doesn't trust my judgment.

And honestly, it's kinda insulting. I'm not stupid. I'm not just blindly handing my baby over to the first people who offer to take him. I've thought this through. I've talked to counselors. I've done my research.

I know it's scary for him. It's scary for me too, okay? But I have to trust my instincts. And I have a good feeling about Mark and Vanessa.

So yeah, I appreciate his concern, I guess. But I also wish he'd just…chill out a little. It's my decision, and I'm trying to make the best one for everyone involved. Including the baby. And sometimes, that means letting go and trusting that things will work out. Even if it's not exactly how my dad would have planned it.

Ugh. Seriously? My dad. Always with the insightful commentary. "You don't know when to say when," he says. Like it's some profound observation about my personality. It's just...annoying.

It's not that I *don't* know when to say when. It's that I have a hard time backing down from a challenge. Or, like, a really good cheeseburger. Or a conversation I'm winning. It's a principle.

And honestly, it's kinda rich coming from *him*. He's the one who's always building stuff, always taking on new projects, always trying to fix everything. He's a fixer-upper, both literally and figuratively.

But I guess he's right, in a way. I do tend to get...enthusiastic. And maybe I don't always think things through. But that's part of who I am. I'm impulsive. I'm opinionated. I'm a little bit of a mess.

And I'm okay with that.

It's just...sometimes I wish he'd just let me be me, you know? Without all the unsolicited advice. But that's my dad. He means well. He just has a really weird way of showing it.

So, yeah. My reaction? Mostly eye-rolling. And a sarcastic comment under my breath. It's my default setting. What can I say? I'm a work in progress. And apparently, I don't know when to stop working on it. Go figure.

Ugh, Loring. Seriously? That place is…a lot. It's like Stepford Wives meets Architectural Digest. Everything is perfectly manicured and everyone pretends to be super happy. It's kinda creepy, honestly.

It's not that I have anything against nice houses or well-maintained lawns, okay? It's just…it feels so *artificial*. Like, people are trying so hard to project this perfect image, and it's exhausting just being around it.

And the gates? The *gates*! Like they're protecting themselves from…what? Reality? It's so isolating. It feels like they're trying to build a bubble around themselves and pretend the rest of the world doesn't exist.

It's just…not real. It's not how people actually live. It's all surface and no substance. And I'm not about that. I prefer a little bit of messiness, a little bit of imperfection. It feels more…honest.

Plus, it's kinda judgy. You can just *feel* the side-eye when you drive through there in a beat-up Volvo. Like, "Oh look, someone who doesn't have a perfectly symmetrical rose garden."

I mean, Mark and Vanessa seem happy there, and that's good. But it's just…not my vibe. I need a little bit of grit, a little bit of chaos. I need to be around people who are real, you know? Not people who are trying to be perfect.

It's a nice place, I guess. If you're into that sort of thing. But it's definitely not my cup of tea. I'd rather hang out in a dive bar with a bunch of interesting people than sip chamomile tea in a perfectly landscaped garden. Just sayin'.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, *really* put-together. And not in a cool, effortless way. More in a…everything-has-a-place-and-a-schedule way. Which, coming from my life, was kinda jarring.

She was all perfectly coordinated outfits and polite small talk. And she was *so* eager. Like, overly eager to be a mom. Which, okay, good for her, but it felt…a little weird, you know? Like she was already planning the baby's college fund before I even knew if I was keeping it.

I remember thinking she looked like a catalog model. Which isn't a bad thing, I guess, but it just felt…distant. Like she wasn't a real person. More like an idea of a perfect mom.

And she kept asking me about my plans for the future. Like, what college I wanted to go to, what I wanted to *do* with my life. Which, hello? I was sixteen and pregnant! I hadn't even figured out what I wanted for *lunch* yet.

I wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole adoption thing to begin with, and she just seemed to amplify all my anxieties. She wasn't *bad*, exactly. Just…a lot. A lot to process.

It took me a while to see past the perfect exterior and realize she was actually a pretty decent person. But those first few meetings? Yeah, she definitely gave off some serious Stepford Wife vibes. It was intimidating, to say the least.

Ugh. Okay, so Bleeker offering to carry my backpack. Right. That was…a moment.

Honestly? It was kinda sweet. I mean, Bleeker is…Bleeker. He's not exactly known for his suave moves or his confidence. He's more of a quiet, awkward, guitar-playing kinda guy. So him offering to carry my backpack, which, let's be real, was probably weighing me down more emotionally than physically, was…unexpected.

It wasn't like a grand romantic gesture or anything. It wasn't like he was trying to be my knight in shining armor. It was just…a nice thing to do. A small act of kindness. And I appreciated it.

I think I probably made a sarcastic comment in response, because that's kinda my default setting. Something like, "Oh, are you sure you can handle it, Captain Muscles?" But inside, I was…flustered. A little bit.

It made me realize that he actually *noticed* me. Not just as the pregnant girl, but as…a person. And that he was willing to help, even if it meant looking a little goofy.

It wasn't a turning point or anything, but it was definitely a little moment that made me see him in a different light. It was a reminder that sometimes, the quietest people have the biggest hearts.

And yeah, my backpack *was* really heavy. So, thanks, Bleeker. Seriously. Even if I didn't say it at the time.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about that? It's kinda embarrassing to talk about, honestly. But fine.

It wasn't just the comic itself, okay? It was…the *honesty* of it. Yuki, she wasn't trying to be, like, supermodel perfect or anything. She was just…herself. And she was happy. And she was drawing these really weird, kinda gross, but also really beautiful comics about her life.

I was at this point where I was just…existing. Trying to be invisible. And I was really hung up on my body, you know? Thinking I was a "fat dork" and all that. But Yuki, she didn't seem to care what anyone thought. She was just creating.

And it made me realize that maybe…maybe it didn't matter what I looked like. Maybe what mattered was what I *did*. What I created. What I thought. 

It wasn't like, suddenly I loved my body or anything. It was more like…I stopped hating it so much. I stopped letting it define me. 

It was a small thing, but it was a turning point. It made me feel…less alone. Less like I had to fit into some stupid mold. It made me feel like maybe, just maybe, it was okay to be me. Even if "me" was a little bit weird and a little bit awkward and a little bit…bigger than some other people.

It was just…a good comic. And sometimes, that's all you need. A little bit of art to make you feel a little bit less awful. Don't judge. It's a complicated time to be a teenager.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about that whole superhero thing with Mark and the comic book? Seriously? It was mortifying. Like, peak mortification.

Look, Mark is…well, Mark. He's sweet, but he's also kinda clueless. And he has a really weird way of showing he likes you. Comparing me to a pregnant superhero? Not exactly smooth, you know?

I think…I think he meant it as a compliment. Like, she was strong and brave and doing something amazing, even though it was scary. And he probably thought I was being strong and brave too, dealing with…everything.

But it was still weird. I mean, she had superpowers and a cool costume. I have morning sickness and a growing belly. It's not exactly the same thing.

And honestly, it felt kinda objectifying. Like he was focusing on the pregnancy instead of, you know, *me*. It's like he saw me as this vessel for a baby, instead of a person with feelings and opinions.

He tried to explain it later, said he was just trying to say I was "super." But it just came off as…awkward. Really awkward.

I think he just doesn't always think things through. He's a good guy, but he's not exactly the most articulate. And he definitely has a thing for comic books.

So yeah, that's why I think he said it. He was trying to be nice, but he totally missed the mark. Get it? Missed the mark? Because it was a bad comparison? Never mind. It's not funny. It was just…weird.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And kinda heavy. People keep asking me about adoption, and honestly, it's not something I thought a lot about before, you know? It's just…what I'm doing.

So, open adoption. People keep talking about it. Like, keeping in touch with the birth parents, regular visits, sending pictures… It sounds…nice, I guess. For *them*. But it also sounds like a whole lot of extra emotional baggage. And honestly, I'm already carrying enough of that, thank you very much.

Look, I get the idea. The birth mom gets to see the baby grow up, know it's okay, and the kid knows where they came from. It sounds all warm and fuzzy and…perfect. But perfect isn't real. And I'm pretty sure it would just make things harder for everyone involved.

For me, and for the baby, I think a traditional, closed adoption is better. It gives everyone a clean break. It allows the adoptive parents – Mark and Vanessa – to be the *real* parents, without having to worry about another woman constantly being in the picture. And it allows me to…move on.

It's not that I don't care about the baby. I do. A lot. But I'm not equipped to be a mom right now. I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, let alone raise a kid. And I don't want to be a constant reminder of a difficult decision.

I want the baby to have a stable, loving home, and I want Mark and Vanessa to be able to fully embrace that role. I want them to be a family, without any complications.

It's not about being selfish. It's about doing what's best for the baby. And for me. And I think a closed adoption gives us all the best chance at a happy future.

It's not easy, okay? It's a really hard decision. But it's the one I've made. And I'm trying to be okay with it. It's just…sometimes it feels like I'm giving away a piece of myself. But I know it's the right thing to do.



It's just…ugh. Can we talk about something else now? This is making me feel all weird and emotional.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it a lot. It's kinda hard to *not* think about it when your life is basically a movie.

Before everything happened with Paul and the baby, I was just… drifting. I was good at observing people, making sarcastic comments, and avoiding anything that felt too real. I was kinda hiding, I guess. I didn't really know what I wanted, or who I was supposed to be. I just knew I didn't want to end up like my mom, you know? Stuck and…sad.

But getting pregnant? That was a wake-up call. It forced me to actually *think* about the future, about responsibility, about what I wanted out of life. It wasn't about avoiding things anymore. It was about making a really big decision.

And choosing to give the baby up for adoption? That wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it wasn't about giving something *up*. It was about giving something *to* someone who could give it the life it deserved. And realizing that I could make that selfless choice, that I could put someone else's needs before my own…that was when I started to feel strong.

It wasn't about being a mom, it was about being a good person.

And then, hanging out with Mark and Vanessa, seeing how much they wanted this baby, how much love they had to give…it showed me that there are different kinds of families. And that love is what really matters.

I think, before all this, I was trying to be cool, trying to be someone other people would like. But through everything, I realized it's okay to be me. Quirky, sarcastic, a little bit awkward me. I don't need to fit into anyone else's mold.

So yeah, the journey was messy and complicated and kinda terrifying. But it forced me to grow up, to face my fears, and to figure out what I really believe in. And it showed me that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm okay with that. I'm Juno MacGuff, and I'm just trying to navigate this crazy life the best I can. And that's enough.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the prom. Seriously? It's been, like, forever. And it's still kinda awkward to think about. But fine, I'll tell you.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know, super cliché. But it felt…right. It wasn't, like, a super upbeat dance song or anything. It was kinda quiet and sweet and a little bit sad. Which, honestly, pretty much sums up my life at that point.

Mark picked it. He said it reminded him of me. I didn't ask why. I didn't *want* to know why.

It was a really weird night. I mean, I was pregnant, he was a senior, and we were trying to pretend everything was normal. It wasn't normal. But for a few minutes, when we were dancing to that song, it felt…okay.

It's a good song, though. Even if it does remind me of all the complicated stuff that happened. Don't tell anyone I said that. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be all sarcastic and detached. But sometimes, even I get a little sentimental. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing people ask me about. Like, it wasn't a simple decision, alright? It wasn't like I was picking a flavor of ice cream.

Look, Mark was a good guy. Seriously. Sweet, kinda clueless, but good. And Vanessa…Vanessa was put together. She had her life planned out. She was stable. And that baby needed stability.

Mark leaving Vanessa wouldn't have magically solved anything. It would have just created more chaos. He wasn't ready to be a dad, and Vanessa deserved someone who *was*. It wasn't about punishing either of them, it was about what was best for the kid.

I saw how much Vanessa wanted a baby. And I saw how much Mark cared about her. They weren't perfect, but they were a team. And I figured, if anyone could give that baby a good life, it was them.

It wasn't about me wanting to break up their relationship. It was about me wanting to give my baby the best possible chance. And that meant finding parents who were already a unit, who were already prepared to be a family.

Plus, let's be real, Mark and Vanessa had a house. And money. And health insurance. I was a sixteen-year-old with a part-time job at a Pear Burger. I wasn't exactly equipped to raise a baby.

It was a hard decision, okay? It still kinda stings sometimes. But I truly believe it was the right one. And I still keep in touch with them. The baby – her name is Charlotte, by the way – is doing great. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for *her*. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Even when it hurts like hell.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark. Seriously. It was…a lot. Like, a whole mess of feelings all at once.

At first, it was just…shock. I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly Mr. Responsibility, but I kinda thought, you know, maybe this would *make* him responsible. Like, a switch would flip and he'd suddenly be all mature and stuff. Stupid, I know.

Then it was anger. A lot of anger. Like, how could he just say that? After everything? It wasn't just about him, it was about the baby. And me. And the fact that I was already kinda figuring out a whole life plan, and he just…dismissed it.

But underneath the anger, there was this…sadness. A really deep, hollow sadness. Because I kinda liked him. And I thought maybe, just maybe, we could make it work. But he wasn't willing to try. He wasn't willing to step up.

It was also kinda…relieving, in a weird way. Because I realized I didn't *need* him. I could do this on my own. I could find a good family for the baby, and I could figure out my own life.

It was just…complicated. It made me realize that sometimes, people aren't who you think they are. And that sometimes, you have to make tough decisions, even if they hurt.

I mean, I wasn't exactly thrilled about giving the baby up for adoption, but I knew it was the right thing to do. And Mark's reaction just solidified that. It showed me that he wasn't ready to be a parent, and that the baby deserved someone who was.

So yeah. It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it also made me stronger. And it helped me figure out what I wanted out of life. Which, honestly, is more than I can say for Mark.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to analyze my feelings about Mark? Seriously? It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. But fine.

It wasn't like I was *looking* for a friend, you know? I was pretty content being a sarcastic observer of the world. But Mark…he was just…different. Everyone else at school was all about cliques and drama and trying to be cool. Mark didn't care about any of that. He collected vintage records and built robots and just generally lived in his own little world.

And it was a *weird* world, yeah. A really weird world. But it was…genuine. He wasn't trying to impress anyone. He was just being himself. And that was kinda refreshing.

I think I liked that he saw me, too. Not just the pregnant teenager everyone was whispering about. He saw me as…Juno. The girl who liked music and movies and making sarcastic comments. He didn't judge me for my choices, even when they were kinda questionable.

He was also just…funny. In a quiet, awkward, kinda endearing way. He didn't try to be funny, he just *was*. And he got my sense of humor, which is a rare find.

And honestly, I think I needed someone to just…be there. Someone who wasn't my parents or my best friend, Leah. Someone who wasn't involved in the whole baby situation. Someone who just saw me as a person.

So yeah, I liked being a part of his weird life. It was a distraction, sure. But it was also…nice. He was a good friend. And he reminded me that it was okay to be different. That it was okay to be yourself, even if yourself was a little bit messy and complicated.

It was a good thing, that friendship. A really good thing. Even if it was kinda weird.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, trying to get inside his head is…a project. He's not exactly an open book, you know? He's more of a…chapter with a lot of blank pages.

But I've been observing. A lot. And I think he's mostly terrified. Like, genuinely, pants-wettingly scared. He's always been kinda…chill. Go-with-the-flow. And this is the opposite of go-with-the-flow. This is a life-altering, responsibility-inducing, diaper-changing situation.

I think he wants to be a good dad. He really does. He's got a good heart. But he's also worried he'll mess it up. He's worried he won't be able to provide, or that he'll be a bad influence, or that he'll just…fail.

He's trying to be supportive of me, which is sweet, but he's also kinda just…processing. He keeps asking me practical questions, like about health insurance and baby gear. It's his way of trying to feel in control, I think.

And I think he's also a little bit excited. Deep down. He's never really had anything to take care of before, and maybe he's looking forward to that. To having a little person who needs him.

But mostly? Mostly, I think he's just really, really scared. And trying not to show it. He's good at that, you know? Being stoic. It's kinda his thing.

He's a good guy, though. He'll figure it out. We both will. It's just gonna be…a process. A messy, complicated, terrifying, and hopefully, ultimately rewarding process.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment. Don't judge me.

Look, everything was just…a lot. I was, you know, pregnant. And dealing with Paul and Mark and my dad and everything. And I was at Loring's, which is basically the fanciest store in town, and everything smelled amazing. And I just…wanted something nice. Something that smelled good. Something that wasn't, like, baby powder and regret.

It wasn't about the perfume itself, okay? It was about wanting something for *me*. Something that made me feel…pretty. And normal. And not like a walking, talking baby factory.

I know it was wrong. Stealing is wrong. I got called out on it, obviously. By Loring himself. It was mortifying. But it was also…a release. Like, a tiny act of rebellion. A way of saying, "I'm still here. I'm still me."

It was stupid. I know it was stupid. But it happened. And honestly, it's a good story now. A cautionary tale about the dangers of hormonal imbalances and expensive perfume.

Don't make a big deal out of it, okay? It's not like I robbed a bank. It was a little bottle of perfume. And I learned my lesson. Mostly.



It's just…sometimes you need a little something to make you feel better, even if it's a really bad idea. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on Mark and Vanessa? Honestly, it's kinda sad. And complicated. But I've been observing people for, like, eighteen years now, and I've learned a thing or two about relationships.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's…stuck. He's always been the responsible one, the provider, the guy who keeps everything together. And Vanessa? She's just…free-spirited. She does her own thing, she follows her passions, and she doesn't really seem to care about what anyone else thinks.

And at first, that was probably attractive to him. She was different. She challenged him. But over time, I think he started to feel suffocated by her lack of…structure. He wants a partner who's on the same page as him, who shares his values, who wants the same things out of life. And Vanessa just doesn't.

He's always trying to *fix* her, you know? Trying to get her to be more "normal" or "responsible." And she just resists. She doesn't *want* to be fixed. She's happy being who she is.

And I think he's realized that he can't change her. And he's also realized that he doesn't want to spend the rest of his life trying. He wants someone who accepts him for who he is, too.

It's not that they don't love each other, I think. It's just that they're fundamentally different people. And sometimes, that's enough. It's like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. It just doesn't work.

It's a bummer, but sometimes people just grow apart. And it's better to admit that and move on than to stay in a relationship that's making both of them unhappy.

It's kinda like…me and Paul. We're good friends, and we care about each other, but we're not meant to be together. And that's okay. Sometimes, that's just how it is.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff, huh? Fine. Look, it wasn't about Vanessa, exactly. It was about…everything.

She was being nice, which is always suspicious. And she was asking what was wrong, and I just…couldn't. I couldn't explain it. Not then. Not to anyone.

It wasn't just about Paul being kinda clueless and me realizing I maybe didn't feel the same way about him anymore. It was about everything being so messy and complicated. I was pregnant, for crying out loud! And I was trying to figure out what to do with my life, and whether I even *had* a life to figure out.

And Vanessa, she's…together. She has a plan. She knows what she wants. And I just felt like a total mess next to her. Like I was falling apart and she was perfectly put together.

So, yeah, I bolted. It was a classic Juno move. Avoid the feelings, run away from the situation, pretend everything is fine. It's not healthy, I know. But it's what I do.

It's easier to just disappear than to try and explain all the stuff that's going on inside my head. It's a defense mechanism, okay? I build walls. It's how I cope.

And honestly, I just needed to get out of there. I needed to breathe. I needed to think. And I definitely didn't need Vanessa's pity.

So, yeah, I rushed out. Don't judge me. It was a moment of weakness. A moment of total, complete Juno-ness.

Ugh. Vanessa. She's…optimistic. To a fault. Like, aggressively optimistic. It's kinda exhausting just being *around* it sometimes.

Look, I get it. She loves Mark. And she wants this to work. She wants the whole picture, the white picket fence, the 2.5 kids, the golden retriever. The whole shebang. But Mark? He's…Mark.

He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely not ready to change a diaper. He's still figuring out how to change his own life, let alone someone else's.

And Vanessa thinking he'll just *eventually* grow into it? That's…naive. People don't just magically become responsible adults. It takes work. It takes wanting it. And I don't think Mark *wants* it. Not right now. Maybe not ever.

She's clinging to this idea of who she *wants* him to be, instead of accepting who he *is*. And that's just setting herself up for heartbreak.

It's not about him being a bad person. It's about him not being ready. And you can't force someone to be ready. You just can't.

Honestly, it's kinda sad. She deserves someone who's as excited about this as she is. Someone who's gonna be there, all in. Not someone who needs "time to come around."

I just hope she realizes that before she gets her heart broken too badly. Because waiting around for someone to change is a waste of time. And life's too short to waste time on people who aren't all in.

It's just…ugh. People are complicated. And sometimes, things just don't work out the way you want them to. And that sucks. But you gotta deal with it. You gotta move on. You gotta find someone who's ready to be a dad. Or, you know, be a mom on your own. Either way. Just don't wait for Mark.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *music*? Like I don't have enough going on? But fine. I'll indulge you.

My favorite genre is…indie folk. Specifically, the kinda stuff that makes you feel simultaneously happy and sad. Like, The Moldy Peaches, obviously. But also Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, Sufjan Stevens…you get the idea.

It's not, like, super mainstream or anything. It's kinda quiet and introspective. And the lyrics are usually really honest and raw. Which, you know, I appreciate. Life isn't all sunshine and rainbows, and those songs get that. They don't try to sugarcoat things.

It's also good for thinking. Like, when I'm walking to school or just staring out the window, I can listen to that stuff and actually *process* my feelings. Which is important, because I have a lot of feelings. Mostly complicated ones.

And it's not all depressing, okay? There's a lot of beauty in it too. It's just…real. It feels like the people who make that music actually understand what it's like to be a human being. Which is more than I can say for a lot of pop stars.

So yeah. Indie folk. It's my thing. Don't judge. It's not like I'm listening to Nickelback or something. That would be a crime against humanity.

Ugh, pilates. Okay, look, don't get me wrong. I'm not against people who like it. It's just...not my scene. It feels a little too…intentional, you know? Like, you have to *try* to be zen and breathe and engage your core. I'm more of a "existential dread and a bag of chips" kind of person.

And exercising in general? It's…fine. I mean, I get it. It's good for you. My mom keeps trying to get me to go for runs with her. It's mostly just a lot of awkward silences and me trying not to die.

Honestly, with everything going on – the whole baby situation, Paul, everything – exercise was the last thing on my mind. I was mostly just trying to survive on caffeine and sarcasm.

But, like, Annie, she's really into it. She's all about "self-care" and "mindfulness." And I guess it's good that she has something that makes her feel good. It's just…not me.

I think I get enough exercise just from carrying around the weight of my own emotional baggage. And, you know, occasionally chasing after a runaway tater tot.

Look, I'm not saying I'm against it. I just think there are more important things in life. Like, finding the perfect vintage record or writing a really scathing email. Or, you know, preparing for motherhood.

So, yeah. Pilates? Not my thing. Exercise? Tolerable. But mostly, I'm just trying to keep it real. And sometimes, that means sitting on the couch and watching bad movies. Don't judge.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so the guitar thing with Mark…it’s complicated. It’s not like some super romantic movie montage, okay? It’s…awkward. And kinda sweet. And definitely a way for us to, like, *not* talk about the actual stuff we need to talk about.

See, he’s really good. Like, legitimately talented. And I…I’m okay. I can strum a few chords, sing a little off-key. It’s a stress reliever, you know? A way to not think about everything else.

But when we play together, it’s different. He’s patient, which is good, because I mess up a lot. And he doesn’t treat me like I’m stupid or anything. He just…helps me. And I can see him kinda relax, too. He gets all serious and focused when he’s playing, and it’s nice to see him like that. Not all brooding and intense.

But it also makes things weird. Because it feels…intimate. Like, we’re creating something together. And it makes me wonder if he sees me as more than just…the girl who’s having a baby.

And it’s a distraction. We spend hours just messing around with the guitar, and it’s easy to avoid talking about the adoption, or the future, or anything that actually matters. It’s like we’re building a little bubble around ourselves, and I know that bubble’s gonna burst eventually.

So, it’s good. And it’s bad. It’s a way for us to connect, but it’s also a way for us to avoid dealing with the real stuff. It’s…a temporary fix. And I know temporary fixes don’t usually last.

It definitely makes me feel things, though. And that’s kinda scary. Because I’m trying to be all practical and responsible about this whole baby situation, and then Mark starts strumming a song and suddenly I’m all confused and emotional. It’s a mess. A beautiful, confusing mess.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about music? It's…everything, honestly. Like, seriously. It's the only thing that doesn't judge me, you know? Everyone else has an opinion about what I should do, or how I should feel, or what's best for the baby. But music just…*is*.

When I found out I was pregnant, I was a mess. Like, a total, complete disaster. And I just started listening to The Moldy Peaches. A lot. Kimya Dawson's songs are just…real. They're about being awkward and messed up and feeling like you don't fit in. And that's exactly how I felt. It was like she was singing directly to me.

Then, as things got more complicated, and I started thinking about giving the baby up, I needed something different. Something…sadder. I got into Bright Eyes. Conor Oberst just gets heartbreak, you know? Even if it's not romantic heartbreak. It's just…loss. And that's what I was feeling.

But it wasn't all doom and gloom. I also listened to a lot of upbeat stuff. Arcade Fire, Death Cab for Cutie…music that made me want to dance, even when I didn't feel like it. It was a way to remind myself that there was still joy in the world, even when things were hard.

Music is like…a soundtrack to my life. It helps me process my feelings, it helps me escape, and it helps me feel less alone. It's a way to connect with something bigger than myself.

And honestly, sometimes it's just a distraction. When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I just put on my headphones and crank up the volume. It's a way to shut out the world and just…breathe.

It's kinda cheesy, I know. But music saved me, man. It really did. It helped me get through the hardest time of my life. And I don't know what I would have done without it. It's my therapy, my friend, my escape. It's just…everything.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a mess. A really big mess. And honestly, looking back, it was a stupid thing to do. But at the time? It felt like the only thing *to* do.

It wasn't about Vanessa and Mark, not really. It was about me. About feeling like I was suffocating. They were being…intense. Like, trying to fix everything, trying to make everything perfect. And it was just making it worse.

They were fighting, obviously. And I was stuck in the middle, feeling like I had to be the mediator, the peacemaker. But I wasn't a therapist! I was just a kid who accidentally got pregnant.

And it wasn't about not caring. I *did* care about them. I wanted them to be happy. But their happiness couldn't come at the expense of my own sanity.

So, yeah, I ran. I just…needed to get away. Needed to breathe. Needed to not be responsible for fixing their marriage. It was selfish, I know. But I was overwhelmed. I was scared. And I just needed a minute to figure out what *I* wanted.

It wasn't a solution, obviously. It just made things more complicated. But sometimes, when you're falling apart, you just need to run. Even if it's the wrong thing to do.

I learned a lot from that, though. About boundaries. About taking care of myself. And about the fact that you can't fix other people's problems. You can only fix your own.

It was a dumb move, but it was a necessary one. At least, that's what I tell myself.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…not a good moment.

Okay, so, like, everything was already a mess, right? Paul and I were fighting, and it wasn't even about the actual stuff we were yelling about. It was about…everything. About being scared, and confused, and feeling like I was messing everything up. And then Bleeker called, and it just…broke something.

When I was in the car, just…falling apart? It wasn't just sadness. It was…overwhelming. Like, all the weight of everything I was carrying just crashed down on me. The baby, Paul, my parents, school…it was too much.

I felt so stupid. So incredibly, ridiculously stupid. For getting myself into this situation in the first place. For thinking I could handle it. For thinking *anything* was going to be okay.

And I was mad. Mad at Paul, mad at Bleeker, mad at myself. Mad at the whole world for being so complicated.

It wasn't a pretty cry. It was, like, ugly sobbing. The kind where you can't breathe and your face feels all puffy and your throat hurts. I just wanted to disappear. To rewind time and make different choices.

It was…terrifying. Because for the first time, I wasn't sure I was strong enough to get through it. I thought I was this tough, sarcastic girl who could handle anything. But in that moment, I just felt…small. And lost.

It was a really awful feeling. And honestly, I don't think I'll ever forget it. It was a wake-up call. A reminder that even when you think you're in control, life can still throw you a curveball. And sometimes, all you can do is cry.



Ugh. I need a snack. Talking about that made me stressed.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the Jiffy Lube receipt. Seriously? That was…a moment. A very specific, very teenage moment.

So, yeah, I wrote "I'm pregnant" on the Jiffy Lube receipt and gave it to Paul. Why? Because I'm a mess, okay? A walking, talking, sarcastic mess. And I was panicking.

I mean, I knew I needed to tell him, but I couldn't just *say* it. It felt too…big. Too real. And I definitely wasn't ready for a serious conversation. I was 16, for crying out loud!

So I thought, what's the most ridiculous, unexpected way to tell someone you're pregnant? And a Jiffy Lube receipt seemed perfect. It's mundane, it's random, it's…just me.

I figured he'd be confused, maybe a little annoyed, and then eventually he'd get it. And he did. He was…surprisingly chill about it, actually. Which, honestly, was a relief.

It wasn't the most mature way to handle things, I know. But it was me. And sometimes, you just gotta be yourself, even if it's a little bit weird.

It was a way to break the ice, to make it a little less scary. And it worked. Sort of. It definitely made for a memorable conversation. And a really awkward trip to Jiffy Lube for Paul, I imagine.



Don't judge me, okay? I was a kid. And I was terrified. The Jiffy Lube receipt was just a coping mechanism. A really, really strange coping mechanism.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? A lot of things. Mostly just a giant, swirling mess of "Oh. My. God. This is going horribly wrong."

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. But I didn't realize it was *that* intense. I thought she was just, you know, a little quirky and maybe a little bit sad. I didn't expect a full-blown meltdown.

When she started crying, I just wanted to disappear. Like, become invisible. I felt so bad for her, but also…kinda responsible? Like, I'd unleashed some kind of emotional monster.

And then there was Paul. Poor Paul. He was just standing there, looking completely bewildered. Like, "What did I do?" It was awkward. Really awkward.

I was mostly just trying to figure out how to fix it. How to make it better. How to not completely ruin everything. But honestly, I didn't have a clue. I just stood there, feeling helpless and wishing I could rewind time.

It was a really stark reminder that this wasn't just about me and the baby. It was about everyone involved. And everyone had their own baggage and their own feelings. And sometimes, those feelings explode in really messy ways.

It was…a lot. And it definitely made me question everything. Like, was I doing the right thing? Was I making things worse? Was I just a giant screw-up?

But then I remembered why I was doing this in the first place. And I knew I had to keep going. Even if it meant facing a lot more awkwardness and a lot more tears. Because it was the right thing to do. For everyone. Even Vanessa. Even if she didn't see it that way at the time.

It was just…a really hard moment. And I'm still kinda cringing about it, to be honest.
