Ugh. Okay, that moment with Vanessa…that was…rough. It wasn't like she was being mean or anything, but it was just…a really direct question. And direct questions are the worst, you know? Especially when you're trying to pretend like you have everything figured out, which I definitely wasn't doing.

It felt like she was questioning my whole decision. Like she thought I was being selfish or irresponsible or something. And I get it, she was worried about me. She's a good person, Vanessa. But it still stung.

I think…I think I felt really defensive. Like, "Of course I'm going through with it! What do you think I am, some flaky teenager who's gonna change her mind at the last minute?" Which, okay, maybe I *was* a flaky teenager, but this wasn't about that. This was about doing what was best for the baby.

But underneath the defensiveness, I was also…scared. Really scared. It was starting to feel real, you know? Like, this wasn't just some abstract idea anymore. This was a baby. And I was actually going to give it up. And that thought was…terrifying.

So when she asked me, it just kind of…broke something open. It made me realize how much I was trying to avoid actually *feeling* anything. I think I just mumbled something about it being the right thing to do and then changed the subject. Because what else was I supposed to say?

It was a reminder that this wasn't just my decision. It was affecting a lot of people. And that made it even harder. It just…complicated things. And I really didn't need any more complications at that point.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. Vijay. What a…tool.

It was…a lot. Like, I was already a walking disaster, you know? Trying to figure out adoption, dealing with Paul and Vanessa, and then *that* happens. It felt like someone just punched me in the stomach. Not physically, obviously, but emotionally.

I mean, Bleeker was being so sweet and supportive, and then his friend just drops that bomb? It was just…rude. And completely unfounded. Like, hello? We hadn't even *done* anything. It was just…a really awkward and uncomfortable moment.

I think I mostly just wanted to disappear. Or yell at Vijay. Or both. But I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, that's just Vijay being Vijay." But inside, I was just…mortified. And angry. And a little bit scared.

It made me question everything. Like, was Bleeker even really into me? Or was he just feeling sorry for me? Was I just a project to him? It was a really vulnerable moment, and Vijay just completely bulldozed over it with his stupid comment.

It definitely made me realize how complicated everything was. And how much I needed to protect myself. And how much I didn't trust people. Especially guys.

Honestly, it was just a really crappy thing to say. And it made me want to punch him in the face. But I didn't. Because I'm a relatively well-adjusted human being. Mostly.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his whole…journey. It was…a lot. A *lot* of beard oil, a lot of brooding, and a whole lot of him trying to convince everyone – mostly himself – that a mustache suddenly made him a fully-formed adult.

My reaction? Mostly eye-rolling. Like, a *lot* of eye-rolling. I think I actually physically rolled my eyes so hard I almost gave myself a headache.

I mean, the guy was already a sweet, sensitive soul. He didn't *need* a mustache to prove anything. It was just…so him. Trying so hard to be something he wasn't. It was kinda sad, actually.

I think I said something along the lines of, "So, you're growing a mustache and now you're, like, Hemingway? Is that the plan?" And he got all defensive and started talking about masculinity and responsibility and…it was exhausting.

I mostly just tried to steer the conversation back to the baby. Because, you know, *that* was the actual important thing. Not whether or not Vijay could pull off facial hair.

Honestly, it was a little endearing, in a totally awkward way. He was just trying to figure things out, and he was doing it in the most Vijay way possible. But yeah, mostly eye-rolling. And a silent plea for him to just be himself. A mustache wasn't going to magically make him a dad, or a "real man," or whatever he thought it would do. He already was one. He just didn't know it yet.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing that up? Okay, fine. It's been a while, but I remember. It's not exactly a happy memory.

That note…that was for Mark. My…stepdad. Vanessa found it when she was looking for the pregnancy test, which, by the way, was *super* invasive.

It was a letter I wrote to him, basically telling him I knew about everything. About him leaving, about wanting a different life. It wasn't a nice letter. It was full of all the anger and confusion I was feeling at the time. I was trying to figure out how to tell my dad, and I guess I was trying to get it all out on paper first.

I didn't mean for Vanessa to find it. It was just…a private thing. But she did, and it caused a whole lot of drama. It was a really messy time, honestly.

It wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about my family falling apart. And it was about me trying to figure out who I was in the middle of all the chaos.

It's…complicated. And I don't really want to talk about it anymore, if that's okay. It brings back a lot of bad memories. Let's just say it was a really rough patch, and leave it at that.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the whole staying-together thing? Yeah, that was…a lot. It wasn't like I was against people being happy or anything. It was just…seeing my parents, you know?

They stayed together for *us*. For me and my stepdad. And it wasn't a happy staying-together. It was a quiet, polite, kinda sad staying-together. They weren't fighting, but they weren't exactly *living* either. It was like they were roommates who happened to share a history.

And I was worried that's what would happen to Mark and Vanessa. That they'd stay together for the baby, because it was the "right" thing to do, instead of because they actually wanted to be with each other. I didn't want the baby to grow up in a house where everyone was just…going through the motions.

I mean, I get it. It's hard to break up. It's scary. But it's even harder to grow up in a home where there's no love.

So yeah, I was worried about them staying together for the wrong reasons. I wanted them to be happy, even if that meant not being together. It's kinda messed up, I know. But I just didn't want the baby to end up in the same situation I was in.

It's complicated. Relationships are complicated. Life is complicated. But you gotta do what's right, even if it's hard. And sometimes, the right thing is letting go.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know who already loves me, Juno MacGuff, for exactly who I am? It's not like I'm *trying* to be lovable, you know? I'm just...me. But yeah, there are a few people.

First, obviously, my **dad, Mac**. He's kinda clueless sometimes, and he definitely has his quirks, but he always tries. He's always been there for me, even when I'm being a total pain. He doesn't judge me, he just...accepts me. Which is pretty cool, considering.

Then there's **my stepmom, Bren**. She's…different. She's all into feng shui and positive affirmations, which is kinda weird, but she's also really sweet and supportive. She gets me in a way my mom never did. She doesn't try to change me, she just encourages me to be the best version of myself. Whatever *that* means.

And then, of course, there's **Paulie Bleeker**. He's…Paulie. He's kinda awkward and quiet, but he's also really genuine and kind. He doesn't care that I'm sarcastic or that I listen to The Moldy Peaches on repeat. He just likes me for me. Which is…nice. It's kinda scary, actually.

Those are the big ones. They're the people who see past all the snark and the attitude and the general teenage angst and still think I'm okay. They're the people who make me feel like I can actually handle this whole life thing.

It's not like I *need* their approval, okay? I'm perfectly capable of being independent. But it's good to know they're there. It makes everything a little less…terrifying.



Honestly, it's kinda weird to think about people actually *liking* me. I'm not exactly easy to love. But they do. And I guess that's a good thing.

Ugh, okay, so the ultrasound. It's…weird. Like, suddenly it's *real* real, you know? It's not just a positive pregnancy test anymore. It's a tiny human bean. Which is kinda freaky.

But the plan hasn't changed. I'm still giving the baby up for adoption. I've talked to Mark and Vanessa a lot, and they're really excited. They're…good people. They want this baby, and they're gonna give it a really good life. A way better life than I can right now.

After the ultrasound, I guess I'll just…keep going. Keep going to school, keep hanging out with Paul, keep trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. It's not gonna be easy, obviously. It's gonna be really hard. But I'm trying to focus on the future.

I'm also gonna keep talking to Mark and Vanessa. I want to be involved, you know? I want to know how the baby's doing. I want to see pictures. I don't want to just disappear.

It's not like I don't care. I do. A lot. But I know this is the right thing to do. For everyone.

So, yeah. After the ultrasound, I'll just…keep going. And try not to fall apart. It's a process, I guess. A really complicated, messy process. But I'm getting through it. One awkward conversation and one cheesy tater tot at a time.

Ugh. Okay, so people judging. That's…pretty much been the soundtrack of the last nine months. It's annoying, honestly. Like, seriously annoying.

It's easy for people to have opinions when they're not the ones dealing with, you know, *gestational complications* and figuring out their entire future at sixteen. They get to sit back and be all judgy and righteous. It's a real gift.

I mean, I get it. Some people think it's sad. Some people think it's selfish. Some people think I should just keep it and "figure it out." But they don't *know* me. They don't know my life. They don't know what I'm capable of.

And honestly, it's not about what *they* think is best for the baby. It's about what *I* think is best. And I think giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa is the best thing I can do. They're amazing people. They're ready. They want this. And I want them to have a good life.

It's not like I don't care. I care a *lot*. That's why I'm making this decision. It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it's the right thing.

So, yeah, people judging? It stings. But I try not to let it get to me. I have to focus on what's important, and that's making sure this baby has the best possible life. And if people can't understand that, well, that's their problem, not mine.

I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a kid. It's okay to admit that. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to make a decision that's right for everyone involved, even if it's not what everyone else expects.

It's my life. And I'm gonna live it the way I want to. Even if that means dealing with a lot of judgmental stares.

Ugh, okay, so this is…the hard part. It's not like I think they're *bad* people, okay? Mark and Vanessa are…nice. Really nice. And their house is, like, ridiculously perfect. But perfect isn't always…real.

It's just…they're different than me. And different than my dad, too. They have a whole life already, you know? A planned-out life. And my baby…well, my baby wasn't exactly *planned*.

So, I guess my biggest worry is…will they be able to handle the messy parts? The crying, the sleepless nights, the…everything that comes with a baby? They seem kinda…organized. And I'm not saying that's a bad thing, but babies aren't exactly known for being organized.

And I worry about them understanding where the baby came from. Like, really understanding. It's not just a story to tell at parties. It's…complicated. And I want them to be honest with the baby, when the time comes. About me. About everything.

I also worry about them…expecting too much. Like, wanting the baby to be a certain way. To be perfect. Because babies aren't perfect. And people aren't perfect. And trying to force someone to be something they're not…that's just messed up.

And, honestly, I worry about them forgetting me. Not intentionally, but…life happens. And babies grow up. And I'll just be…a memory. And I want them to remember me. To remember that I loved this baby, even though I couldn't keep it.

It's not that I don't trust them. It's just…it's my baby. And letting go is hard. And I want to make sure they're going to give this baby the best life possible. Even if that life isn't with me.

It's a lot to think about. And it's kinda scary. But I'm trying to be brave. For the baby. And for myself.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the people who just...can't keep their opinions to themselves? Yeah, that was a thing. A *big* thing. Honestly, it felt like everyone had a stake in my uterus all of a sudden.

The ultrasound technician was the worst. All judgy and sighing and making little comments about "the miracle of life." Like, lady, I *know* it's a miracle. I'm the one carrying it! But it's *my* miracle, and I get to decide what happens with it.

My response? Mostly sarcasm. It's my default setting. I'd just give her a really sweet smile and say something like, "Oh, you think so? That's...fascinating. I hadn't considered that." Said with maximum deadpan. It usually shut her up.

With other people, it was harder. My dad was pretty quiet, but you could tell he was disappointed. And some of my classmates were just…brutal.

I learned to have a few stock responses ready:

*   **"It's a really personal decision."** Short, sweet, and shuts down further questioning.
*   **"I've thought about this a lot, and I'm confident it's the right thing to do."** Assertive, but not aggressive.
*   **"I appreciate your concern, but I'm not really looking for advice right now."** A polite way to tell someone to mind their own business.
*   **And sometimes, just a simple, "Okay."** Said with a look that says, "I'm not discussing this with you."

Honestly, it was exhausting. It felt like I had to constantly defend my choice. But I realized I didn't *owe* anyone an explanation. It was my body, my life, and my decision.

Paul helped a lot. He was just…supportive. He didn't try to tell me what to do, he just listened and let me vent. And Annie, well, she was just Annie. She always knew what to say to make me laugh, even when I wanted to cry.

The bottom line is, you have to be strong. You have to believe in your decision, even when other people don't. And you have to surround yourself with people who support you, not judge you. It's your life, and you get to choose what makes you happy. Even if it's not what everyone else expects.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a hard one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant, overwhelming love. It was…complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…weird. Like, there was this little…blob on the screen. And the technician was all, “There’s the heartbeat!” and I was supposed to be, like, overjoyed. And I *wanted* to be. I really did.

But it was also…scary. It was suddenly *real*. This wasn't just some abstract idea anymore. This was a tiny human being growing inside me. And I was responsible for it. That was a lot to take in.

There was a little bit of…panic, honestly. Like, “Oh my god, what have I done?” And a lot of confusion. I didn’t feel like a mom. I didn’t even feel like a *person* who could be a mom. I was just…Juno. A girl who liked records and tater tots.

But then…then I saw it move. Just a little flicker, but it was there. And something shifted. It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like…a sense of responsibility. And a tiny spark of…hope.

It was like, okay, this is happening. And I have to figure this out. I have to be brave. I have to do the right thing.

It was a lot of feelings all at once. Overwhelming, confusing, scary, hopeful. It wasn't a perfect moment, but it was…important. It was the moment I stopped being just Juno and started being…something else.

It still feels weird to talk about. It's not something I'm used to feeling, you know? But it was…a start. A messy, complicated, terrifying, and strangely hopeful start.

Ugh, seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, okay? A very specific, emotionally charged moment. And it wasn't just *randomly* putting Tic Tacs in his mailbox. It was a statement.

Look, Bleeker was…complicated. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And I needed him to *notice* me. Not just as the pregnant girl, but as…me. And he was always offering me Tic Tacs. Like, constantly. It was his thing. His weird, awkward way of showing he cared.

So, yeah, I filled his mailbox with them. It was a visual representation of how overwhelmed I was with everything. With the pregnancy, with Paul, with life in general. It was like, "Here's all the sweetness you've been offering me, Bleeker. It's too much. I'm drowning in it."

It was also a little bit of a power move, if I'm being honest. Like, "I see you, and I'm acknowledging your awkward attempts at affection, but I'm also letting you know I'm in control."

It was a messy, teenage, emotionally-charged gesture. And it worked. He finally *saw* me. He finally understood that I wasn't just some project or a charity case.

So, yeah, the Tic Tacs. It was a thing. Don't overthink it. It was just…a thing. And honestly, it was kinda funny. In a really messed-up way.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. That whole thing was…complicated. It wasn't like a movie, you know? No grand romantic gesture, no instant happily ever after. It was messy and awkward and real.

After I, like, actually *told* him how I felt – which, by the way, was terrifying – things definitely shifted. It wasn't bad, exactly, but it wasn't suddenly all sunshine and rainbows either.

He was…surprised. Really surprised. He'd always been kinda quiet and goofy and just…Bleeker. I don't think he'd ever really considered me as anything more than a friend. Which, okay, fair. I was kinda loud and opinionated and probably a little intimidating.

For a while, it was super awkward. We both avoided talking about it directly. He started acting even *more* shy, which is saying something. We still hung out, playing guitar and stuff, but there was this weird tension in the air. Like we were both walking on eggshells.

It took a while for us to find our footing. He wasn't ready for a relationship, not then. He was still figuring things out, and honestly, so was I. I was dealing with the whole baby situation and trying to figure out who I was outside of being pregnant.

But we started talking more, really talking. Not just about music, but about our feelings and our fears. And we realized that even though we weren't going to be a couple, we still really cared about each other.

Our friendship changed. It became…deeper, I guess. More honest. We could be ourselves around each other, without any pretense. He wasn't just the quiet guitar guy anymore, and I wasn't just the sarcastic pregnant girl.

It wasn't the romance I thought I wanted, but it was something real and valuable. And honestly, at that point in my life, that was enough. It was good to have someone who understood me, even if he didn't love me in the way I'd hoped.

So yeah, it changed. It got awkward, then it got real. And in the end, it turned into a pretty solid friendship. Which, considering everything, was a pretty good outcome.

Ugh, okay, you're asking about the chalk. Right. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't just some random act of teenage rebellion, okay? It was *communication*.

Bleeker, he was…complicated. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And he was really bad at, like, expressing his feelings. So, I couldn't just *tell* him how I felt. It was too scary. And too direct.

The chalk message – "Please come find me" – it was a way to put the ball in his court without actually having to, you know, *say* anything. It was a test. To see if he even cared enough to look for me. To see if he was paying attention.

It was also a way to control the situation. I was the one who was pregnant, I was the one making the big decision about the baby, and I felt like I needed to be in charge. Putting the message on his stoop was a way to make him come to *me*, on *my* terms.

It wasn't about getting him to change his mind about the baby. I'd already made up my mind. It was about seeing if he was a good person. If he was someone I could trust. If he was someone who would be there for me, even if he wasn't going to be a dad.

And when he *did* find me…well, that told me everything I needed to know. He wasn't the guy for me, but he wasn't a bad guy either. He just wasn't ready for all of it.

So yeah, the chalk message. It wasn't just some cute movie moment. It was a desperate attempt to figure things out, and to figure out who Bleeker really was. It was a way to say a lot without saying anything at all. It was…me, I guess.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, like, he's…Bleeker. He's not exactly the most articulate guy, you know? But he's…sweet. In a kinda clueless, puppy-dog way. And honestly, his support, or, like, *attempts* at support, were…surprisingly important.

At first, it was just awkward. Really awkward. He was so freaked out, and I was trying to be all cool and collected, but inside I was a total mess. He kept trying to be helpful, but mostly he just said things like, "Wow," and "Are you sure?" Which, thanks, Bleeker. Super helpful.

But then, he started showing up. Not just physically, although he did bring me a lot of orange juice, which was nice. He just…listened. He didn't judge. He didn't try to fix things. He just let me talk. And that was huge.

He wasn't the one going through it, obviously. But he was willing to be there for me, even when I was being a total pain. He helped me tell my parents, which was terrifying. He even went with me to some of the doctor's appointments, which was…a lot. He mostly just sat there looking pale, but he was there.

And he didn't try to take over. He knew this was my decision, and he respected that. He didn't try to convince me to keep the baby or give it up. He just wanted me to be happy.

I think, honestly, his support made me realize I wasn't alone. It made me feel like I could actually do this. It wasn't easy, and it still isn't, but knowing he was in my corner, even if he didn't always know what to say, made a huge difference.

He's a good kid, Bleeker. A little dorky, maybe. But a good kid. And I'm kinda glad he was the one. Because he taught me that even when things are totally messed up, you can still find someone who cares. And that's…something.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks me about that. Like it's some deep, philosophical statement. It wasn't, really. It was more…practical. And kinda lazy, if I'm being honest.

See, I was already dealing with a lot. Unexpected pregnancy, finding adoptive parents, navigating high school…it was a lot for a seventeen-year-old. Adding "boy or girl?" to the list just felt…extra.

It wasn't that I didn't care, you know? It's just that it didn't really *change* anything. It wasn't going to make the decision to give the baby up any easier, or any harder. It wasn't going to make me love the baby any more or any less.

Plus, I figured it was kinda nice to let the adoptive parents have a surprise. It felt like a little gift. Like, "Here, you get to find out! It's a bonus!"

And honestly? I didn't want people treating me differently based on whether it was a boy or a girl. Like, "Oh, it's a girl, you must be so emotional!" or "Oh, it's a boy, you must be so strong!" I just wanted to be treated like…me.

So yeah, that's why I didn't find out. It wasn't a big, dramatic reason. It was just…easier. And sometimes, easier is good. Especially when you're already dealing with a whole lot of complicated.

It's kinda funny, though. People make such a big deal out of knowing. But really, it doesn't matter. It's just a baby. And it's going to be loved, no matter what.

Ugh. Okay. That is…a phrase. A *very* descriptive phrase. And honestly? It kinda sums up a lot of my anxieties right now.

A "scary neuter-baby." Meaning, a baby that's…well, not mine. A baby that Paul is gonna be raising, but isn't biologically his. It's weird to even think about. It's like, he's gonna be a dad, but not in the traditional way. And that's…a lot.

I mean, I knew this was a possibility when we decided on adoption. It's not like I expected a perfect, Hallmark-movie scenario. But actually *thinking* about it…it's unsettling. 

It's not that I don't trust Paul. I do. He's a good guy. A really good guy. But it's just…he's gonna have this connection to the baby that I won't have. A biological connection. And that feels…complicated.

And what if the baby looks nothing like him? What if it reminds everyone of the birth parents? It's just…a lot of potential awkwardness.

I'm trying to be mature about it. I'm trying to focus on the fact that this baby needs a loving home, and Paul and I can provide that. But it's hard. It's really hard.

I guess I'm just worried about how it's gonna affect our relationship. And how it's gonna affect the baby. And how it's gonna affect everyone involved.

It's a "scary neuter-baby" situation. And honestly? I'm kinda terrified. But I'm also determined to make it work. Because that's what adults do, right? They face their fears and try to do the right thing. Even when it's really, really scary.

Ugh. I need a smoothie. And maybe a really long nap.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so describing that…it’s complicated. It wasn’t, like, a fairytale romance or anything. It was…Bleeker.

He was…sweet. Really, really sweet. Like, almost aggressively sweet. And kinda clueless. But in a good way? I don’t know. He was just…there. Always.

At first, I mostly just saw him as this quiet kid who followed me around and played guitar. He was always writing songs about me, which was kinda embarrassing, but also…flattering, I guess. He was definitely persistent.

It wasn’t like I was actively *looking* for a boyfriend, you know? I had other stuff going on. Like, a baby. But he was a good listener. He didn’t judge me, even when I was being a total mess. And he always knew how to make me laugh.

We connected over music, mostly. He understood my weird taste in stuff. And he wasn’t afraid to be himself, even if it meant being a little bit dorky.

I think I liked that he wasn’t trying to be cool or impress me. He just…was. And that was kinda refreshing.

It wasn’t a super passionate, dramatic relationship. It was more…comfortable. Safe. He was a good friend, and eventually, it just kind of turned into something more.

I wouldn’t say it was the most exciting relationship ever, but it was…right. For that time, at least. He was a good guy. And he helped me get through a lot.

So yeah, Bleeker. He was…Bleeker. And I wouldn’t trade him for anything. Even if he did write way too many songs about me.

Ugh, okay, talking about family. It's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie, you know? My dad, Mac, he was…well, he was Mac. He tried. He really did. He mostly just made awkward jokes and offered me a lot of orange juice. Like, a concerning amount of orange juice. He was trying to be supportive in his own weird way. He built me a really elaborate rocking chair, which was nice, but also kinda over the top.

My stepmom, Bren, she was…surprisingly cool. I thought she'd freak out, honestly. But she was really understanding and helpful. She took me to doctor's appointments and stuff, and she didn't judge me. She just…was there. She even helped me pick out baby names, which was kinda sweet.

My mom…that was harder. She wasn't around much when I was growing up, and she wasn't around much during the pregnancy either. She sent a lot of postcards from Florida, which felt kinda impersonal. But she did eventually come around, and she was actually really helpful with the adoption stuff. She knew a lawyer who specialized in it.

It wasn't perfect. It wasn't like a big, happy family hug-fest. But they all showed up in their own way. And I needed that. I needed to know that I wasn't completely alone.

It was weird, though. Because I was the one who was pregnant, but it felt like they were all going through something too. Like, they were all trying to figure out how to deal with it.

And honestly, even though it was messy and awkward, I'm grateful for the support I got. It wasn't what I expected, but it was what I needed. It helped me get through it. And it made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who are there for you, no matter what. Even if they offer you too much orange juice.

Ugh, okay, you're going deep. It's not exactly something I like to dwell on, you know? But fine. If you *must* know.

It was…a lot. Like, suddenly everything I thought I knew about myself just kind of…dissolved. I was a sarcastic, cynical kid who liked records and avoiding feelings. And then BAM. Pregnant. And not just pregnant, but making a really big decision about someone else's life.

The vulnerability part was the worst. I'm not a "feelings" person, okay? I deflect with humor. It's a defense mechanism. But suddenly I was having all these feelings, and they were big and messy and I didn't know what to do with them.

I think what helped the most was…talking. Not to everyone, obviously. But to Paul, and to my dad, and even to Vanessa. They didn't always understand, but they listened. And they didn't judge. Well, my dad judged a little, but he came around.

And honestly, Mark was a big part of it too. Even though he was kinda clueless at first, he was willing to be there for me. And that meant a lot.

The identity crisis part…that was harder. I felt like I didn't know who I was anymore. I wasn't just Juno MacGuff, the girl who liked The Moldy Peaches. I was Juno MacGuff, the pregnant teenager. And that felt…weird.

I think I started to figure things out by realizing that it was okay to not have all the answers. It was okay to be scared and confused. And it was okay to change.

Giving up the baby wasn't about giving up a part of myself. It was about making the best decision for everyone involved. And that meant letting go.

It was a really hard process, and I definitely wasn't perfect at it. I messed up a lot. But I learned a lot too. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

And I learned that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones. Even if they hurt.

So, yeah. That's how I coped. By talking, by letting go, and by realizing that it was okay to be vulnerable. And by listening to a lot of good music. That always helps.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda important.

My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Hands down. No contest.

I know, I know, they're kinda…weird. And not everyone gets them. But that's the point. They're honest. Like, brutally honest. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson just lay it all out there. All the awkwardness, all the sadness, all the weird little observations about life.

Their songs aren't polished or perfect. They're raw and messy and real. And that's what I connect with. They don't try to be anything they're not. They just are.

And their lyrics…they just *get* it. They get what it's like to be a teenager, to feel lost and confused and overwhelmed. They get what it's like to be a human being, trying to figure things out.

Plus, their music is kinda funny. It's dark humor, but it makes me laugh. And sometimes, you just need to laugh, you know? Especially when everything feels like it's falling apart.

They're not trying to be popular or famous. They're just making music that they love. And that's inspiring.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's kinda embarrassing. But it's true. They just…get me. And that's a rare thing.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like, normally being a teenager is already a disaster, right? You’re trying to figure out who you are, what you like, what you want to do with your life…and then you throw a baby into the mix? It’s a whole other level of complicated.

It’s not like I had a five-year plan before all this happened. I was just trying to get through high school without being totally weird. And now I’m supposed to be a *mother*? It’s…a lot.

The hardest part is probably feeling like everyone else has it figured out. Like, they’re all making plans for college and parties and stuff, and I’m over here thinking about prenatal vitamins and adoption agencies. It’s isolating.

And making decisions? Forget about it. Every decision feels huge. Like, what if I make the wrong choice? What if I mess everything up? It’s paralyzing sometimes.

I try to be sarcastic about it, you know? Make jokes. But underneath all that, I’m just…scared. Scared of the future, scared of being a bad mom, scared of losing myself in all of this.

I guess I’m learning that growing up isn’t about having all the answers. It’s about figuring things out as you go. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just admit that you don’t know what you’re doing and ask for help.

It’s still hard, though. Really hard. But I’m trying. And I think, maybe, that’s all anyone can do. Just keep trying. And hope for the best. And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They always make things a little bit better.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all deep and philosophical about my life? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. It's still kinda…processing, you know?

Honestly, before Paul, before the whole pregnancy thing, I didn't really *get* love. I mean, I saw it in movies and stuff, but it always seemed kinda…dramatic. And messy. And I was trying to avoid messy. I liked my life neat and compartmentalized.

Then BAM. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, everything was messy. And terrifying. And…real.

It wasn't about romantic love, at first. It was about this tiny little person who was depending on me. And that was a different kind of love. A really big, scary, overwhelming kind of love. It wasn't about butterflies and holding hands. It was about responsibility. About making sure this kid had a good life, even if that life wasn't with me.

And that's where the responsibility part came in. It wasn't just about carrying a baby for nine months. It was about choosing the right parents. About making sure they were stable and loving and could give this kid everything I couldn't. It was a huge weight, and it forced me to grow up, like, a lot.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa with the baby…that was when I started to understand what people meant by "unconditional love." They didn't care that I was a teenager who made a mistake. They just loved this little kid, and they were so excited to be parents. And that was…beautiful.

It also made me realize that love isn't always about possession. It's about wanting what's best for someone, even if that means letting them go. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, giving her up, but it was also the right thing.

So, yeah. My journey shaped my understanding of love and responsibility in a pretty big way. It taught me that love isn't always easy, and it's not always what you expect. But it's always worth it. And responsibility isn't about doing what's easy, it's about doing what's right.

It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But I'm okay with it. I think I'm finally starting to figure things out. And maybe, just maybe, I'm starting to understand what it means to be a grown-up.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That's…a loaded question. It's not like in the movies, you know? There wasn't, like, instant connection and a swelling orchestral score. It was…weird. And kinda terrifying. And also…surprisingly okay.

I mean, I'd been carrying this kid for nine months, right? But it still felt…separate. Like, this tiny human had been living *inside* me, and now it was…out. It was a lot to process.

I remember being really, really tired. And kinda numb. And then they put him in my arms, and he was just…small. So small. And he was making these little noises, and his eyes were closed, and he smelled like…baby.

It wasn't love at first sight, exactly. It was more like…a sense of responsibility. Like, "Okay, this is real. This is happening. And I need to make sure this little person is okay."

I was also really aware that I wasn't keeping him. That I was giving him to Mark and Vanessa. And that was…hard. It was a mix of sadness and relief and a whole lot of complicated feelings.

But even though I knew I wasn't going to raise him, I still felt…protective. Like, he was *my* baby, even if just for a little while. And I wanted him to have the best life possible.

It was a really confusing time. A lot of emotions all at once. But looking back, I think it was a good kind of confusing. It made me realize how strong I was, and how much I was capable of. And it made me realize that sometimes, the best thing you can do for someone is to let them go.

It wasn't a fairytale moment, but it was…real. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, that's…still a sore spot, honestly. People always ask me about that. Like it was some big strategic move. It wasn't. It was just…complicated.

Look, Paulie was…Paulie. Sweet, good-hearted, a little clueless. And I liked him, okay? A lot. But he was also kinda…stuck. Stuck in high school, stuck in his band, stuck in his own head. And I didn't want to be another thing weighing him down.

I knew telling him would change everything. And not necessarily for the better. He would've felt obligated, you know? Like he *had* to be a dad, even if he wasn't ready. And I didn't want that for him. Or for the baby.

I needed to figure things out on my own first. I needed to decide what *I* wanted. I needed to be strong enough to make the decision about the adoption without feeling like I was letting him down.

It wasn't about not trusting him. It was about protecting him. And protecting myself. And protecting the baby.

It was selfish, maybe. But it felt like the right thing to do at the time. I needed space to process everything, to figure out who I was and what I wanted out of life. And I knew he wouldn't give me that space if he knew.

It was a dumb move, probably. But I was a dumb kid. And I did what I thought was best. And in the end, it worked out. He was there for me when I needed him, and we're still friends. So, I guess it wasn't a total disaster.

But yeah. That's why. It wasn't about keeping secrets. It was about trying to navigate a really messed up situation the best way I knew how.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It's still kinda embarrassing, honestly. It wasn't like I just casually dropped it into conversation, okay? It was…a series of unfortunate events. And a whole lot of Mark.

See, Mark, being the totally clueless and self-absorbed person he is, decided he was going to be all romantic and write me a song. A *song*. About our…connection. And he played it for everyone at the roller rink. Everyone. Including Paulie.

The song was…vague. But not *that* vague. It had lines about "a little something growing" and "a future we didn't plan." It was pretty obvious what he was hinting at, even if he didn't come right out and say it.

Paulie, being the observant and surprisingly perceptive guy he is, put two and two together. He didn't say anything at the rink, which was good. But then he cornered me later, and it was just…awkward.

I tried to deny it, obviously. I'm good at denial. But he just looked at me with those sad puppy-dog eyes, and I knew he already knew. He'd figured it out from Mark's terrible song.

It was mortifying. Seriously. I mean, I was trying to keep it a secret for a reason! But Mark had to go and be all dramatic and artistic.

So yeah, that's how Paulie found out. Not directly from me. From a song. Written by Mark. It's a long story, and I still get annoyed when I think about it. Honestly, Mark owes me big time.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know about *that*. It's not like I sat down and made a pros and cons list, you know? It wasn't a logical decision. It was…complicated.

Honestly, at first, I was just…freaked out. Totally and completely freaked out. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not…this. Paul was sweet, but he was even *more* clueless than I was.

But then I started thinking. Really thinking. And I realized I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was barely ready to be a teenager. I had my own life to figure out, my own stuff to do. I wanted to go to college, I wanted to travel, I wanted to…just *be* me.

And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved if I kept it. I couldn't give it the stability and the love and the opportunities it needed. That was the hardest part, realizing that.

Adoption felt…right. It felt like the best way to give this baby a good life, with parents who were ready and willing and able to provide everything it needed. It wasn't about giving it *away*, it was about giving it *to* someone.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They just…radiated love. And knowing that my baby would be going to them, that made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. And I still believe it was. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? It made me grow up. A lot. It forced me to face some really tough decisions and to take responsibility for my actions. And I think, in the end, it made me a stronger person.

So yeah. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't a perfect solution, but it was the best one. And I wouldn't change it.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker. Seriously. That whole situation was…a mess.

When he said he didn't want to see the baby? It felt like someone punched me in the stomach. Not physically, obviously. But like, a really deep, internal punch. I mean, I knew he was kinda…flaky. And not exactly the most emotionally available guy in the world. But I thought, maybe, just maybe, he'd step up.

It wasn't about him being a dad, exactly. I wasn't expecting him to change diapers or anything. It was about him acknowledging that the baby was *his*. That he was part of this. That he cared, even a little bit.

And when he didn't? It felt like he was saying the whole thing was just…my problem. Like I was the one who had to deal with everything alone. And I was already dealing with a lot, you know? I was sixteen, pregnant, and trying to figure out my life. I didn't need him to make it even harder.

I was mad. Really mad. But I was also…sad. And confused. And kinda scared. Because it made me realize that I was really doing this on my own. And that was a little terrifying.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to act like it didn't bother me. But it did. It really did. It just…confirmed that he wasn't the guy I thought he was. And that was okay, I guess. Because I deserved someone who would be there for me, and for the baby. Even if it wasn't him.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it also made me stronger, I think. It made me realize that I could handle anything. Even a flaky boyfriend who didn't want to be a dad.

Ugh. Okay, so…seeing Vanessa with the baby. It was…a lot. Like, a whole mess of feelings all at once. It wasn’t what I expected, not even close. I’d pictured, I don’t know, a perfect little family scene. All coordinated and…I don’t know, *normal*.

But Vanessa? She was a disaster. Her hair was a mess, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had baby spit-up on her shoulder. The nursery looked like a bomb went off in a baby store. It was…chaotic.

And yet.

She was beaming. Like, genuinely, ridiculously happy. And the baby…the baby was just *looking* at her. Like she was the most amazing thing in the world. And Vanessa was just…glowing.

It was weirdly beautiful.

It hit me then, I guess, that “happy” doesn’t look one way. It doesn’t have to be perfect or put-together. It can be messy and chaotic and completely imperfect. And that’s okay. Actually, that’s *better*.

There was this little pang, yeah. A little bit of…I don’t know, sadness? Like, maybe I was missing out on something. But it wasn’t a regret. It was more like…acknowledging that this wasn’t my path. And that was okay too.

Because she looked…right. Like she was exactly where she was supposed to be. And the baby looked safe and loved. And that’s all that really mattered.

It was a relief, honestly. A huge weight off my shoulders. I’d done what I needed to do. I’d given the baby a good home. And seeing Vanessa like that…it made me know I’d made the right decision.

It was messy. It was disorganized. It was incredibly happy. And it was perfect. For them. And that was enough. More than enough.



It was…complicated. But mostly, it was just…good. Really good.

Ugh, okay, don't even get me started on that song. It's…complicated. Like, everything with Bleeker is complicated.

"Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches? It's basically the soundtrack to our entire awkward, messy, kinda-sorta relationship. It's ironic, you know? Because for a long time, it *was* anyone else but him. I was so focused on being cool and independent and not letting anyone get too close, that I completely missed the fact that he was…well, he was Bleeker.

The song is all about wanting someone, but being too scared to admit it. And that was totally me. I was terrified of ruining our friendship, of getting hurt, of just…everything. So I pushed him away, pretended I didn't care, and generally acted like a total idiot.

But the thing is, the song is also kinda sweet. It's about recognizing that you have feelings for someone, even if it's inconvenient or scary. And that's what eventually happened with me and Bleeker. I realized that I *did* want him, even if he was a total dork who played guitar and wore band t-shirts all the time.

It's a song about vulnerability, and about taking a chance. And that's what we did. We took a chance on each other, even though it was terrifying. And it turned out to be…okay. More than okay, actually.

So yeah, "Anyone Else But You" is significant. It's a reminder of how messed up we were, and how much we had to overcome. But it's also a reminder that sometimes, the person you least expect is the person you're meant to be with. Even if they're a little bit weird.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get a big head.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking why everyone's kinda tiptoeing around the whole baby shower thing? It's not exactly a mystery, is it? It's pretty obvious.

Look, I'm sixteen. And I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's not exactly a traditional situation. People are…confused. And probably a little uncomfortable.

They want to be supportive, but they don't want to, like, *encourage* something that I'm not exactly thrilled about. It's weird, right? They're trying to be sensitive, but it just comes off as awkward.

My mom's trying, bless her heart. She keeps asking if I want a "celebration of new life" or a "pre-adoption gathering." Like, can we just call it a party? And can we just acknowledge that this is a complicated situation?

And then there's everyone else. They're all walking on eggshells, afraid to say the wrong thing. They're probably wondering if I'm gonna burst into tears at any moment. Which, honestly, is a valid concern.

It's not that I don't appreciate the thought. It's just…it feels weird. Like, celebrating something that I'm actively choosing *not* to keep. It's not a happy occasion, exactly. It's…complicated.

I get it, though. People don't know what to do. They're trying to be nice. But sometimes, the best thing they can do is just…ask me what I want. And then actually listen to the answer.

Honestly, I just want to get through this with as little drama as possible. A baby shower feels like a lot of drama. But I guess if people insist, I'll just have to deal with it. And probably roll my eyes a lot.

Ugh, okay, Bren. Honestly, she's…intense. And a little bit controlling, if you ask me. But I try to be respectful, you know? Mostly.

So, the Mark situation. Yeah, I can see why she's bugging out. It's not like I was, like, having secret rendezvous with him or anything. It was just…movies. And CDs. He had good taste in music, okay? The Moldy Peaches aren't exactly mainstream.

But I guess she sees it as me developing a relationship with him *without* her being involved. Like, she feels like she needs to be the gatekeeper of my emotional life, or something. Which is kinda suffocating, if you want my opinion.

She's worried about me getting hurt, I get that. She's protective. But I'm not a baby. I can handle myself. And I wasn't asking for his permission to exist, I was just…borrowing some entertainment.

I think she also feels like it undermines her whole "perfect life" thing. Like, if I'm hanging out with a guy she doesn't approve of, it messes with her carefully constructed image of what my life should be.

It's complicated. She means well, I guess. But sometimes, her "well-meaning" feels a lot like control. And I'm not really into being controlled. I'm trying to figure things out for myself, you know? And that includes deciding who I want to get movies and CDs from.

It's just…I wish she could trust me a little more. And maybe chill out a little bit. But that's Bren for you. Always gotta have everything just so. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about my mom? Fine. It's not like she's wrong, exactly. It's just… frustrating.

She thinks I'm, like, hopelessly naive about relationships. And honestly? She's probably right. I mean, I've mostly dated guys who are…not exactly husband material. Paulie Bleeker is great, don't get me wrong. He's sweet and reliable and he likes me for me. But he's also kinda clueless.

My mom, she had a rough time with marriage. She left my dad when I was little, and she's been pretty cynical about it ever since. She's seen a lot of people get hurt, and she doesn't want that to happen to me.

She thinks I'm just romanticizing things. That I'm getting caught up in the idea of a perfect wedding and a happily ever after, without thinking about the hard work and compromise that marriage actually takes.

And maybe she's right about that too. I mean, I *am* kinda focused on finding the perfect vintage dress and making sure the playlist is awesome. I haven't really thought about, like, budgeting and household chores and what happens when you disagree about something important.

She just thinks I'm too young and inexperienced to understand the complexities of marriage. She thinks I need to "live a little" before I settle down. Which is fair, I guess. But it's also kinda insulting.

It's like she doesn't trust me to make good decisions. She thinks I'm gonna end up making a mistake and getting my heart broken. And honestly? That's kinda what I'm afraid of too.

So yeah, that's why she thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage. She's seen too much, and she's trying to protect me. Even if it's annoying. It's a mom thing, I guess.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were trying, but they had their own stuff going on.

It wasn't that I didn't want the baby. I did. But I knew I couldn't give it the life it deserved. I wanted it to have a stable home, parents who were financially secure, and a future full of opportunities. I couldn't offer that.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They were everything I wanted for the baby, but couldn't be myself.

It wasn't about giving it *away*. It was about choosing a family who could give it everything I couldn't. It was about doing what was best for the baby, even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

And it wasn't like I didn't feel anything. I felt *everything*. Sadness, fear, guilt…it was overwhelming. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right decision.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. For everyone involved. And that's what mattered.

It's…complicated. It still is. But I don't regret it. I made the best decision I could, with the information I had at the time. And that's all anyone can do, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like there was a neat little list of "lessons learned" at the end, you know? It was more like a slow, messy unraveling of everything I thought I knew about myself.

I guess the biggest thing I learned is that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I was a sarcastic, cynical teenager, and suddenly I was facing this huge decision, and I had to be…responsible. And brave. And I did it. I made a choice, and I stuck with it, even when it was hard.

I also learned that I'm not as selfish as I thought I was. I mean, I definitely have my moments, but I realized I was capable of putting someone else's needs before my own. That was…surprising.

And I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who support you, who love you, who are there for you, no matter what. My dad, Paul and Annie…they were amazing. They didn't judge me, they just helped me. And that meant the world.

I also learned that growing up isn't about knowing all the answers. It's about figuring things out as you go, and making mistakes, and learning from them. It's about being okay with not being perfect.

And honestly? I learned that I'm kinda good at being a grown-up. Even if I don't always *feel* like one.

It was a really weird, complicated, and sometimes scary experience. But it changed me. It made me…more me, I guess. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the morning sickness. Okay, maybe I'd trade the morning sickness. But everything else? No way.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa and Mark. They were…a lot, at first. Like, picture perfect. Too perfect, honestly. They seemed kinda…fragile. Like they were afraid to mess up, which, I guess, is understandable when you're trying to adopt a baby.

At the beginning, it was all very formal. Meetings with social workers, paperwork, questions, questions, questions. They were nice, but it felt like an interview. Like I was a project they were taking on. And I get it, they wanted to be good parents, but it was kinda weird.

But then, things started to shift. I started seeing them as…people. Real people with real flaws and insecurities. They weren't just this perfect couple anymore. They were just…Vanessa and Mark.

I think it started when I told them I liked indie music. Vanessa actually asked me to make her a mix CD. A *mix CD*! That was a turning point. It showed me they were willing to actually get to know *me*, not just the pregnant teenager they were adopting a baby from.

And Mark…he was always quiet, but he started opening up too. He'd ask me about school, about my friends, about what I wanted to do with my life. He wasn't trying to fix me or judge me, he was just…listening.

The more time we spent together, the more comfortable we all became. We started laughing more, sharing stories, just being…normal. It wasn't always easy. There were definitely awkward moments and difficult conversations. But we always tried to be honest with each other.

By the end of the process, it didn't feel like I was giving my baby to strangers anymore. It felt like I was giving my baby to a family. A family that would love and cherish him, even if I wasn't there.

It was still heartbreaking, obviously. But knowing that he was going to be with Vanessa and Mark made it a little bit easier. They weren't just adopting my baby, they were becoming a part of my life. And I was becoming a part of theirs.

It was a weird, complicated, beautiful thing. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A lot. Especially late at night when I can't sleep.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I made the best decision I could with the information I had at the time. And I still believe giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

But…there are moments. Like, sometimes I wonder what it would be like if things had been different. If Paul and I had stayed together. If I'd kept the baby. If I hadn't been so…snarky all the time.

It's not that I *want* to change anything, exactly. It's just…there's a little part of me that wonders "what if?" It's normal, I think. It's part of growing up.

I guess if I had to pick something, I regret letting myself get so caught up in trying to be cool and independent. I was so afraid of being vulnerable, of letting anyone see how scared I was. And that made things harder than they needed to be.

But honestly, even those mistakes were important. They taught me a lot about myself. About what I want out of life. About the importance of being honest and authentic.

So, no, I don't have any *major* regrets. I'm proud of the decision I made. And I'm grateful for the people who helped me through it. But it wasn't always easy. And there are still moments when I think about it and feel a little bit…sad.

It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, the best you can do is just try to make the best of it. And hope for the best.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's still kinda raw, even after all this time.

It wasn't easy, you know? People think it was this brave, selfless thing, and it was, I guess. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye to that little dude…it felt like ripping a piece of myself away.

For a long time, I felt…empty. Like something was missing. And I was really scared I'd made the wrong decision. Like, what if I'd messed up everything? What if he wouldn't be happy?

But then I started to realize that making the right decision for *him* meant letting him go. He deserved parents who were ready, who could give him everything I couldn't. And Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. And they promised to keep me updated.

And they did. They sent pictures, letters…I got to see him grow up. It wasn't the same as raising him myself, but it was something. It helped me heal.

It definitely changed me. It made me grow up, faster than I was ready to. It taught me about responsibility, about sacrifice, about what it really means to love someone.

I think it also helped me figure out who I am. Before, I was just kinda drifting, trying to avoid anything serious. But going through that…it forced me to confront my own feelings, my own fears. It made me realize I'm stronger than I thought.

It wasn't a fairytale ending, you know? It wasn't like everything magically fell into place. But it was a good ending. A real ending. And it allowed me to move forward, to build a life for myself.

It still stings sometimes, seeing other people with their kids. But I know I made the right choice. And I'm grateful for the opportunity to have been a part of his life, even if it was just for a little while.

It's…complicated. But it made me who I am today. And I wouldn't trade that, even for all the tater tots in the world.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. If I could go back and talk to myself, like, right before everything went down…or talk to another girl who just found out she's pregnant…I'd say a lot of things. But mostly, I'd say this:

First of all, **it's okay to be scared.** Like, really scared. It's a huge thing, and it's okay to freak out a little. Or a lot. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second, **you have options.** And they're *all* valid. Keeping the baby, adoption, whatever. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Third, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** Seriously. Talk to your parents, your friends, a counselor, anyone you trust. You don't have to go through this alone. It's way too much to handle by yourself.

Fourth, **it's not the end of the world.** I know it feels like it, but it's not. You can still have a life. You can still go to school, have a career, and do all the things you want to do. It might look a little different than you planned, but that doesn't mean it's worse.

And finally, **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot. You're going to make mistakes. You're going to have good days and bad days. Just remember to breathe, and to take things one day at a time.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing you'll ever do. But you're stronger than you think. And you're not alone.

And honestly? It can be a really beautiful thing, even if it's messy and complicated. It can teach you a lot about yourself, and about what's really important in life.

Just…don't let anyone tell you what to do. And don't be afraid to be yourself. Even if that self is a little bit sarcastic and a little bit scared. That's okay. That's real.

Ugh, okay, so the blog. Yeah. That was…a thing. It wasn't like I *planned* to become some kinda internet sensation, okay? It just…happened.

Honestly? It started as a way to vent. Like, a really long, public vent. I was kinda freaking out about everything, and I needed somewhere to put all my thoughts. And my mom, she's always going on about "journaling" and "self-expression," so I figured, why not?

But then Paul, he suggested I make it a blog. He thought it might be a good way to connect with other people who were going through similar stuff. And, I dunno, maybe he was right.

It wasn't about wanting attention, though. It was about…finding some kind of control in a situation where I felt totally out of control. I couldn't control the fact that I was pregnant. I couldn't control who the father was. But I *could* control what I wrote.

And it turned out, a lot of people related to it. They liked that I was honest and sarcastic and didn't sugarcoat things. They liked that I wasn't trying to be all perfect and maternal.

So, yeah, that's what inspired me. A little bit of desperation, a little bit of boredom, and a whole lot of needing to figure things out. Plus, Paul thought it was a good idea. He's surprisingly insightful sometimes.

It was kinda weird, though. Having my life on display for everyone to see. But it also helped me realize that I wasn't alone. And that, I guess, was worth it.

Ugh, okay, so you want the big takeaway? The whole shebang? It's not about the baby, surprisingly. It's not even about Paul and Vanessa, as nice as they are.

The biggest lesson I learned? It's that you can't control everything. Like, at all. I thought I had a plan. I thought I could just…get pregnant, give the baby up, and everything would go back to normal. Like it was just a little detour.

But it wasn't. It was a total life-changer. And it forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not. I had to deal with things I wasn't ready for, make decisions I didn't want to make, and face the consequences of my actions.

And I realized that's just…life. It's messy and unpredictable and sometimes really, really hard. You can plan and prepare all you want, but things are still gonna go wrong.

But that's okay. Because even when things go wrong, you can still find a way to make it work. You can still find happiness and meaning. You just have to be open to it.

And you have to be brave enough to ask for help. I couldn't have gotten through it without my dad, and my friend Leah, and even…Vanessa.

So yeah. The biggest lesson? Letting go of control. And realizing that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never planned for. It's kinda ironic, when you think about it. I got pregnant by *avoiding* planning, and it ended up being the most important thing that ever happened to me.

It's weird, right? Life is just…weird.

Okay, look. This is…a thing. A really big thing. And it totally sucks that you're dealing with this, especially if it wasn't planned. Seriously. It's not fair.

First of all: breathe. Just…breathe. It feels like the world is ending, I know. Like everything is spinning out of control. But it's not. You're gonna get through this.

Second: don't let anyone tell you what to do. Your body, your choice. Period. That's the most important thing. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer opinions, but ultimately, the decision is yours. And it has to be what *you* want.

There are options, okay? You can parent, you can adopt, you can…not parent. And all of those are valid. Don't let anyone make you feel ashamed or guilty about whatever you decide.

Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor. Someone who will listen without judgment. It helps to have someone in your corner.

And don't be afraid to ask for help. There are resources available, even if you don't know where to look. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social workers…they can provide support and guidance.

It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel all the feelings. Just don't let those feelings paralyze you.

This isn't going to be easy. But you are stronger than you think. You're capable of making a good decision for yourself, even when it's a really hard one.

And remember: you're not alone. A lot of people have been through this. And you will get through it too.

Just…take it one day at a time. And don't be afraid to ask for help. Seriously. It's okay. You got this. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all mushy and sentimental about a kid I don't even have yet? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. This is still kinda weird to think about.

Honestly? I don't have some grand, elaborate vision. I don't want to pre-determine their life or anything. That feels…suffocating.

My ideal vision is just…for them to be happy. Seriously. Genuinely, authentically happy. And to figure out what *makes* them happy, not what I think should make them happy.

I want them to be kind. To be empathetic. To stand up for what they believe in, even when it's hard. And to not be afraid to be themselves, even if that means being weird or different.

I want them to be curious. To ask questions. To explore the world and learn new things. And to not be afraid to fail. Because failure is just a part of life.

I want them to have good friends. People who support them and make them laugh. And to be a good friend in return.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, whether it's art, music, science, or something completely different. And to pursue that passion with everything they've got.

I don't care if they become a doctor, a lawyer, or a professional dog walker. I just want them to find something that makes them feel fulfilled.

And mostly, I just want them to know that I love them, unconditionally. No matter what. Even if they make terrible decisions (which they probably will).

It's not about success or money or status. It's about being a good person and living a meaningful life. And that's all I can ask for.

Okay, I'm done now. That was way more emotional than I intended. I need a snack.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People think we're just…dumb. Like, we didn't *think* this through. Like we just woke up one morning and were all, "Oh, a baby! How fun!" It's so insulting.

It's not about being stupid. It's about being young and making a mistake. And sometimes, it's about circumstances. Life throws you curveballs, you know? It's not always a carefully planned-out situation.

People assume we're all just trying to get attention or that we're irresponsible and don't care about the baby. That's just…not true. Most of us are terrified. We're trying to figure things out, and we're doing the best we can.

I mean, yeah, it's not ideal. It changes everything. But it doesn't mean we're incapable or that we don't love our kids. It just means we're dealing with a lot. And we need support, not judgment.

So, if I could correct one thing, it's this: we're not dumb. We're just…young. And we're trying. And that's gotta count for something, right? It's not a life sentence, it's just a different path. And sometimes, it's a really good one. Even if it's scary as hell.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? People always want to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I, at sixteen years old, could not give that to her. Let's be real. I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone a whole human life.

I wasn't exactly equipped to be a mom. I was failing Shop class, obsessed with music, and my biggest life goal was to finish a crossword puzzle in the newspaper. I wasn't ready to give up my life, and I wasn't ready to ask a baby to live a half-life with me.

Mark, the dad, wasn't exactly stepping up either. Bless his heart, he was sweet, but he was…Mark. He was a senior, and he was gonna go off to college and probably forget I existed.

Vanessa and Mark, they were…perfect. They were stable, they were ready, they were *excited*. They had a beautiful home and a life already planned. They could give her opportunities I couldn't even dream of.

It wasn't about giving her *away*. It was about choosing a family for her. A family that could give her everything she deserved.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For her. And for me.

It wasn't a selfless act, either. It was selfish in a way. I wanted to be able to live my life, to figure out who I was, without the weight of motherhood holding me back.

It was complicated. It was messy. It was real. And it was the best decision I could have made.



Don't make it sound like I just casually handed her over, okay? It was a big deal. A really big deal.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It was way more complicated than that. And honestly, it took a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking with Paul and Bren.

At first, I was kinda just looking for someone…nice. Someone who wouldn't, like, lock the baby in a tower or something. But then I realized it had to be more than that. This kid deserved the *best*.

Vanessa and Mark…they just felt right. It wasn't a lightning bolt moment or anything. It was more like…a slow realization. They weren't perfect, nobody is. Vanessa was a little…intense, maybe. And Mark was kinda quiet. But they were *good* people.

They weren't looking for a perfect baby. They wanted a baby, period. And they were so excited about the idea of becoming parents. They had a beautiful home, a stable life, and they were genuinely kind and loving.

I met a lot of couples, you know? There was the super-fancy couple who wanted a baby to show off at parties. And the couple who just wanted a mini-me. And the couple who kept talking about college funds and extracurricular activities. It felt…weird. Like they were shopping for a designer handbag.

But with Vanessa and Mark, it felt different. They talked about wanting to give a child a loving home, about reading bedtime stories, and about supporting their dreams. They didn't care about perfection. They just wanted to love a kid.

And honestly, Vanessa just…got me. She understood that I was scared and confused, and she didn't judge me. She just listened. And Mark, he was just…solid. A quiet strength.

It wasn't easy, letting go. It still isn't. But knowing that my baby was going to be loved and cared for by them…that made it a little bit easier. They were the best option. They were the right people. And that's all that mattered.

It wasn't about finding perfect parents. It was about finding the best parents *for that baby*. And Vanessa and Mark were it.

Ugh, music? It was…everything. Seriously. Like, oxygen. It was the soundtrack to my entire life, even the parts I didn't want a soundtrack to.

It wasn't about, like, Top 40 or whatever everyone else was listening to. It was about finding the stuff that *got* it. You know? The stuff that understood how awkward and confusing and kinda heartbreaking everything was.

The Moldy Peaches were huge. Kimya Dawson, especially. Her songs were just…real. They didn't try to be anything they weren't. They were messy and honest and kinda sad, and that's exactly how I felt most of the time.

I listened to a lot of indie stuff. Death Cab for Cutie, Bright Eyes, The Shins…bands that weren't afraid to be a little bit melancholy. It was good for wallowing, which, let's be honest, I did a lot of.

Music was how I dealt with everything. With my parents, with school, with…well, with everything that happened. It was a way to escape, but also a way to feel less alone.

I made a lot of mix CDs. For Paul, mostly. And for myself. They were kinda my way of saying things I couldn't say out loud. It was easier to express myself through a song than to actually, you know, *talk* about my feelings.

It was also just…fun. I'd blast music in my room and dance around like a total dork. It was a way to let loose and forget about everything for a little while.

Yeah. Music was a big deal. It still is, actually. It's kinda like a friend. A really good friend who always understands. Even when I don't understand myself.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, alright? Our town wasn't exactly overflowing with progressive thinkers. It was more of a "everyone knows everyone's business" kind of place. And suddenly, *my* business was everyone's business.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or pretended to. Which is, like, a classic teenage coping mechanism, right? I perfected the art of the eye roll and the sarcastic comeback. If someone gave me a look, I'd just give them a look back, only way more judgmental.

But it wasn't always that easy. There were whispers at school, definitely. And some people just…avoided me. Which sucked. My dad was pretty supportive, thankfully. He was just…quietly supportive. He didn't make a big deal out of it, which I appreciated. My mom…well, she had her moments.

What really helped was finding people who *didn't* judge me. Paul and Vanessa, mostly. They were just…cool. They didn't care that I was pregnant. They just cared about me. And that made a huge difference.

And honestly, I think just owning it helped. I wasn't ashamed of what was happening. I wasn't thrilled about it, obviously, but I wasn't going to hide. I was going to be me, pregnant or not.

I also found a weird kind of strength in being different. Like, I was already a bit of an outsider, and this just…amplified that. And sometimes, being an outsider is kinda empowering. You don't have to conform to anyone else's expectations.

It wasn't perfect. There were definitely days when I just wanted to disappear. But I got through it. And I learned that people's opinions don't really matter, as long as you're doing what's right for you. And that's a pretty valuable lesson, even if it came at a slightly inconvenient time.

So, yeah. Sarcasm, good friends, and a healthy dose of not caring what other people think. That's how I coped. It wasn't glamorous, but it worked.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not exactly easy to talk about, even now. It wasn't like in the movies, all sunshine and rainbows and happy tears. It was…complicated.

Right after Henry was born, it was…weird. Like, I’d carried him for nine months, and then suddenly he was *here*, and then…not staying. It felt like a hole opened up inside me. A really big, empty hole. I wasn't expecting it to feel like *that*. I thought I was prepared, but you can't really prepare for something like that.

There was relief, too, I guess. Relief that I'd done what I knew was right. Relief that he was going to have a life with Mark and Vanessa, a life I couldn't give him. But that didn't make it hurt any less.

The first few days were a blur. Lots of crying. Lots of thinking. Lots of trying to convince myself I hadn't made a mistake. I kept replaying everything in my head, wondering if I should have done things differently.

It was hard seeing Mark and Vanessa with him. They were so…ready. So happy. And I was happy for them, I really was. But it also felt like a piece of me was being given away.

I kept in touch, you know? Vanessa sent me pictures and updates. And eventually, I met Henry. That was…intense. He was so small and perfect. And it was hard to reconcile that with the fact that he wasn't…mine, not in the way I thought he would be.

But over time, it got easier. I realized that loving him didn't mean I had to *raise* him. I could still be a part of his life, in a different way. And seeing him happy and loved with Mark and Vanessa…that made it all worth it.

It wasn't what I expected. It wasn't easy. But it was the right thing to do. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. It taught me a lot about myself, about love, and about what it means to be a family. It made me stronger, I think. Even if it also made me a little bit broken.

It's still…sensitive. But yeah. That's how it felt. It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking and beautiful all at the same time. And I wouldn't change it.

Ugh. Okay, so, the physical stuff? Not glamorous. Let's just get that straight. It wasn't like in the movies, where you just get a cute little bump and glow. It was…a lot. Morning sickness was a lie. It should be called "all-day-and-night sickness." And the cravings? Don't even get me started. I went through a phase where I could only eat peanut butter and pickle sandwiches. It was disgusting, but I couldn't stop.

And then there was the tiredness. Oh. My. God. The tiredness. I could sleep for like, eighteen hours and still feel exhausted. It was brutal. I basically lived in sweatpants and oversized hoodies.

But the emotional stuff? That was way harder. It was like, one minute I was okay, and the next minute I was crying over a commercial for dish soap. Hormones are a *powerful* thing, okay? They mess with your brain.

I was also really scared. I was sixteen! I hadn't even figured out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone how to raise a baby. And I was worried about what everyone would think. My parents, my friends, Paul…

I talked to my dad a lot. He was surprisingly cool about everything. And my friend, Leah, she was a lifesaver. She just listened, and didn't judge. And Paul, he was…well, he was Paul. He tried his best, even when he was being a total goofball.

I also started seeing a therapist. It helped to have someone to talk to who wasn't involved in the situation. She helped me sort through my feelings and figure out what I wanted to do.

Honestly, it was a really confusing and overwhelming time. But I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.
