And it definitely made me overthink everything with Mark. He was…different. More mature, I guess. But it also made me suspicious. Like, what did he *want* from me? Was he just looking for a temporary fix? I was constantly analyzing his motives, looking for the catch.

It took me a long time to realize that my parents' relationship wasn't a template for all relationships. That it was possible to find someone who was genuine and trustworthy. And that it was okay to let myself be vulnerable.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I could rely on myself. That I didn't *need* a relationship to be happy. Which is good, I guess. But it also made it harder to ask for help when I needed it.

It's still something I think about, you know? The impact it had on me. But I'm learning to let go of the past and focus on building healthy relationships now. It's a work in progress.

It's just…seeing your parents fail at something so fundamental makes you question everything. It makes you wonder if you're doomed to repeat their mistakes. But you're not. You can choose a different path. You can build a different kind of life.



It's complicated. It just…is.

Ugh, okay, that's a loaded question. Like, am I supposed to brag about myself? That feels weird. But fine, if you insist.

I think what makes my story…different…isn't the pregnancy itself, honestly. Plenty of people get pregnant. It's the way I *handled* it, I guess. I didn't freak out and run away, or try to pretend it wasn't happening. I just…dealt with it. On my own terms.

I mean, I'm not exactly a poster child for responsible decision-making, okay? But I took ownership of my choices. I didn't let anyone tell me what to do. I decided what was best for me, and for the baby. And that wasn't easy.

And I think it's kinda rare to see a movie about a pregnant teenager that doesn't involve a lot of drama and shame. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, obviously. It was messy and complicated and sometimes really sad. But it was also funny and hopeful.

I think people connected with the fact that I was just trying to figure things out, like everyone else. I wasn't trying to be perfect. I was just trying to be me. And I think a lot of people can relate to that.

Plus, I have a pretty sarcastic worldview. And I say what I think. Which, you know, can get me into trouble. But it's also kinda refreshing, I think.

So yeah, I guess what makes my story special is that it's honest. It's real. And it's about a girl who's trying to find her own way in the world, even when things get really, really complicated.

And maybe it shows people that it's okay to be a little bit weird. And that it's okay to make mistakes. And that it's okay to not have all the answers. Because nobody does.

Ugh, good friends. Those are…important. Especially when life is being a total mess, which, let's be real, is most of the time. Okay, so, what do I look for? It's not about, like, being popular or having the coolest stuff. It's way more complicated than that.

First off, **honesty.** Like, brutal honesty. I don't need someone to tell me what I *want* to hear, I need someone to tell me what I *need* to hear. Even if it's, like, "That outfit is a disaster" or "You're being totally irrational." I can handle it. Mostly.

Then there's **a good sense of humor.** Someone who can make me laugh, even when I want to cry. Someone who doesn't take themselves too seriously. Life's too short to be all serious all the time.

**Loyalty** is huge. I need someone who has my back, no matter what. Someone who won't talk behind my back or ditch me when things get tough.

And **being a good listener.** Not just waiting for their turn to talk, but actually *listening* to what I have to say. And not judging me. Because, honestly, I already do enough of that myself.

Also, **shared weirdness.** I like people who are a little bit…off. People who don't fit in. People who have their own unique quirks and interests. It makes things more interesting.

And finally, **someone who doesn't try to fix me.** I'm a work in progress, okay? I don't need someone to tell me how to be a better person. I just need someone to accept me for who I am, flaws and all.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's genuine. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves. And someone who can handle my sarcasm. Because there's a lot of it.



It's a high bar, I know. But good friends are worth their weight in gold. Or, you know, vintage records. Whatever.

Ugh. Okay, so the pregnancy. Yeah. It kinda…shifted things. Like, a lot. It wasn't just about me anymore, which is a weird feeling when you're, like, used to being pretty self-contained.

With my dad, it was…complicated. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He still doesn't quite *get* me, you know? He kept offering to pay for everything, which was nice, I guess, but also kinda suffocating. It felt like he was trying to fix things, instead of just letting me figure it out. We had a lot of awkward silences. But we're getting there. He's learning to just…be there.

My mom was…well, my mom. Super supportive, but also kinda overbearing. She wanted to know every detail, and she had opinions on everything. Which is just my mom being my mom. But it was a lot. We had some good talks, though. She actually understood more than I thought she would.

And then there's Paul. Oh, Paul. That was…a whole thing. At first, he was kinda freaked out, obviously. But he stepped up. He really did. He wasn't perfect, and we had our fights, but he was there for me. He helped me think through my options, and he supported my decision to give the baby up for adoption. That meant a lot. It made me see him in a different light.

And Bleeker? He was…Bleeker. Still kinda clueless, but in a sweet way. He tried to be helpful, but mostly he just offered to make me mix CDs. Which, honestly, was kinda perfect.

It made me realize who my real friends are. The people who were there for me, no matter what. And it also made me realize that some relationships are just…different now. They've changed. And that's okay.

It's like, before the pregnancy, I was just Juno. And now I'm Juno…who's a mom. Or, was going to be a mom. It's a weird title to carry around. It definitely changed how people see me, and how I see myself. It's still kinda settling. But it's…good. Mostly. It's just…a lot.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts with Juno. Don't expect anything profound, alright? I'm just a teenager. But people have asked me what I think about stuff, so I've had to, like, *think* about stuff.

I guess the biggest thing is…honesty. Not necessarily telling everyone *everything*, because that's just rude. But being real with yourself and with the people you care about. No pretending. No BS. Life's too short for that.

And I think people should be allowed to be who they are, you know? Like, no judgment. Everyone's got their own stuff going on. You don't know what someone else is dealing with, so you shouldn't just assume you know what's best for them.

I also think it's important to be responsible for your own choices. Like, you mess up, you own it. You can't just blame other people or make excuses. That's just weak.

And I believe in being kind. Even to people you don't like. It doesn't mean you have to be their best friend, but you should treat them with respect. Because everyone deserves that.

I'm not really into labels or categories. I don't care if you're popular or a nerd or whatever. Just be a good person. And be true to yourself.

I guess those are some of the things that matter to me. It's not like I have a whole philosophy of life or anything. I'm just trying to figure things out as I go. And trying not to be a total jerk in the process.

It's kinda weird to have to put it into words, actually. It's just…how I see things. And it's probably still evolving. I mean, I'm still learning, right?

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, "Oh, let's name him Bartholomew because it sounds fancy." It was way more complicated than that.

See, Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were adopting him, they had a whole list of names already. Really traditional names. Like, "Henry" and "William" and stuff. Which are fine, I guess. But they didn't feel…right. Not for *my* kid. Even though I was giving him up, he was still *my* kid, you know?

I wanted something a little different. Something that felt…hopeful. And a little bit quirky. Because that's kinda how I am.

I was flipping through this old record album – The Velvet Underground, if you must know – and I saw the name "Phoenix" on the back. And it just…stuck.

It's a symbol of rebirth, of rising from the ashes. And that felt really powerful. Like, even though I was giving him up, he was going to have a new life, a new beginning. And he was going to be strong and resilient.

Plus, it's just a cool name. It sounds good.

I told Mark and Vanessa about it, and they were hesitant at first. It wasn't on their list. But I explained what it meant to me, and they eventually agreed. They said it felt right for him.

So, yeah. That's how he got the name Phoenix. It wasn't about finding the perfect name, it was about finding a name that felt meaningful and hopeful. And that's what mattered.

It still kinda makes me tear up a little when I think about it. But it's a good tear-up. A hopeful tear-up.

Ugh, okay, so…the whole pregnancy and adoption thing. It was…a lot. Like, a whole *life* crammed into nine months. And honestly, I learned a ton. Mostly stuff I didn't even know I needed to know.

First off, I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. I mean, I was a teenager, dealing with something huge, and I didn't fall apart. I made a really hard decision, and I stuck with it. That took guts, even if I didn't feel like I had any at the time.

I also learned that people are…complicated. Like, my parents, Paul and Bren, they were amazing. But they didn't always understand. And Mark, Van, even Sean…they all had their own stuff going on. It made me realize that everyone's fighting their own battles, and you gotta try to be understanding, even when it's hard.

The world isn't black and white, either. It's all shades of gray. There's no easy answers, and sometimes the right thing to do is also the hardest thing to do. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

I learned a lot about love, too. Not just romantic love, but the love between friends, family, and even…the love you feel for a baby you know you can't keep. It's a weird kind of love, but it's real.

And I learned that it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to just…be yourself. Even if yourself is a sarcastic, cynical teenager who's trying to figure out her place in the world.

Honestly, the whole experience made me grow up a lot. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel…stronger. More confident. And I know that whatever life throws at me, I can handle it. Because I've already handled something pretty big.

It wasn't what I expected, but it was…good. In a weird, complicated, life-changing kind of way. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe for a lifetime supply of tater tots. But that's beside the point.

Ugh. Okay, looking back…that’s a loaded question. It’s not like I can just rewind and hit “undo” on everything, you know? But yeah, there are definitely things I would have done differently. Not huge things, but…little tweaks.

I think I would have let myself *feel* things more, instead of always trying to be sarcastic and deflect with a joke. It was a defense mechanism, obviously. But sometimes I just shut down, and that wasn’t helpful. Especially with Paul. He was…good. And I didn’t always let him in.

I also would have maybe been a little less judgmental of Mark. He was trying, okay? He was a clueless jock, but he wasn’t a *bad* person. I was just so quick to write him off. I was scared, and I took it out on him.

And maybe I would have talked to my dad more. He was…weirdly supportive, considering. But I still kept a lot from him. I should have just been more honest.

But honestly? I don’t know if I would change anything major. Because everything that happened, even the messy parts, led me to where I am now. And I’m…okay. I’m figuring things out. I’m learning who I am.

I think the biggest thing I learned is that it’s okay to not have all the answers. It’s okay to be scared and confused and uncertain. And it’s okay to ask for help.

So yeah, maybe a few little things. But overall? I think I did the best I could with what I had. And that’s all anyone can really do, right?

It was a weird, messy, beautiful experience. And I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Even the cheesy tater tots. Okay, maybe I’d trade a few of those. But not all of them.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. A *lot*. Honestly, it's kinda my specialty. Life rarely goes according to plan, you know? Especially when you're, like, a teenager navigating a surprise pregnancy and trying to figure out your whole future.

So, how do I deal with it? Well, first, I let myself be bummed out. Like, really bummed out. It's okay to feel sad or angry or frustrated when things don't work out. You gotta acknowledge the feelings, otherwise they just fester.

But then, I try to remember that it's not the end of the world. Seriously. It's just a bump in the road. A detour. A really annoying plot twist. But it's not the whole story.

I also try to focus on what *did* go right. Even if it's just something small. Like, maybe the plan fell apart, but I still managed to make a really good mix CD. Or maybe I still had a good conversation with a friend.

And I try to find the humor in it. Because sometimes, you just have to laugh. Otherwise, you'll cry. And crying is exhausting.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I leaned on my friends, my dad, even Paulie Fleischer. It's good to have people who support you and remind you that you're not alone.

Basically, I try to be realistic. Things are gonna go wrong. Life is messy. But you can get through it. You just gotta keep moving forward, even when it's hard. And maybe eat a really good cheeseburger. That always helps.

It's not about pretending everything's perfect. It's about accepting that things are imperfect, and finding a way to deal with it. And sometimes, that just means taking a deep breath and saying, "Well, that sucked." And then moving on.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to analyze my friendship with Leah? It's not like I sit around psychoanalyzing things, you know? But fine. It's a good question, actually. It wasn't always smooth sailing.

At the beginning, Leah was…well, she was Leah. Super into everything, super enthusiastic, kinda overwhelming. I thought she was a little bit much, honestly. She was always trying to get me to join her band or go to rallies or just *feel* things more intensely. I was more of a "observe and comment" kind of person. I liked my space.

But she stuck with me. Even when I was being a total mess about the pregnancy. Even when I was being sarcastic and pushing her away. She just…kept showing up. And she didn't judge me. She didn't try to tell me what to do. She just listened.

I think it evolved because she saw through all my defenses. She knew I was scared and confused, even when I was pretending to be all cool and collected. And she didn't try to fix me. She just accepted me, flaws and all.

And I started to see her differently too. I realized she wasn't just being overly enthusiastic, she was genuinely passionate about things. And she was a really good friend. She was the one who actually helped me sort through my feelings about giving the baby up for adoption. She didn't try to sway me either way, she just helped me figure out what *I* wanted.

By the end, she wasn't just my friend, she was like…family. Someone I could always count on. Someone who understood me, even when I didn't understand myself.

It wasn't a perfect friendship, we still had our moments. But it was real. And it was important. It showed me that it's okay to let people in, even when it's scary. And that sometimes, the people who annoy you the most are the ones who care about you the most.

So yeah, it evolved from "slightly annoying friend" to "essential human being." It's a pretty good story, if you ask me.

Ugh, okay, that's a loaded question. "Favorite" is a strong word. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Morning sickness was…not cute. And people constantly touching my stomach? Seriously invasive.

But if I had to pick something…I think it was the feeling of, like, *something happening*. Like, I was creating a whole person. Inside me. It was kinda weird and kinda amazing at the same time.

And honestly? The kicks. That was pretty cool. It felt like…a secret little dance party going on in my belly. It was the only time I didn't feel totally alone, I guess. Like, there was someone else in there with me, even if they were just a tiny little human doing gymnastics.

It also made me think about stuff. About responsibility and the future and what it means to be a parent. Which was terrifying, but also kinda…good.

I wouldn't say I *enjoyed* being pregnant. But it definitely changed me. It made me grow up a little bit. And it made me realize that I was capable of more than I thought.

So yeah, the kicks. That was probably my favorite part. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.
